LEAD: A bidding war has broken out among the nation's business schools for finance professors.

An $81 Million Bond Issue For Shelby County, Tenn.
LEAD: Shelby County, Tenn., priced a total of $81 million in general-obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding.
The bonds will be used for public improvement, schools and special purposes.


Six Guilty Of Stock Conspiracy
LEAD: The five principals of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership and a former trader with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. were found guilty yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.


U.N. Today
LEAD: Trusteeship Council  Meets at 11 A.M.


F.T.C. Approves Pennwalt Takeover
LEAD: An agreement to sell a New Jersey chemical plant has cleared the way for the $1.05 billion takeover of the Pennwalt Corporation by the French oil giant Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine.
The Federal Trade Commission unanimously accepted an agreement that allows completion of the $132-a-share deal, the companies said.


Koch Endorsed By Police Union For Re-election
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch received the endorsement of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday in his campaign for re-election.

10-Day Shutdown For Ford Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut its plant in Atlanta for 10 days, beginning next Monday.
The shutdown, the second for the Atlanta plant this summer and the fifth involving a Ford plant, followed weak orders for its products, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable.


McDonnell To Sell Unit
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had agreed to sell its network systems business to British Telecommunications P.L.C. for $355 million.


European Prices Rise
LEAD: Consumer prices in the European Community rose three-tenths of a percentage point in June over the previous month, the community's statistical agency, Eurostat, reported today.
The office said prices were 5.4 percent higher than a year earlier.
The European Community warned that, despite the moderate price increase in June, inflation rates were ''clearly higher than in 1988'' for the 12 member states, except for Denmark, Greece and the Netherlands.

Salomon Units to Pay Fine Of $4 Million in Cocoa Case
LEAD: Phillip Brothers Inc., the commodity marketing and trading subsidiary of Salomon Inc., and three affiliates agreed today to pay $4 million, a record fine, as part of a settlement of Federal disciplinary charges.


Vietnam to Allow Prisoners Who Aided the U.S. to Leave
LEAD: Vietnam has agreed to resettle in the United States at least 19,000 former prisoners who had been closely associated with the United States-backed Government in Saigon, State Department officials said today.


Hooked on Scanning
LEAD: SCANNERS often transform the thinking of their users as quickly as they transform paper documents.
Some people move from ''I can't imagine why I would ever want one of these things,'' to ''I can't imagine how I'll ever again get by without one'' in a matter of minutes.


Bird Returns to Court After a Back Injury
LEAD: Larry Bird, who was expected to miss from four to six weeks after fracturing a bone in his lower back over the weekend, made a stiff, gingerly return to the basketball court yesterday.


Bloch Goes Home to Washington And Has a Chat With an Austrian
LEAD: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat under investigation for espionage, returned to his Washington home from New York today trailed by Federal agents and reporters, and chatted for 45 minutes with a correspondent for Austria's state-financed television service.


2D THREAT ISSUED; BUSH CONVENES SECURITY PANEL; Videotape Released
LEAD: A terrorist group in Lebanon said today that it had hanged a hostage Marine colonel, and distributed a grisly videotape that showed a figure identified as the American twisting at the end of a rope.

Sister Thomas Cushing, Hospital Director, 85
LEAD: Sister Thomas Francis Cushing, executive director of St.
John's Hospital in Queens for 22 years before retiring in 1982, died yesterday at Maria Regina Convent in Brentwood, L.I., where she lived.
She was 85 years old.


Police Removing Roadblocks at Reservation
LEAD: Mohawk leaders and the state police agreed today to ease a 10-day-old standoff at the St.
Regis Indian Reservation and remove some roadblocks on the Mohawk territory, officials said.


LeMond to Compete
LEAD: Greg LeMond, the Tour de France champion, has decided to compete in a World Cup cycling event in Montreal, race organizers announced yesterday.


Results Plus
LEAD:  TENNIS  Novacek Beats Sanchez: Karel Nova-cek of Czechoslovakia defeated Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday to capture the Hilversum tournament in the Netherlands.
The eighth-seeded Novacek needed 1 hour 10 minutes to overcome Sanchez, seeded second.
The match had been scheduled for Sunday but was postponed because of rain.

New Face and Name For the Ritz Theater
LEAD: The Ritz Theater on Broadway is getting a new look and a new name.
It will be called the Walter Kerr Theater as a salute to the longtime drama critic.


Ozone-Thin Air Disperses, Scientists Say
LEAD: Air partly depleted of ozone appears to be transported from Antarctica to New Zealand and southern Australia by air currents in the atmosphere, scientists reported last week.


A Worthy Immigration Update
LEAD: In 1986, a Federal law addressed illegal immigration by legalizing the status of long-term undocumented aliens and imposing sanctions on employers who hire new ones.
Though bureaucratic problems remain that could jeopardize some of those aliens, Congress is now turning its attention to legal immigrants with a bill that confirms two worthy principles: the importance of reuniting families and


The Big Gains Rip-Off
LEAD: Cutting taxes on capital gains was a bad idea when it was just one of the few substantive proposals George Bush made in his shabby Presidential campaign; and it's still a bad idea now that some Democrats have foolishly taken it for themselves.


Cholesterol Reduction May Avert Cancers
LEAD: CHOLESTEROL reduction has long been tried as a preventive measure to ward off heart disease.
But now there are tantalizing hints that, in a certain category of cancer cases, cholesterol reduction might head off tumor formation as well.


Kenneth R. May, 65, Ex-Lutheran Bishop
LEAD: The Rev.
Kenneth R. May, retired bishop of the Western Pennsylvania-West Virginia Synod of the former Lutheran Church in America, died of complications from an aortic aneurysm Friday.
He was 65 years old and lived in McCandless, Pa.

Cross &amp; Trecker Restructuring
LEAD: The Cross &amp; Trecker Corporation, the second-largest independent machine tool manufacturer, announced a restructuring that will involve the sale of three units and an interest in a joint venture.


3 Arrested in Tent Removals
LEAD: Three people were arrested in Tompkins Square Park early this morning in a protest against city park rangers who tore down eight to 10 tents shortly before midnight.
A police spokesman, Sgt.
Raymond O'Donnell, said that there was no violence.
Sergeant O'Donnell said the three people arrested were Paul Augusta, 25 years old, of 114 East 53d St., and Francisco Acuary, 38, a homeless man, who were both charged with disorderly conduct and harassment, and Stacy Brown, 20, of 356 West 34th St., who was charged with disorderly conduct.


Correction
LEAD: A brief article in some copies on Sunday about an agreement under which the actor Rob Lowe could avoid prosecution on charges that he videotaped a girl performing a sex act in an Atlanta hotel room described the agreement incorrectly.
District Attorney Lewis R. Slaton said Mr.
Lowe agreed to perform 20 hours of community service over two years, not two years of community service.

LEAD:  Guilty Verdict on Wall St.
Five principals of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership, Princeton/Newport, and a former Drexel Burnham Lambert trader were found guilty in the first case that charged racketeering on Wall Street.

New Breed of Robots Have the Human Touch
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Aug. 1 about new robots called teleoperators referred incorrectly to the views of John Molino, president of the Tech-U-Fit Corporation in Alexandria, Va.
He said he believed the robots would assist, but not replace, shuttle crews working in space.

LEAD: As eagerly as if they were expecting toys, about a thousand children line up in shifts for the spartan lunch served daily in two dining rooms operated by the Church of San Pedro Nolasco.


Cutting Flood Insurance
LEAD: MANY people endorse the exclusion of undeveloped barrier islands from the National Flood Insurance Program which, in effect, subsidizes coastal development.
Critics of the program say that the low-cost insurance encourages shoreline development, and that taxpayers pick up the tab when the inevitable storm strikes.


Lin's Deadline Passes
LEAD: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that its deadline for a negotiated buyout agreement with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. had passed without an agreement and that its board would pursue other options.
McCaw, the nation's largest cellular telephone operator, had offered $110 a share for the 90.2 percent of Lin it does not already own.

LEAD: He was not commenting on the criminal charges, but Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday pronounced Leona M. Helmsley guilty of ''chintziness.''

LEAD: Frances Woodworth Wright, a Harvard University astronomer who taught celestial navigation to Navy officers, died of cancer Sunday.
She was 92 years old and lived in Cambridge.

With 2 Premiers Tarnished, Japanese Party Gets Down to Squabbling
LEAD: One week after Prime Minister Sousuke Uno announced that he would resign, Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party has dissolved into fierce factional and cross-generational battling for the choice of a new leader and perhaps even a new style of leadership.


Mysterious Particle
LEAD: The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., has analyzed the largest sample ever of the mysterious Z#0 (pronounced zee-zero) particle and succeeded in obtaining a measure of its mass that is six times more precise than any other.
The finding sheds light on a fundamental building block of nature and helps scientists better understand the forces that hold the universe together.


Westin Leaves ABC to Join King World
LEAD: Av Westin, a news producer for ABC and CBS for more than 35 years, was named senior vice president for reality programs for King World Productions yesterday.
King World is one of the largest distributers of syndicated shows for television, including ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.

LEAD: An Wang, the 69-year-old founder of Wang Laboratories Inc., at home recovering from cancer surgery two weeks ago, is already taking an active role in directing his company's business.
It looks like the Lowell, Mass., computer maker will need all of its founder's many talents.

LEAD: Three construction workers were injured yesterday afternoon when the building they were rehabilitating in Harlem partially collapsed, burying them under plaster and debris.

The Changing Landscape
LEAD: BARRIER islands are at once the most vulnerable and the most resilient parts of the coastline.
Formed and nourished by sand carried on currents that run along the shore, they are constantly in motion, rising, falling and migrating.
A storm can divide them in an afternoon, forming inlets in low-lying areas.


Savings Unit Has Big Loss
LEAD: Lincoln Savings and Loan, which was seized by Federal regulators in April, lost $847 million in the first six months of the year, sending its net worth plunging to a negative $906 million, California officials said.


Eastern Airlines
LEAD: Eastern Airlines, in a promotion aimed at funeral homes, is offering a 50 percent discount for corpses shipped aboard its passenger jets until Aug. 31, a spokesman said.
Funeral directors can also earn bonus frequent-flier miles based on the volume of business they bring to Eastern if they sign up for another program for cargo shippers, she said.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a 1989-90 budget for Yonkers that specifically marks $24 million to build two schools required by his desegregation plan for the city.

McDonnell Pact
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had been awarded a contract worth $691 million by the Air Force to produce four more C-17 aircraft.
The planes are to be delivered in 1991.
The new order brings to six the number of C-17's ordered by the Air Force of a planned total of 210 to modernize its current military airlift command fleet by the year 2000, McDonnell Douglas said.

LEAD: No one pretends to have good answers on how to combat terrorism.

Michael Harrington, Socialist and Author, Is Dead
LEAD: Michael Harrington, co-chairman of the Democratic Socialists of America and author of ''The Other America,'' which helped to encourage the Federal Government's War on Poverty, died of cancer of the esophagus Monday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y.
He was 61 years old.

LEAD: The Dana Corporation, a maker of parts for trucks and automobiles, said yesterday that Southwood J. Morcott, the company's president and chief operating officer, has been elected to the additional position of chief executive, effective immediately.

LEAD: Some 230 players sit in rapt concentration in the fraying ballroom of the Penta Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.
Silence reigns, except for something sounding vaguely like a den of rattlesnakes.
It is the subdued clatter of tiles being shaken.

Jules B. Singer, 89, Advertising Executive
LEAD: Jules B. Singer, a former president of the Federal Advertising Agency and a former vice president of the Grey Advertising Agency, died of respiratory failure Saturday night at his home in Manhattan.
He was 89 years old.


Iranian Denies Link To Death of Hostage, The Soviets Report
LEAD: The Iranian President-elect expressed regret today over the reported killing of an American Marine officer by kidnappers and said Iran had nothing to do with the death, Tass reported from Teheran.


Yonkers Budget Is Certified
LEAD: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan certified a budget for Yonkers today, ending concern that the state's fourth-largest city would end up in default.
The $372.3 million budget was adopted Monday by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan.
The city had reached a stalemate over $24 million for two new schools, which had been ordered by Judge Sand to remedy what he found to be 40 years of discrimination.


Voluntary Curb On TV Violence Urged by House
LEAD: Responding to a wave of public protests against sex and violence on television, the House of Representatives took a major step today to put pressure on the industry to reduce the amount of violence in programs.

Businessland Sets Training Division
LEAD: Businessland Inc., the nation's largest non-franchised personal computer chain, said it was forming a training division to provide a comprehensive standardized computer education program across the country.
Businessland, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would increase its management, support staff and classrooms and would develop a national reservation system to accommodate the projected demand for training.


New Jersey Ordered to Expand Homeless Aid
LEAD: The state can continue to stop shelter benefits after five months, but it must expand its programs by Dec. 1 to keep the people off the street, the State Supreme Court ruled today.
The court said it would let the Human Services Department prove that its programs will help the homeless find shelter after their emergency assistance ends.

LEAD: Batteries are the weak link in the consumer electronics revolution, with dead ones stalling the operation of everything from cordless telephones to laptop computers.
That has created demand for rechargeable batteries, but the most common rechargeables, which contain nickel and cadmium, are expensive and run out of power faster than disposables.

Time Warner Payout
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would begin paying cash for the 100 million shares it accepted from Warner shareholders under the Time offer that expired on July 24.

Time itself owns an additional 17 million shares of Warner.

Others cheesecake.
Still others find solace in fudge.

He is the second Soviet player to sign with an N.B.A. club.

LEAD: THE explosion in the popularity of peppers over the last few years has been astonishing, with many varieties and colors coming on the market.

Typesetting Gets a Digital Facelift
LEAD: Until recently, only publishers with access to expensive laser printers could participate in the digital typsetting revolution, one of the most fundamental changes in the five-century history of typography.
Now digital typography is about to become part of the basic software controlling personal computers and work stations, allowing millions of users to generate and display typefaces on their computer screens and on inexpensive printers.

Steel Downturn Seen
LEAD: A projected slowing in business activity will result in a decline of 3 percent in shipments from steel service centers this year, the Steel Service Center Institute said Monday.
The institute is a trade association of the steel service center industry.
The centers purchase and distribute one of every three tons of carbon industrial steel products and nearly half of all stainless steel produced in the United States.

He was 82 years old.

Del Labs Account
LEAD: Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke has ended its seven-year alliance with the Commerce Drug Company.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: VEAL chops, one of the most expensive cuts of meat, can be wonderfully tender and subtle when cooked properly, but the margin for error is narrow.
For my taste, veal chops must be cooked to medium.
A rare veal chop is unappetizingly pink and lacking in flavor, while one well done, of course, is dry.

A New Lease for Housing Tax Credits
LEAD: A low income housing tax credit program has turned out to be one of the more useful elements of the 1986 tax reform.
Unless Congress extends it, the credit will expire in December.
That would deprive the nation of valuable relief for its chronic shortage of low-income housing.

DRUG PLAN TO PUSH LAW ENFORCEMENT
LEAD: A new Federal strategy against drug abuse formulated by William J. Bennett calls for increasing the number of Federal prison cells by as much as 85 percent and using Federal money as a lever to force state and local governments to commit more resources to law enforcement Mr.
Bennett, director of national drug control policy, also proposes in a draft report being circulated among Cabinet members this week that new offices be created to eliminate infighting among some of the Federal agencies involved in the anti-drug effort.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American General Finance Inc., Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of American General Corp. of Houston, named Roy Haley president, chief executive and a director, replacing John Bolger, who will become vice chairman.


Aguilera Feels Relief; He Will Start as a Twin
LEAD: By the time the trade was finally made, Rick Aguilera was well prepared for it.
Yesterday morning, he caught an early flight from St.
Louis to New York, arrived at Yankee Stadium about the fifth inning and was throwing in the Minnesota Twins' bullpen as the game stretched into the late afternoon.


Top Helmsley Aide 'Knew Too Much'
LEAD: Shortly before Leona M. Helmsley dismissed her top aide, Frank J. Turco, in 1986, Helmsley executives who knew their companies had paid millions of dollars of the couple's private expenses discussed their fear that Mr.
Turco ''knew too much,'' a Helmsley executive testified yesterday.


Bridgestone Move
LEAD: The Bridgestone Corporation, which last year completed a $2.6 billion acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said it was consolidating its tire business, giving it a new name and a single corporate headquarters.
The merged company will be known as Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. and it will be based in Akron, where Firestone was founded in 1900.


American Gets U.N. Post
LEAD: Ronald I. Spiers, a veteran American diplomat, will be the new Undersecretary General for General Assembly Affairs, the top-ranking American at the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced today.
Mr.
Spiers, 64 years old, was Ambassador to Pakistan from 1981 to 1983 and has also served as Ambassador to the Bahamas and Turkey.


Bureau Having Trouble Filling Jobs for Census
LEAD: The Northeast's labor shortage, long the bane of fast-food restaurants, department stores and other sectors of the region's service economy, is hobbling a new employer: the 1990 census.


People
LEAD: * Gerald Wright has been appointed regional director of Lintas's Germanic region.


Greenstone Acquisition
LEAD: Greenstone Rabasca Roberts in Melville, L.I., announced the acquisition of Sommer Inc., a small business-to-business ad agency in Englewood, N.J.
Ronald Greenstone, Greenstone Rabasca's president, said the acquisition would bring the agency's billings to about $50 million in 1989.
Earlier this year, the agency bought Weston Ganoff Marini in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.


Citadel's Lonely Battle To Keep Women Out
LEAD: The Citadel is a military college with its roots deep in the Old South.
Its cadets fired the first shots of the Civil War, lobbing cannon balls at the Federal steamer Star of the West heading for Fort Sumter out in the harbor.

LEAD: ''I was real nervous before I went on,'' Ringo Starr said the other day about the Dallas concert that opened his 30-city tour on July 23. ''I kept thinking, What's it like?
What do you do?
All those madnesses go through your brain.
But once you're out there, you see that people haven't come to see you get nervous.

Col.
William Higgins by Hezbollah terrorists.

They are guilty of brutal murder.

The F.B.I. suspects him of passing secrets to the Soviet Union.

On July 21 ABC News disclosed that he was under investigation.
On July 27 he appeared at his daughter's house on Hamilton Road in Chappaqua, N.Y.

Rose Schulman, Acting Teacher, 79
LEAD: Rose Schulman, an acting teacher at the nation's oldest repertory company, the Hedgerow Theater of Rose Valley, Pa., died after a heart attack on Sunday at the Crozer Chester (Pa.) Medical Center.
She was 79 years old.


Big Engine Orders For G.E. Venture
LEAD: Two European airlines have ordered $900 million in jet engines from CFM International, a venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France.
Alitalia of Italy and Iberia, the Spanish airline, ordered Airbus Industrie A321 aircraft powered by the CFM56-5B jet engine made by CFM.


New Pricing Plan For I.B.M. System
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a new pricing structure for its System 370 software that could bring price cuts or increases, depending upon how a customer's system is organized.
The increases will be most prevalent at the higher end of the processor group structure and decreases at the lower end, the company said.

H.U.D. IS CRITICIZED ON MORTGAGE FUND
LEAD: The Comptroller General told a Senate subcommittee today that problems in the Federal Housing Administration's fund that insures $277 billion worth of mortgages mainly arose from the housing department's failure to oversee private lenders who took over much of the operation.


Ferry Will Play for Rome Team Instead of Signing With Clippers
LEAD: Danny Ferry, the star Duke forward who was the second player picked in the National Basketball Association's June draft, has reportedly passed up a chance to play for the Los Angeles Clippers next season in favor of a $1 million contract to play for the Messaggero Rome team in the Italian professional league.


Aquino Signs Autonomy Law For Restive Muslim Regions
LEAD: Trying to end years of separatist unrest, President Corazon C. Aquino signed into law today a measure that could lead to some autonomy for 13 southern provinces.
Most of the Muslim minority lives in those provinces.


Review/Music; Philharmonic in the Park
LEAD: Weather reports had threatened rain, but nonetheless an audience estimated at 30,000 came to Central Park on Monday night to hear the New York Philharmonic.
As it turned out, the listeners beat the odds -dark clouds loomed but not a drop of rain fell - and they had the benefit of a cool, breezy evening as well as music by Berlioz, Prokofiev and Dvorak.

James B. Ramsey Jr., Consultant, 66
LEAD: James B. Ramsey Jr., a financial consultant to the Small Business Administration in New York, died of a respiratory illness Saturday at the Carteret General Hospital in Morehead City, N.C., near his vacation home.
He was 66 years and also lived in Wyckoff, N.J.


Economic Watch; Sleep? Why? There's No Money in It
LEAD: Most people think they sleep because they are tired.
Now come two economists from Michigan State University who say people sleep because they have nothing better - or remunerative - to do.
The findings, in a study for the National Bureau of Economic Research by Jeff Biddle and Daniel Hamermesh, offer a striking example of economists' relentless search for economic motivations in everything from having babies to mugging tourists to going to church - and how, in the process, they sometimes generate real insight.

Review/Theater; A Garcia Marquez Tale Opens Festival Latino
LEAD: In the fiction of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the weight of history hangs like a stone in the sweltering atmosphere, and the spirits of the dead haunt the living in feverish dreams.
Time stands still in the sense that the dead continue to stir as long as the tiniest memory of them persists.
For the living, dreams of the distant past are often more vivid than the grinding physical realities of the present.

Review/Opera; New 'Traviata' in Santa Fe
LEAD: The Santa Fe Opera enjoys an unfair advantage over most other music festivals.
The open-air performances, set against the backdrop of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, often radiate a youthful freshness that can induce a benign out-of-body state of mind in the visitor from the flatlands.
It was sometimes difficult to keep in mind on Monday evening, for instance, that the company's handsome new staging of ''La Traviata,'' one of this season's five new productions, failed in important ways to measure up to internationally accepted vocal standards, such as they are.

Reviews/Music; Magmouat Hakmoun, From Morocco
LEAD: Hassan Hakmoun, who brought his Gnawan Moroccan band, Magmouat Hakmoun, to the Village Gate on Tuesday night, is one of those musicians who can prod and inspire his musicians into a frenzy.
A virtuoso of rhythm, he slammed out riffs on his sintir (a cello-like lute), changing the accent on the notes, making new riffs from the last note of an old one, leaving notes out to vary the rhythms, picking up and slowing down tempos.

Hyman Hirsch, Institute Founder, 84, Dies
LEAD: Hyman Hirsch, a New York City teacher who founded the Institute for Retired Professionals at the New School, died Monday at St.
Luke's Hospital.

Nissan Sedan Priced at $38,000
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company says it is pricing its Infiniti Q45 luxury sedan at $38,000, putting it in the same price range as Toyota's Lexus and just below the most expensive European-made luxury sedans.
The Q45 is a four-door sedan, equipped with a 4.5-liter, 32-valve, 278-horsepower V8 engine.
Its two-door coupe, with a 3-liter, 162-horsepower V6, will be priced at $23,500.

SENATORS, AT ODDS WITH HOUSE, PASS PENTAGON BUDGET
LEAD: The Senate approved a 1990 military bill tonight that leaves it in a fundamental dispute with the House of Representatives over how to divide an increasingly lean Pentagon budget among nuclear arms, conventional weapons and 21st century technology.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: WHEN made of carefully selected seasoned wood and installed properly, clapboard siding can be maintained in excellent condition for as long as a house stands.
Still, cracks, warping and decay can occur.
When they do, prompt action is needed.
If the edges of a crack meet precisely, it usually can be repaired with waterproof wood glue, available at home centers.


Expert Says Drug Use Has Been Effectively Deterred by Testing
LEAD: A member of the International Olympic Committee medical commission testifed today that drug-testing procedures used at the Olympics and other major events for 20 years have effectively deterred drug use by athletes even though he had written in 1974 that out-of-competition testing was the only true way to eliminate drug use.

LEAD: The families of two young people who disappeared last year in New Mexico have said a photograph found in a Florida parking lot appears to show their children together bound and gagged.

Morgan Guaranty
LEAD: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York is offering $150 million in notes through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.
The 7 7/8 percent notes are due in 1991 and are priced at 99.95, to yield 7.902 percent, or about 42 basis points higher than the Treasury two-year note.
The issue, which is noncallable, is rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.&amp;P.

Reviews/Music; Some Fancy Flute Work
LEAD: On too many of his albums, the flutist Hubert Laws smothers his solos in goopy pop-jazz arrangements.
But in a rare New York engagement through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Mr.
Laws is allowing himself to play some of the daredevil, harmonically intricate material that established him as the leading jazz flutist of his generation.


Teen-Agers Held in Robberies That Killed One and Hurt Five
LEAD: Two teen-agers were charged early Tuesday in several bodega robberies in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx over 48 hours that left one man dead and five others wounded, the police said yesterday.


Helmsley Aides and Auditor Agreed on Reporting Income
LEAD: Senior Helmsley executives met with their chief outside auditor in 1986 and agreed that Harry and Leona Helmsley should report an additional $2 million of income on their tax returns because their businesses were paying their personal expenses, one of the executives testified yesterday.

No August Doldrums
LEAD: In the past, I have provided readers with a list of suggested knee-jerk reactions to carry through the August news doldrums.
Not this year; as I slouch toward vacation, the march of events is quickening. 1.
Confrontation With the Terrorist Murderers.
Israel's painful but gutsy decision to capture the Hezbollah's field commander and his aides, after the failure of all other means of handling hostage-taking over a decade, is being criticized as provocative.


Never Say 'Never Talk'
LEAD: In the Bush Administration's first anguishing hostage crisis, the White House spokesman yesterday invoked a familiar adage: Never negotiate with terrorists.
But it's an adage, not a policy, an example of rhetorical boilerplate that remains impervious to reality.

LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency has told the White House that Lieut.
Col.
William R. Higgins was probably killed before Monday, the day a pro-Iranian terrorist group said it hanged the Marine officer, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Venezuela's debt negotiating team is scheduled to consult on Friday with the Mexican Finance Minister, Pedro Aspe, before beginning informal talks with commercial bankers.

Scrimshaw, With No Threat to Whales
LEAD: SCRIMSHAW, the ancient art of carving ivory, has been given a new life.
Inspired to protect species like whales that have been traditional sources of ivory, David Lazarus, a Nantucket, Mass., artist, found he could get ivory-like results working on plastics like Corian or Formica.


Review/Pop; Nigeria's Fela Makes Political Opinion Sing
LEAD: Rough-hewn music, swivel-hipped dancing and implacable oratory swirled together in the concert by Fela Anikulapo Kuti and Egypt '80 on Friday night at the Apollo Theater.
Fela, as he calls himself, has been Nigeria's most outspoken dissident musician since he began leading a band, then called Afrika '70, nearly two decades ago.

SWIMMING  Wharton Lowers Record: David Wharton broke his American record in the 400-meter individual medley last night when he swam the event in 4 minutes 15.93 seconds at the United States long-course championships in Los Angeles. Wharton erased his mark of 4:16.12, set in 1987. Eric Namesnik was second and Ray Looze was third.   Janet Evans easily won the women's 400 freestyle in 4:06.73, the fastest time in the world this year. Andrea Hayes was second and Julie Kole was third. In the backstroke, Betsy Mitchell won the 100-meter race and Dan Veatch won at 200 meters. Other winners were Nicole Haislett in the 100 freestyle and Brent Lang in the men's 100 freestyle.(AP)  TENNIS  Agassi Gets By: Andre Agassi, the defending champion and seeded No. 1, survived a scare from Marty Davis and won, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the Volvo International tournament at Stratton Mountain, Vt.(AP)  Andersson Upsets Mecir: Johan Andersson, a Swedish-born Australian qualifier, upset top-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1, yesterday in the rain-plagued Swedish Open at Bastad, Sweden.(AP)  Buchmayr Surprises: Unseeded 18-year-old Thomas Buchmayr of Austria upset top-seeded Alberto Mancini of Argentina in the second round yesterday at the Austrian Open at Kitzbuehel. Earlier in the day at the rain-delayed event, Mancini beat Richard Vogel of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3. Buchmayr beat Mancini, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2.(AP)  BASEBALL  Taiwan Beats U.S.: Taiwan beat the United States, 3-2, yesterday in Tokyo and will play for the championship of the world youth tournament. The team of 13- to 15-year-olds from Taiwan next faces Japan, a 4-1 winner over Brazil yesterday.(AP)  GOLF  Two Veterans Advance: Anne Sander and Carol Semple Thompson, former winners from the two previous decades, joined some of the youngsters in advancing to the round of 16 yesterday in the United Staes women's amateur championship in Pinehurst, N.C. The 51-year-old Sander, who won the title in 1961 and 1963, scored upsets over Tanna Lee, 3 and 2, and Nanci Bowen, 4 and 3, to advance at Pinehurst Country Club's No. 2 course.   The 40-year-old Thompson, the 1973 champion, defeated both Jennifer Buchanan and Phyllis Preuss, 3 and 2. Match play continues today.(AP)

Pilots Angered by Airing of Tape of Banter Before Fatal Crash
LEAD: Responding to the public airing of casual conversations among crew members in a passenger jet just before a fatal crash in Texas last year, the airline pilots' union today called for legislation restricting the release of such recordings.
But it backed away from a threat to protest the public airing by turning off cockpit voice recorders.

Expressions of Whimsy In the Humble Umbrella
LEAD: Two months ago, when Janet Kardon became the director of the American Craft Museum at 40 West 53d Street in Manhattan, she began looking for exhibitions.
Visiting the Fabric Workshop, a Philadelphia-based design organization, she saw ''Rain of Talent: Umbrella Art'' and promptly brought the show to the museum.

PARENTS &amp; CHILD
LEAD: THE moment your child has a child is the beginning of a new set of relationships and a new way of viewing yourself.
Taking on the title ''grandparent'' is an event that is embraced by most adults and dreaded by a few.
It is an opportunity that many parents all but take for granted, but one that their own grandparents did not count on.


Lomas to End Its Dividends
LEAD: The Lomas Financial Corporation, a struggling diversified financial services company, said that it would suspend dividends on its common and common equivalent preferred stock until the company's financial reorganization is completed, the commercial leasing division is sold and the company has been profitable for a while.

Varian Planning A Realignment
LEAD: Varian Associates Inc. said it would undertake a substantial realignment of its operations and management structure to reflect changes in strategy.

LEAD: The criminal investigators of the Government's Offices of Inspectors General sometimes think of themselves as the junkyard dogs of Federal law enforcement - low-status sleuths prowling the recesses of their agencies sniffing out corruption, fraud and abuse.

'88 Farm Costs Up 7.5%
LEAD: The cost of running the nation's farms rose 7.5 percent, to $118.4 billion, in 1988, the Agriculture Department reported today.
Despite the increase, the figure falls short of the record $131.8 billion that farmers spent in 1981, before the general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the agricultural sector.

Jacobs Offers to Buy Avon for $2.2 Billion
LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he had sent a letter to Avon Products Inc. offering to buy the cosmetics company for $41 a share in cash, or about $2.2 billion.

Genevieve R. Hanfield, Broker, 57
LEAD: Genevieve R. Hanfield, a real-estate broker who specialized in sales of houses and cooperative apartments in Greenwich Village, died of bone cancer Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital.
She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Soviet Team Expels 2
LEAD: Dmitri Bilozerchev, a triple gold medalist in the Olympics, and a teammate, Vladimir Gogoladze, were removed from the Soviet Union's team for the world gymnastics championships because of a two-day drinking binge, a report in Sovetsky Sport announced.
Bilozerchev broke a leg badly in a car accident while driving while intoxicated in 1985, but made a spectacular comeback in the Olympics at Seoul, South Korea, getting six perfect marks and winning gold medals in the pommel horse and rings.(

Senate Panel Describes Data on Nuclear Risks
LEAD: A Senate committee today described 26 Government studies indicating that workers and neighbors of the Government's nuclear sites have developed excessive cancers and other diseases.
The information raised new concern about the Energy Department's handling of data concerning the risks of radiation at its weapons plants.


Ex-Lawmaker Wins Primary
LEAD: A conservative former state legislator won the Republican primary here Tuesday for the Congressional seat vacated by the death of Claude Pepper, but the Democratic vote was sharply split, forcing a runoff to be held Aug. 15.

LEAD: Thousands of patrons in a record opening-day crowd of 30,658 at Saratoga Race Track left early and angrily today after a ''gremlin'' in the track computers crippled on-track betting on the last five races.

Market Place; A Savvy Outsider Ventures Inside
LEAD: PETER S. LYNCH, one of the nation's best-known money managers, is still getting used to seeing the world from inside the board rooms of top corporations.
About three months ago, he joined the board of W. R. Grace &amp; Company, a specialty chemical maker with far-flung interests ranging from energy and health care to book and video distribution.


Karl Malden Is Elected
LEAD: The actor Karl Malden was elected today to be the 27th president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the entertainment-industry organization responsible for the Oscar ceremonies.
Mr.
Malden, who won an Academy Award in 1951 for his role in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' replaces Richard Kahn, a public-relations executive, whose one-year term expired.


Irwin Joffe, 47, Official Of Clothing Companies
LEAD: Irwin Joffe, former president of Dawson International USA Inc., an American subsidiary of a British knitwear manufacturer, died of a heart attack on July 17 in London.
He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

6th Suspect in Park Attack
LEAD: A sixth suspect was arrested last night in connection with an assault July 23 on two men who had been sitting in Carl Schurz Park, near Gracie Mansion, the police said.
The police have labelled the assault bias-related because the dozen attackers shouted anti-homosexual slurs at the victims.
The suspect arrested last night was Anthony Flores, 16, of 250 East 105th Street.


Mayoral Race Debate Rates Above Baseball
LEAD: Politics was more popular in New York City than baseball Tuesday evening.
To the surprise of many politicians, the Democratic mayoral debate on WCBS-TV (Channel 2) outdrew a baseball game between the San Francisco Giants and the Los Angeles Dodgers on WNBC-TV (Channel 4).


Bond Prices Mixed at Close
LEAD: In moderately active trading yesterday, the prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed as market participants reacted somewhat negatively to a report that showed the big drop in interest rates might be stimulating the housing industry.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omni Magazine Trying To Achieve New Image
LEAD: For a scientific publication, Omni magazine's newest advertisements are rather earthy, not to mention earthbound.
Instead of ethereal images of planets and stars - or even semiconductor chips - the television ads feature an actor imitating the sounds of a spaceship, robot and other futuristic items.

Factories' New Orders Increased by 0.4% in June
LEAD: Orders for manufactured goods edged up a slight four-tenths of 1 percent in June, reflecting a rebound in demand for military hardware.

A.T.&amp;T. Venture
LEAD: The American Express Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company formed a company to process telephone calls for market research, direct selling and other interactive uses.
The joint venture, Call Interactive, will be able to process up to 10,000 toll-free and toll telephone calls in 90 seconds when it begins operations next month, the companies said.

Merrill Lynch
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company yesterday priced $200 million of notes due 1994 through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The notes were given an 8 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at par to yield about 87 basis points more than the five-year Treasury note.
Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard &amp; Poor's.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee medical commission is developing a drug test that could be used to disqualify athletes from the Olympics even if they do not test positive for drug use immediately after their competition.

Market Place; Who Could Gain In Clean Air Act
LEAD: WITH President Bush's clean-air initiative pushing the country firmly in the direction of stricter pollution control, some analysts are looking at companies that stand to gain from tighter regulation.
The Administration estimates that the cost of compliance with its proposals would be $14 billion to $19 billion a year.

LEAD: No ninth-inning rescue this time for the Mets.
No splashy debut by Frank Viola, pitching four-hit ball and breaking the gloom.
No little winning streak to carry home to New York for the weekend intrusion of the first-place Montreal Expos.
And no edge over the St.
Louis Cardinals, who hung on to shade the Mets today, 6-5, and hold them to a split of the four-game series.

Keye/Donna Decision
LEAD: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein Los Angeles has dropped out of the American Suzuki Motor Corporation's review of its account, reportedly worth $30 million in annual billings, that was announced in May.
The account may be worth half the agency's billings.
Suzuki has seen sales plummet since Consumer Reports magazine said last year that its Samurai four-wheel-drive vehicle has a propensity to tip over during sharp turns.

'Liaisons' at the Quad
LEAD: Roger Vadim's 1960 film ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' will begin an open-ended run today at the Quad 2 Cinema, 34 West 13th Street.
The film is an updated version - by Mr.
Vadim, Roger Vailland and Claude Brule - of the 18th-century novel of sexual adventure and deceit by Choderlos de Laclos.
Gerard Philipe and Jeanne Moreau co-star; the film is in French with English subtitles.


Dollar Extends Its Gains; Gold Up in Europe and U.S.
LEAD: The dollar extended its advance yesterday against most major currencies, bolstered by continued concern about the hostage situation in the Middle East.


American Eagle
LEAD: American Airlines said its commuter carrier, American Eagle, would open a hub at Miami International Airport, the home base of the strike-crippled Eastern Airlines.
American Eagle's president, Robert E. Martens, said the carrier planned to open on Oct. 1 with 20 flights a day from Miami to Key West and West Palm Beach, also in Florida.

Economic Scene; The Wage Jump That Never Came
LEAD: Through the winter and spring, many economists expected wages to rise sharply.
This wage spiral would be the inevitable result of the nation's low unemployment rate: companies would be forced to bid for scarce workers, and wages would finally behave as they once did - rising briskly for millions of people.


11 Deaths Reported in Kiev Balcony Collapse


Illinois Takeover Law
LEAD: Gov.
James R. Thompson of Illinois signed legislation Wednesday intended to prevent hostile takeovers of corporations.
The law authorizes the issuance of ''poison pill'' shareholder rights or options plans by Illinois corporations without shareholder approval.
Such plans can make hostile takeovers prohibitively expensive.


Apple Computer Gets Postal Pact
LEAD: In its first significant Federal contract, Apple Computer Inc. will supply the United States Postal Service with Macintosh IIx personal computers for its nationwide system.
Depending upon demand, the five-year agreement may total as much as $30.2 million for systems and other services.
The Apple bid includes more than 25 subcontractors supplying peripheral products for the

Money-Fund Assets at Peak
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds rose by $4.24 billion in the latest week, to a record $337.03 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.


Cuomo Weighs Plan to Pay Lawyers Suing State
LEAD: In a move expected to be closely watched in other states, Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo is to decide soon whether to approve a bill that would force the state to pay the legal costs of some people who sue it.


OPEC Output Still High
LEAD: OPEC nations continued to pump oil at a robust rate in July despite promises to curtail their crude output, the International Energy Agency said today in its Monthly Oil Market Report.
The agency estimated that the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced about 21.3 million barrels a day last month.

LEAD: The Knicks announced yesterday that they had signed the free-agent guard Trent Tucker to a multiyear contract.

Auctions
LEAD:  Shaker Samplings A slender, seven-foot-tall Shaker chest of drawers is to be auctioned at noon on Sunday at Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Mass.
The 1830's pine chest of nine graduated drawers, in the original red stain finish, is one of several unusual offerings in the annual sale of Shaker furnishings organized by Willis Henry Auctions Inc.


U.S. Given Deadline to Protect Sea Turtles
LEAD: A Federal district judge said today that Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher had no right to suspend enforcement of regulations on shrimpers to protect sea turtles from drowning and gave the agency until Monday to draft temporary measures.

Julius J. Adams, 88, Ex-Newspaper Editor
LEAD: Julius J. Adams, managing editor of The Amsterdam News from 1938 to 1950 and a former member of New York's Republican State Committee, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, said at a Palestinian congress in Tunis today that the P.L.O. would continue its recent diplomatic efforts to reach a Middle East settlement.

News Summary
LEAD:  International A2-7  If another hostage had been killed, President Bush was prepared to order an air strike against suspected terrorist strongholds in Lebanon, Administration officials said.
Page A1  A decision to kill a U.S. hostage has been suspended, pro-Iranian militants said, to allow more time for the release of a Shiite Muslim cleric abducted by Israeli commandos in Southern Lebanon last week.


Rights Group Deplores Level of Abuse in Ethiopia
LEAD: On the eve of the first high-level official contact in a decade between Washington and the Government here, Amnesty International issued a report today on what it called ''the high level of serious human rights abuses'' in Ethiopia.


Bridge
LEAD: Two top-seeded teams were upset here Wednesday in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.


Group Suspends Decision to Kill A U.S. Captive
LEAD: Pro-Iranian militants said tonight that they had suspended a decision to kill an American hostage to allow more time for the release of a Shiite Muslim cleric abducted by Israeli commandos in southern Lebanon last week.
But the group issued new demands and said they must be met within days.


California Attorney General Calls For a Statewide Vote on Pollution
LEAD: The State Attorney General today proposed a sweeping ballot measure to reduce pollution of the air Californians breathe, the water they drink and the food they grow and eat.

Magazine Investor Buying 50% Stake in Ms. and Sassy
LEAD: Dale W. Lang, the magazine investor and publisher, said yesterday that he had agreed to acquire a half-interest in Ms. and Sassy magazines and will publish them along with three other magazines under a new media company, Lang Communications Inc.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD:  French Film Festival


Harvard and Japanese In Skin Research Deal
LEAD: In an unusual commercial and academic joint venture, Harvard and Massachusetts General Hospital today accepted $85 million from Japan's leading cosmetics company for a new skin research center.
The company would have exclusive rights to sell health and beauty products growing out of the research.


Washington Talk; Q.&amp;A.: Mollie Orshansky; The Hand That Shaped America's Poverty Line As the Realistic Index
LEAD: The poverty line has become one of those fundamentals of government on which Federal, state and local officials rely in calculating aid to the poor.
Politicians use it to argue about how humane or inhumane their opposition is.
The index was developed in the early 1960's by Mollie Orshansky, who was then an economist for the Social Security Administration.


The Candidates and the Kids
LEAD: A central measure of a society is how well it treats its children.
By that standard, New York City is in trouble.
Nearly 40 percent of the city's 1.7 million children live in families that are poor.
The infant mortality rate is rising.
There are 7,325 children in homeless families.
And the number in foster care is 35,000 and climbing.

Sandinistas Suspend Army Draft Until After Election
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that his Government would suspend the conscription of new military recruits until national elections are held in February.


Echoes of struggle for rule of law in China reverberate on Columbia campus.
LEAD: On a balmy summer day, the Columbia University campus seems as remote from Tiananmen Square psychically as it is geographically.
But in the office of Professor R. Randle Edwards of Columbia Law School, the recent tremors in China have registered clearly and profoundly.


Hurricane Veers Off From Caribbean Isles
LEAD: Hurricane Dean veered out into the Atlantic today with winds up to 85 miles an hour, and the National Weather Service lifted hurricane warnings for all the islands of the eastern Caribbean including Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Ease
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in the credit markets yesterday, as traders sold securities in advance of this morning's release of July employment data and the impending sale of more than $29 billion worth of new Treasury issues.


Review/Opera; Massenet's Infrequently Performed 'Cherubin'
LEAD: It would be senseless to try to define or analyze charm, but as a Supreme Court Justice said in a different context, you know it when you see it.
And you see it in all its magnetic mystery whenever Frederica von Stade steps onto a stage.
If there could be such a thing as a collective smile, it broke out in the Santa Fe Opera's audience the moment the irrepressible mezzo-soprano came bounding out in the title role of ''Cherubin.

LEAD: For more than a decade, Anne and Patrick Poirier have been remaking, with mixed results, the archeology of ancient civilizations.
Like Piranesi, they have seen a peculiar beauty in the ruins of Greece and Rome and have spent years traveling from one excavation site to the next.
For the French couple, antiquity is a wellspring of memory.

LEAD: Genevieve Fisch Fernandez, a public relations consultant, and Richard Gilbert Hewitt, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Lowell Hotel in New York by Judge J. Daniel Mahoney of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The bride was a widow and the bridegroom was a widower.
The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a senior consultant at Ruder-Finn, a public relations firm in New York.

Mennen and McCann
LEAD: McCann-Erickson New York increased its billings from the Mennen Company yesterday by between $7 million and $10 million a year.
The company gave the agency its Home Expression Group's account, consisting of three units that make paper party goods and household fragrance products.
McCann, a unit of the Interpublic Group, already handles Mennen's Speed Stick and Lady Speed Stick deodorants, which spent $26 million on advertising in 1988.

Reviews/Art; In New Jersey: A Prussian and Some Passions
LEAD: There is not just one exhibition worth visiting at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton; there are two. ''Oscar Bluemner: Landscapes of Sorrow and Joy'' is a retrospective of an early, largely unknown American modernist. ''A Density of Passions'' brings together 15 intense, obsessive artists who are either part of or related to the tradition of ''outsider art'' that has aroused particular interest in the United States this decade.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; If Frozen Food Thaws
LEAD: Power failures during summer thunderstorms are always a hazard.
Here is some advice from the United States Department of Agriculture on what to do with frozen foods when the electricity goes out.
First, open the freezer as little as possible.
A full, freestanding freezer will hold its temperature for about two days; a half-full freezer about one day.

LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company is ''overrun with orders'' for its new Lexus luxury model, and the car will probably be sold out for 1989 before it is formally introduced Sept 1., Lexus's general manager, J. David Illingworth, said.
He said Toyota had begun shipping the car to 70 dealers who have set up separate showrooms for it.

LEAD: Last week the United Auto Workers union suffered a humiliating defeat in its bid to represent employees at a Nissan plant in Smyrna, Tenn.

LEAD: Even before the first electric guitar chords had been struck, the vibes from a Pink Floyd concert in Venice last month were bad.

LEAD: The Oracle Systems Corporation, Ashland Oil Inc. and Nicor Inc. were included Thursday in the Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index before the market opened.
Oracle, which is involved in data base management, is traded over-the counter.
Ashland Oil, a petroleum, chemical and building concern, and Incor, a natural gas distributor, are listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

15 Months Under Fire at City Hall Agency
LEAD:  May 19, 1988: It is reported that former city employees have told investigators for the Commission on Government Integrity that records of job applicants at the Mayor's Talent Bank were altered or destroyed to delete references to patronage affiliations.
The coordinator, Joseph DeVincenzo, in an interview, dismisses the allegations, but adds that it is the city's policy to discard stale or obsolete resumes every six months or so.


WASHING CHLORINE AWAY
LEAD: Swimming in a chlorinated pool can leave hair dry and brittle.
Hair absorbs chlorine, which bleaches it and breaks down protein bonds.
Those who color their hair or have permanents are particularly vulnerable to damage because chemically treated hair is more porous.

He was 79 years old.

25 Killed in Cuba Train Wreck
LEAD: Two speeding passenger trains collided head-on about 100 miles east of Havana early today, killing at least 25 people and injuring 100, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported.
It said many passengers were trapped inside the wreckage.
The Havana radio said that the accident occurred in the city of Colon and that an army helicopter was helping to transport the injured.

LEAD: The New Jersey Stars of the Domino's Pizza TeamTennis league announced yesterday that Tracy Austin, who was in an automobile accident Thursday in Short Hills, N.J., suffered a broken bone in her right leg in the crash and was being cared for at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J.
The Stars' coach, Asim Sengun, named Leigh Thompson, a 25-year-old former touring pro who is now the women's tennis coach at Maryland, to replace Austin.

Victory for Reason on Howard Beach
LEAD: This week the New York Supreme Court's appellate division rightly affirmed the convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach murder case.
In the process it condemned the racially motivated attack that resulted in the death of a black man, and clarified the principle that racial discrimination, whether by the defense or the prosecution, has no place in jury selection.


Morgan and Smurfit Study New Venture
LEAD: The Morgan Stanley Group and the Jefferson Smurfit Group of Ireland said yesterday that they are considering forming a new venture that would acquire and merge their interests in two major paper and packaging concerns, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation and the Container Corporation of America.
Sources familiar with the proposed transactions valued the deal at over $2 billion.

Review/Opera; Old China's Simple Intricacies
LEAD: The idea behind ''A Night at the Chinese Opera'' is both simple and as intricate as a set of Chinese boxes.
Judith Weir, a Scottish composer, has inserted into her three-act work an actual 13th-century Chinese play that appears to parallel the life of the opera's protagonist, a civil engineer named Chao Lin, who misinterprets it and tries to use it to predict his own destiny.

LEAD: Plans by New York City to moor a prison barge on the Greenwich Village waterfront for up to five years, which had provoked local outrage, were quashed yesterday when the Army Corps of Engineers denied a permanent mooring application and issued a one-year permit instead.

LEAD: Arthur Rutzen, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who later became a Commerce Department official, died of an aneurism Thursday at the Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida.
He was 79 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

In Enclave, Mayor's Race Hinges on Crime
LEAD: Every afternoon at 3 o'clock, a private patrol car begins rolling through one of the prettiest neighborhoods in Brooklyn.
It cruises under canopies of ailanthus and maple trees, past unbroken rows of 19th-century brownstones, chocolate-rich and crisply preserved, with their jaunty window bays and welcoming stoops.


14 Companies Are Fined
LEAD: The European Commission said today that it had fined 14 European Community producers of welded steel mesh more than $10 million for operating an illegal cartel.
The commission, the European Community's executive body, said in a statement that the companies had operated a cartel between 1981 and November 1985 that involved agreements to set market shares, fix prices and restrict exports.

LEAD: The Senate approved comprehensive legislation on oil spills today, making the enactment of such a law likely after years of unsuccessful attempts in both houses of Congress.

LEAD: Too much of summer remains to sense the kind of urgency Ron Darling faced on that crisp October night in St.
Louis nearly four years ago.
The season had less than a week to go.
The opponent was John Tudor.
Darling's contribution was nine memorable scoreless innings that made an important victory possible.

CD's Available for a Song
LEAD: FOR VETERANS OF THE compact-disk revolution - those who were buying anything, anything at all, that was issued when CD's first came on the market and were extremely scarce - the present state of affairs seems like a second CD revolution.
In those early days, music lovers and audio buffs) who had to be the first on the block with new technology were happily (well, almosst happily) paying up to $22 for a single disk.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: After reading the articles on Spain (Travel, May 28), I would like to add several comments.
Yes, Seville has a lot of hotels, but there is a tremendous difference between Alfonso XIII and the next level (first class).
The Dona Maria Hotel, while desirably situated, has dingy, dark, rather seedy rooms.

LEAD: THIS is a parents' alert.
In a few weeks, your children will be back in school.
Which means homework.
And questions - lots of questions.
Many will be the kind of questions to which you know you once knew the answers, but for which your only response now will be a panicky expression (which you hope your child doesn't see) and either a mumbled response or a ''Sweetheart, why don't we ask (fill in the blank with name of spouse or grandparents - they told you, didn't they?).

LEAD: IT should be the centerpiece of a 19th-century New England mill town, a long, low, brick mill building surrounded by tenements.

It is on the west side of Amsterdam Avenue between 150th and 151st Streets.

During the last few years I had access to videos.

LEAD: The breakaway effort by a black priest in Washington reflects a desire for assertion and recognition that has been prevalent among many black Roman Catholics in the last 20 years, black church members said.

Aeolians' Black Beaches, Fiery Peaks
LEAD: TO the ancients, they were the islands of wind and fire.
The Greek god Aeolus kept his winds imprisoned in a cave in the archipelago that takes his name, and flames leaping from the chain's volcanoes both terrified and guided Mycenaean, Greek and Roman mariners sailing the southeastern Tyrrhenian at night.

Prospects; Housing vs. the Economy
LEAD: The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose by 5.5 percent in June, the third consecutive monthly increase.
The increase came after a sluggish first part of the year when sales fell to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession.
Seasonally adjusted, annual sales of new homes rose to 670,000 units, roughly the same as 1988.

LEAD: AS students prepare to sharpen their pencils, cover their books and hone their minds for the start of the new school year, they should resolve to work with parents, teachers, administrators and policymakers throughout the state to demand the abolition of the Regents exams.
It is time.
It is long overdue.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from a visit to Seville, Cordoba and Granada, I was surprised that you did not mention one of the best ways to visit the cities of Moorish Spain.
We took the Andalusian Express, a restored 1920's train, which takes passengers on two-day, overnight trips beginning in Seville and ending in Malaga.

LEAD: When you hear the words ''Leica camera,'' what adjectives spring to mind?
My list runs as follows: indestructible, mechanical, professional, expensive.
Photojournalists who have to take pictures on the run might add ''indispensable.'' Of course, we would all be thinking of M series Leicas, rangefinder cameras with interchangeable lenses and the durability of wrought iron.


British Law Urged for Nazi War-Crime Trials
LEAD: A report on a war-crimes inquiry has recommended changes in British law to allow prosecutions for Nazi war crimes said to have been committed by immigrants who have since become British citizens.
The report said there was already enough evidence to convict three such people living in Britain.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: THE fastest-growing intercollegiate sports for women are soccer and cross-country.
Soccer, offered for women in 3 percent of schools in 1977, has grown to 38 percent in 1988.
Cross-country was available in less than a third of the schools and is presently represented in more than 80 percent.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Empire Games

FOOD: Western Flair; Come 'n' Get It
LEAD: There really is a home on the range, and it looks just like you've always imagined.
The cowboys sleep under the stars, they herd the cattle for branding and eat their meals around an open fire.
The range cook, almost always a cowboy, gets up long before dawn to start the day's meals.
It isn't an easy task: on the range, after all, there is no running water and no electricity - only a wood fire and 20 hungry cowboys.


Paolo Baffi Dies at 77; Headed Italian Bank
LEAD: Paolo Baffi, the former governor of Italy's central bank, died on Friday night after a long illness, the bank announced today.
He was 77 years old.
The bank did not disclose the illness.
Mr.
Baffi, one of the major economic figures in postwar Italy, worked for 40 years with the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank.

LEAD: The Western imprint on fashion is now much like a cattle brand - not too striking, but obvious enough to catch the eye.

When in doubt about the mix, stride up to the mirror.

Finally, Mozambique Sees a Way to Halt Its Own Devastation
LEAD: THE statistics recited by Mozambique's President Joaquim Chissano have testified to the grim effects of more than a decade of vicious guerrilla war - 600,000 to 700,000 Mozambicans dead in a land of 15 million, an additional 1.6 million displaced as refugees, 2,599 primary schools and 822 rural health clinics destroyed or forced to close, 44 factories and more than 1,000 stores ruined.


At Last, a Plan That Reduces the Pain
LEAD: The Mexican debt agreement is good for both Mexico and the banks.
Mexican negotiators asked for 55 percent reduction in either principal or interest, or an 80 percent refinancing of 6 years of interest payments.
The banks met Mexico more than two-thirds of the way with a 35 percent reduction of debt or interest payments or a 60 percent refinancing of interest payments over four years.

LEAD: Protesting recent food price rises and dismal working conditions, thousands of Polish rail workers in the heavily industrialized southern region of Silesia staged a one-hour walkout today, warning that failure to quickly redress grievances would lead to further labor action, the state television reported.

Duffel Coats Are Losing Their Old Utilitarian Image
LEAD: The duffel coat is moving up the fashion ladder.
This upwardly mobile style started as a rugged coat for country wear and bad weather, made in sturdy fabrics like loden cloth.
Leather toggles anchored it securely, a hood that buttoned under the chin kept out the wind, and the fabric was frequently water resistant so it would keep out the rain.

LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Zesty, Versatile Sauce
LEAD: Sesame noodles are the chop suey of the 80's.
Just about every takeout Chinese restaurant offers the dish.
It is the rich taste of the sesame, freshened with ginger and sweetened slightly, that appeals to us.
The taste is not unlike peanut butter.
It is easy to have a version of the sauce on hand to use whenever the mood for that flavor strikes.

Elegy for the Underhill Oak, The Last of Four Giants
LEAD: IT is always sad to lose a friend, one that you have known and admired for many decades.
My dear departed friend was the Underhill Oak, a red oak, the largest and oldest in Yonkers.
This arboreal giant stood 115 feet tall and had dominated the landscape near the foot of Underhill Street for at least 350 years.

More shoppers arrived at 7:30 A.M. and by 9:45, just before the sale was to open, dozens of people were lined up at the door hoping for the first crack at the advertised set of Mercedes tires, spinet piano and Oriental rug, as well as the hundreds of other items that are traditionally sold at low prices at such sales.

THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
LEAD: I can inform Joseph Epstein that there is nothing wrong with the conscience-and-guilt appeal in battling racism.
The civil-rights movement grasped in its early years - in the budding days of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People - that conscience and guilt are two sides of the same moral coin, and that any society claiming to be civilized must wrestle with both conscience and guilt when rectifying the wounds it creates.

LEAD: Lisa Burke, 15 years old, and Molly Tolkoff, 14, of Brookline, Mass., play a rough and tough, competitive brand of ice hockey for the Brookline High School freshman team.
Rough play is not unusual for this sport.
What is unusual is that their teammates are boys.
In two years, however, the girls won't be on the varsity team.

LEAD: ABOUT half the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-A has been been penalized for breaking N.C.A.A. rules at least once since 1980.
Division 1-A is the N.C.A.A.'s most visible competitive level, comprising 106 colleges and universities with big-time football programs.
Most violations have occurred in basketball and football programs.

Disaster Leads to Safety on the High Seas
LEAD: Until 10 years ago, the fatalities in post-World War II sailboat races could be counted on four or five hands.
Occasionally, a sailor might fall overboard and drown, and a boat would disappear with all hands.
Never was it said that sailing was as predictably risky as mountain climbing or powerboat racing.

Mother Nature Will Provide
LEAD: Insofar as erosion on Long Island's South Shore, I say, ''Don't mess with Mother Nature!'' If one looks back, say to the day the Fire Island Lighthouse was built, the water was literally a stone's throw away.
There would be no Robert Moses State Park there today if it weren't for erosion.
What the sea took away in other places, it gave back on Fire Island.

Harmony Envelops the DAT
LEAD: The Last days of July profoundly altered the long-range outlook for audio.
Obstacles that had hitherto barred the import of digital audio tape (DAT) decks were suddenly removed by an unexpected agreement between record companies and the manufacturers of DAT equipment.
After three years of waiting and some bitter regulatory debates in Congress, American audio fans will at last have unhindered access to this superior method of home recording.

When Child's Play Isn't Fun
LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST worrisome reports a pediatrician can hear from a parent is that a child has lost all interest in favorite toys.
A child who can no longer take pleasure in playing may be signaling a psychiatric emergency.
Though the pediatrician may not be formally trained in child psychology, such emergencies must always be as much a concern as medical problems.

Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Joan Gould's article on the Great Mosque of Cordoba, which I visited many years ago: Each of the 850 pillars has a lead plate at the top.
In case of earthquake, instead of stone rubbing against stone, the lead acts as a buffer.

THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD

A Steady Observer for Trembling Moodus
LEAD: IN Moodus, they call her the Earthquake Lady.
Each time the ground moves, the windows of Cathy Wilson's house rattle and the stereo speakers that hang on the wall shake.
At times, loud thumps send ripples through her water bed, waking her at all hours of the night.
And sometimes, rumbling jackhammer-like noises from below send her 20 cats scattering in every direction.

Airport Parking
LEAD: To the Editor: Speaking of airport parking (Travel Advisory, June 25), some city agency should look into the parking fees at the city's airports.
Short-term parking costs $1 an hour; fair enough.

PASTIMES: Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Divide overgrown clumps of bearded iris and replant firm rhizomes in groups of three; discard rhizomes that are old or rotted.
Mail orders for bulbs that will be planted in fall.
Cut to the ground stalks of perennials that bloomed.
Prune hedges, especially privet, hemlock, yew.
Last call to sow biennial seed outdoors in nursery beds.

Three Gems in an Azure Setting
LEAD: FAVIGNANA, Levanzo and Marettimo, as the three small islands that make up the Egadi archipelago are called, lie just off the western coast of Sicily, opposite the port of Trapani.
Each island has steep and stony coastlines, a few scattered farms and one small town whose inhabitants have lived - for thousands of years - by quarrying the rock beneath them and harvesting the waters around them.

A Boom, As Nature Fails to Satisfy Demand
LEAD: Although fish have been farmed in this country for more than 30 years, aquaculture has never been what you would call a booming business.
Most of the entrepreneurs who dominate the business lack the resources and sophistication to bring their fish to the mass market.

LEAD: SOME travelers think a change of scenery means a breath of fresh air, but if they're headed for Rio de Janeiro, Milan or Seoul - to name just a few cities - they are wrong.
Air pollution has spread to most cities around the globe, turning skies gray, choking many residents and raining soot.

'Workshop Sharecroppers'?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Runner at Half-Century Is Brought to Knees
LEAD: LAST year I turned 50, and it didn't bother me a bit.
I was in great shape.
I weighed 20 pounds less than when I got married 23 years before.
I had no gray hair, and from the front only a dignified receding at the temples was visible, suggesting, if anything, accumulating wisdom.
It was fun assuring friends that indeed I was 50, and hearing ''You sure don't look it,'' and ''I never would have guessed.


Police in South Africa Clash With Mourners
LEAD: Thousands of mourners defied armed South African police today to bury two student supporters of the African National Congress.
Later, the mourners clashed with the police after the officers tried to disperse them with tear gas.


Design: Western Flair; Rough and Ready
LEAD: The look is easily identifiable: Navajo blankets and beautifully handcrafted clay pots, rough-hewn furniture and cactus plants.
Indeed, Western artifacts are as much a part of the American design culture as Shaker or Colonial objects.
But rather than creating a total down-home environment, those who embrace this Western esthetic today tend to happily transplant elements of it in relatively small doses, placing just a few objects in modern settings.

LEAD: ALUMINUM siding is popular because of its easy installation, durability, good looks and affordable cost.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: THE number of public one-room schools, schools with one teacher for the first eight grades, has decreased because of population growth and the increased busing of students to central sites.
There were nearly 150,000 public one-room schools in 1930; in 1971 there were less than 2,000, and in 1987 about 700.

LEAD: THIS is the way I remember the pledge to the flag as we used to give it in school.
We fifth graders would stand up and face the flag.
Right hand over heart we'd begin: ''I pledge allegiance to the flag...'' At that point we'd fling out the right arm, palm up, and continue, ''...of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

Holmes said his aim in ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' had been to ''make fun'' what had been a ''dark and somber book.'' He did not say he intended to make fun of the Dickens work.

Cooperation Between Equals
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fund Follows a Tradition of Marian Anderson
LEAD: WHEN Marian Anderson received the $10,000 Philadelphia Award in the 1950's, she used the money to set up scholardhips for young singers. ''If some of these people have gone out and brought pleasure and satisfaction to publics of their own and if the scholarship helped them climb another rung on the way to their goal, I feel that the people who have listened to me ofer the years deserve the credit,'' she wrote in her autobiography.


So Far, Congress Comes Up Short on Ideas
LEAD: RARELY has a summer vacation been so eagerly awaited.
The 101st Congress broke for its August recess this weekend in a frustrated and uncertain mood.
Yes, it was jarred by ethics scandals and slowed by the transition to new leadership in both houses.
But with the leaders in place now and the turmoil receding, it is clear that some larger trouble is at work.


PASTIMES: Stamps
LEAD: Three recent books, handsomely produced and well illustrated, are each a good browse.
The first is ''The Guinness Book of Stamps,'' part of the Guinness Superlatives series.
Herein are found the biggest stamp and the smallest, the fastest delivery and the slowest, and a wealth of information on how and why stamps are produced.

This could be a prime example of a well-intentioned reform with devastating side-effects.

Has Mr.
Epstein ever heard Mr.
Jackson speak?
He doesn't talk about being a victim.
Quite the contrary.
He tells young people: You can do it if you study, if you work, if you stay off drugs.

Europe's Unwieldy Air Traffic Setup
LEAD: Each time an airplane is about to leave the airspace of one European country for that of another, an air traffic controller must usually make a time-consuming phone call to a foreign colleague who notes the information with pencil and paper.
In the United States, by contrast, computer hookups have for more than 10 years allowed a controller in one center to pass on a flight to a neighboring center with the touch of a button.

Bolivia Set to Join GATT
LEAD: Bolivia has agreed to become the 97th member of the world's main trade forum, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets the rules for four-fifths of international commerce.
In a ceremony on Friday at the organization's Geneva headquarters, the Bolivian Ambassador, Raul Espana-Smith, signed a protocol setting out the terms of his country's admission to GATT, after 21 months of negotiations with the pact's other member states.

Question Box
LEAD:  Age Extremes of PGA  Q. Who were the youngest and oldest golfers to win the PGA Championship?
A.
The honors belong to a pair of members of the PGA Hall of Fame, Gene Sarazen, who was enshrined in 1940, and Julius Boros, inducted in 1974.
Six years after the PGA Championship was instituted, and when it was still a match-play event (a format that lasted until 1958), Sarazen defeated Emmet French, 4 and 3, in the 1922 final at Oakmont, Pa.

LEAD: Japanese banks don't have to give away toasters to attract new deposits - their customers' propensity to save is strong.
How strong?
According to Fortune magazine, when a Japanese bank recently offered 250-year ''Time Capsule'' savings accounts, it had 20,000 takers.

LEAD: A prominent Peronist in the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem walked into the headquarters of the Bunge &amp; Born Corporation in downtown Buenos Aires a few months ago to keep a lunch appointment.

Campaign Matters; No Opposition, No Explanations For Santucci
LEAD: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens, who usually investigates others, is hands down the most investigated prosecutor in the city.
He is, as politicians say, accident-prone.
He has been investigated by the special state prosecutor and also superseded by him.
He has been investigated by a fellow district attorney and the State Commission on Government Integrity.
