LEAD: In a few months a new task force headed by Dr.
James O. Mason, the Assistant Secretary for Public Health, is slated to tell President Bush what America should do about ''crack babies'' - the thousands born brain-damaged, malformed or seizure-prone because their mothers smoked crack during pregnancy.

20 Firefighters Hurt in Blaze
LEAD: Twenty firefighters suffered heat exhaustion and smoke inhalation battling a three-alarm fire at a warehouse on the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday.
The Victorian warehouse, at 135 Plymouth Street, was occupied by about 30 artists, but none were injured and damage to the building was not serious, a Fire Department spokesman said.

Review/Opera; How Santa Fe Handles a Built-In Problem in 'Rosenkavalier'
LEAD: Few roles in the opera repertory demand more stage presence, intelligence and psychological insight of a lyric soprano than that of the Marschallin in ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' This most complex of Strauss heroines is a princess from whom authority naturally radiates but whose power to command respect depends as much on her cultivation and brains as on her high position in the Viennese aristocracy.

LEAD: When it came time to select a judge for the trial of the six youths charged in the rape and beating of the Central Park jogger, a court administrator departed from a New York State policy of choosing judges by lottery.

New Orleans Sauce For Jelly Roll Morton
LEAD: In his later years, Ferdinand Joseph LaMenthe, better known as Jelly Roll Morton, used to boast that he invented jazz.
He didn't, of course - an earlier generation beat him to it -but he did change the course of the music, not just as a virtuoso pianist but also as a composer, arranger and bandleader.

Girl, 15, Is Killed In Bronx Shooting
LEAD: A 15-year-old girl was shot to death in the Bronx yesterday afternoon after the driver of the car in which she was sitting exchanged words with another driver, who then pulled a gun and started firing, the police said.


Market Place; Bond Issuers Turn to RED's
LEAD: NEW financial instruments that go by the unlikely name of RED's, or refunding escrow deposits, enable issuers of tax-exempt bonds to lock in today's low interest rates for bond issues years down the road.
Introduced recently by the First Boston Corporation, RED's have since been used by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company (which calls its version ''municipal forwards'') and an affiliate of the Bankers Trust Company, and may become a common arrow in the quiver of all the big investment banking firms.

LEAD: The best dance music offers a release from the yoke of daily existence, from taxes to heat to a busted romance.

Elf's Pennwalt Offer Is Completed
LEAD: The French oil giant Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine ended its $132-a-share offer for the Pennwalt Corporation on Friday after buying 96 percent of the outstanding shares.
Elf Aquitaine plans to merge Pennwalt, a pharmaceutical company, with AC Development Inc., an Elf subsidiary in Stamford, Conn.

Review/Music; The Beethoven Influences: He on Today, Today on Him
LEAD: There was a chaos to this weekend's ''Beethoven Experience'' at the Pepsico Summerfare that the composer of the Ninth Symphony would have found useful.
Two days and nights of rehearsals, recitals, lectures, sing-alongs and even dancing in the lobbies were piled one on the other.
All were centered on Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players and aimed at this evening's performance of Beethoven's last and most problematic symphony.

LEAD: Shares in Wyse Technology, the troubled personal computer maker, jumped $1.25 today, to $6.625, amid speculation that the company will go private, either through a leveraged buyout or a sale to a third party.
The 23.3 percent gain was the second largest on the New York Stock Exchange.
More than seven million shares were traded.

LEAD: Despite a tidal wave of publicity for the premiere, the new ABC News program ''Prime Time Live'' stirred only a ripple of interest among television viewers - a development that industry analysts attributed to the limited ability of news personalities to attract a mass audience.

New Studies Find Many Myths about Mourning
LEAD: SOME of the most widespread beliefs about mourning are largely myths, new scientific findings are showing.
And researchers warn that these myths can increase the mourners' distress by holding them to false expectations of what is ''normal.''

NEW DIVORCE ISSUE: EMBRYOS' STATUS
LEAD: An estranged couple's battle over seven fertilized human eggs went to trial in State Circuit Court here today, with the woman's lawyer contending the embryos are ''preborn children'' with rights of their own.


Finding That Parents 'Imprint' Genes May Shed New Light on Diseases
LEAD: OVER the last two years, molecular biologists have gradually come upon a startling discovery that flatly contradicts the laws of genetics.
Now, with that work in mind, clinical researchers are taking a new look at the inheritance patterns of diseases and are asking whether the molecular biologists' findings could help them understand, predict and even treat diseases like cancer and Huntington's disease.


Hanson Wins Gold Fields
LEAD: Hanson P.L.C., the British industrial conglomerate, won control of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. today with a revised $:3.5 billion ($5.6 billion) cash offer for the London-based mining concern.
Hanson's investment bank, N.M.
Rothschild, said it had acceptances representing 57.3 percent of Gold Fields' shares, including 29.6 percent committed by the South African-backed Minerals and Resources Corporation after its own bid failed earlier this year.


Insurers' Excessive Fear of AIDS
LEAD: Meeting the health costs of AIDS will not be easy.
But health insurance companies are making a cruel situation worse by insisting on the right to test applicants for health insurance and, in some cases, by restricting coverage for the disease.
The cost of AIDS is large and growing, but is still a very small part of the national health bill.


Utah Votes $4.5 Million For Cold Fusion Studies
LEAD: With one scientist abstaining and another voting no, a state panel today voted to release $4.5 million for research on room-temperature fusion at the University of Utah.

A Bit of Summer Year Round: Resort Wear Branches Out
LEAD: Resort collections being shown in New York this week have a bright, joyous look and are designed to give a lilt to a woman's wardrobe.
These clothes will start appearing in the stores in November and will be available until spring styles take over.
They are divided between styles to be worn at warm-weather resorts and those to be worn up north under winter coats.

Mr. Bush, Alone on Nicaragua
LEAD: Five Central American Presidents ended their meeting in Honduras yesterday with a workable plan for demobilizing the contras and ending civil war in Nicaragua.
They called for disbanding rebel camps in southern Honduras by Dec. 8.
This would be 90 days after the stationing of international monitors in the jungles to oversee compliance and deter cross-border raiding.


Kennedy Center Announces '89 Awards
LEAD: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced yesterday that the 1989 Kennedy Center Honors would be awarded to the singer and actor Harry Belafonte, the actresses Claudette Colbert and Mary Martin, the dancer Alexandra Danilova and the composer William Schuman.


Weill Hall '89 Season
LEAD: Two cabaret mini-series, a Great Singers series, and programs called Quartets Plus, Vintage Originals and Perfect Combinations will make up the Weill Recital Hall 1989-90 season, which opens on Oct. 13.
The cabaret series begins on Oct. 18 with Elisabeth Welch and continues with Jill Corey, Margaret Whiting, Kaye Ballard and Julie Wilson.

By Design; Odd Couplings
LEAD: Last year, would you have tossed a big satin stole over your gray flannel suit?
Or thought about muffling the neckline of a tweed jacket with a scarf of silk taffeta?
Probably not.
No more than you would have dreamed of adding gold-and-red-brocade boots to a casual suede skirt and cashmere sweater costume.

Fruehauf Changes Name
LEAD: The Fruehauf Corporation has changed its name to the K-H Corporation.
The name change was required under terms of the July 14 sale of its truck-trailer and maritime operations to the Terex Corporation.
K-H is the holding company for the Kelsey-Hayes Company, a maker of wheels, brake parts and other car and truck components.

LEAD: The White House indicated today that efforts to win the release of eight American hostages in Lebanon might take a long time.
Administration aides said President Bush wanted to allow time for various initiatives to gel.


Bus-Car Crash Kills 4
LEAD: A tour bus carrying 43 people from Oklahoma and Arkansas, many of them elderly, collided head-on with a car Saturday on U.S. 1, killing 4 people and injuring 20.
The dead were in the car, said a Penobscot Bay Medical Center spokesman.
A 10-year-old boy was hospitalized.

Gay Chorus Auditions
LEAD: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus will hold auditions for tenors, baritones and basses on Aug. 23 and 30 from 7 to 10 P.M.
Singers must have a prepared song and participate in sight-reading and voice-placement exercises.
Men and women who do not sing but who wish to help the chorus may also apply, the director, Gary Miller, said.


Brokerage Mergers Up
LEAD: Twenty-five securities firms were involved in mergers or acquisitions last year, compared with 19 in 1987, the Securities Industry Association said yesterday.

Clue Is Found To Evolution Of Plants
LEAD: BOTANISTS studying freshwater algae have discovered structures that may have been critical to the evolution of plant life from water to land 400 million years ago.


Stena May Sell Containers Stake
LEAD: Stena Holding A.G., a Dutch ferry concern, said it might sell a portion or all of its 8.2 percent stake in Sea Containers Ltd.
Stena is a partner with Tiphook P.L.C. in Temple Holdings Ltd., which has offered $50 a share, or $824 million, for Sea Containers.
The bid is scheduled to expire on Wednesday.

Chess
LEAD: Yasser Seirawan was disappointed with his showing in the Fifth World Cup Tournament, which finished June 24 at the World Trade Center in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
The 29-year-old Seattle grandmaster, the only American entered, was hoping for one of the top places, but instead came out just below the middle of the field.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials challenged Nicaragua today to guarantee safety and political rights to contras returning home under the agreement reached by five Central American leaders.
But the officials acknowledged that they had little leverage to force concessions by Managua.

LEAD: In a sharp and perhaps decisive blow to the American-supported Nicaraguan rebels, the Presidents of five Central American countries agreed today on a timetable for rebel base camps in Honduras to be disbanded under international supervision no later than Dec. 8.

Japanese Ruling Party Makes Choice for Premier
LEAD: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party today selected Toshiki Kaifu to become the nation's next Prime Minister, giving the 58-year-old former Education Minister the task of rescuing the party from its worst crisis in history.


New Law Curbs Illegal Aliens, Report Shows
LEAD: Nearly 1.3 million aliens crossed into the United States from Mexico illegally from 1986 to 1988, but the figure would have been closer to 2 million if not for an overhaul in immigration law, a new study reports.


Bridge
LEAD: When the Life Master Pair Championship ended here Sunday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals the word went round the playing area: ''Katz has won.'' This was not entirely clear, because there were two players named Katz in contention.

LEAD: The dollar edged higher yesterday against most currencies in thin trading, extending last week's rally, which stemmed from speculation that interest rates are not likely to decline soon.

Fall in Oil Prices Continuing As World Supply Increases
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and its byproducts continued to ease yesterday as the market's attention shifted from the latest Mideast hostage crisis to the increasing global supplies of petroleum being offered by both OPEC and non-OPEC producers.

Big East Is Expected to Approve 6-Foul Rule
LEAD: Basketball coaches in the Big East Conference are expected to agree to a rule change that would allow players six personal fouls before disqualification from a game instead of five, but a league poll is not complete, the Big East commissioner, Dave Gavitt, said yesterday.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  YACHTING  Lack of Wind Stalls Fastnet Fleet: A lack of wind left the nearly 280 yachts in the Fastnet Race, the most prestigious portion of the Admiral's Cup regatta, floundering yesterday in the waters off the southwestern coast of England, having covered less than 150 miles in 24 hours.
It was one of the slowest starts ever in the Fastnet Race, between England and Ireland, and many of the boats had to drop anchor overnight to avoid being carried in the wrong direction by tides.


Surprises for Rookie Linemen at Jet Camp
LEAD: When Ron Stallworth and Patrick Marlatt, the Jets' two rookie defensive linemen, reported to camp this morning, they found surprises waiting for them.
Stallworth, a fourth-round draft choice out of Auburn, thought his was a practical joke.
Marlatt, a ninth-round pick out of West Virginia, thought his was the beginning of the end.


Cleaning Screens Safely
LEAD: THE insurance company spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on fancy new computer workstations.
The company knew that screen glare could cause headaches, eye strain and general physical stress, so each computer was equipped with an expensive high-resolution monitor with a special glare-free optical coating.


Steel Output Up in Week
LEAD: Domestic steel production totaled 1.9 million net tons in the week ended Saturday, up four-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.
The week's production represented 83.8 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, according to the steel industry group.

Cadaret's 2-Hitter Stops Indians
LEAD: Greg Cadaret all but leaped out of the dugout and fairly sprinted once his spikes hit the field on his way to the mound to face the Cleveland Indians in the eighth inning last night.
If he was going to make history, he was going to do it in a hurry.


Pair Charged in Son's Death
LEAD: A couple was arrested Saturday on felony child-neglect charges after their 2-year-old son died in a pickup truck in 100-degree heat.
The parents, Larry and Cornelia McCook, had parked in the desert and left their son, Tawnshi, in the truck's cab while they ate in the back of the vehicle, Tom Dillard, a Metro Police spokesman, said.


Market Place; Impact on Banks Of Mexican Pact
LEAD: FOR American banks, whose stock prices have long suffered because of their heavy lending to Latin American countries, the Mexican debt accord of late July was a reminder that the troubled loans can be worked out without cataclysm, but not without sacrifice.

Tettleton Has Surgery
LEAD: Mickey Tettleton, the Baltimore Orioles' catcher, who is tied for fourth in the American League with 22 home runs, will be out three to six weeks after undergoing surgery yesterday to remove a cyst from his left knee.


URBAN POPULATION GAINING, U.S. SAYS
LEAD: Nearly half of all Americans live in just 37 metropolitan areas, and almost nine-tenths of the nation's growth occurs in metropolitan areas, the Census Bureau has reported.


Thomas Stanley, 71, A New Jersey Surgeon
LEAD: Thomas A. Stanley, a surgeon in New Jersey, died from complications of a stroke Sunday at St.
Mary's Hospital in Orange, N.J.
He suffered the stroke three weeks earlier.
He was 71 years old and lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.


Making a Connection
LEAD: YOU'RE on the road for business, toting your trusty portable computer.
When you get to your hotel room, it's time to send a report to the head office.
You unplug the telephone line from the back of the instrument, just as you do when working at home, and plug your modem into it.

Births in Brazil Are on Decline, Easing Worries
LEAD: In one generation, Brazil's fertility rate has been cut almost in half, and in the words of one expert, the country's ''population bomb has been deactivated.''


Women Make Gains in Attaining Office
LEAD: Being a woman and running for public office is still a challenge, but it is not quite the challenge it used to be, the National Women's Political Caucus has found.


Review/Opera; 17th-Century Camp and Kinkiness
LEAD: Early Baroque operas, composed in a pastoral tradition that modern audiences, separated from the idiom by three centuries, cannot reasonably be expected to savor, do not revive easily.
So in a time when the old stunt of updating opera classics is again in fashion, Baroque opera is especially ripe for revisionism.


U.S. Sees New Milken Indictment
LEAD: The Government expects to bring a new indictment against Michael R. Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s former ''junk bond'' chief, by the first week in October, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.


Austin Has Leg Surgery
LEAD: Tracy Austin, the two-time United States Open singles champion, who suffered a broken right leg in a car accident in Short Hills, N.J., last Thursday, underwent a three-and-a-half-hour operation on the leg yesterday in Inglewood, Calif.


Dunkin' Donuts
LEAD: The Delaware Chancery Court ruled in favor of Dunkin' Donuts Inc. in its lawsuit against the DD Acquisition Corporation, which has made a $305 million hostile bid for Dunkin.
The court denied DD Acquisition's motion to block Dunkin' Donuts takeover defenses involving an employee stock ownership plan, a ''poison pill'' and the sale of preferred stock to the General Electric Capital Company.


John G. Piper, 74, A Textile Executive
LEAD: John G. Piper, a former vice president of the Pepperell textile company, died of bone cancer Friday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford.
He was 74 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.


A.T.&amp;T. Says MCI Violates Pricing Rules
LEAD: In a new thrust in the dispute over the pricing of long-distance services for business customers, A.T.&amp;T. yesterday accused its main competitor, MCI, of violating the Communications Act by providing large customers with services at prices not specified in its public tariffs.

Hubert Beuve-Mery, 87, Dies; Founded Le Monde
LEAD: Hubert Beuve-Mery, the stubbornly independent founder of Le Monde, France's most respected newspaper, and its editor for a quarter of a century, died Sunday in Fontainebleau, near Paris.
He was 87 years old and suffered a severe fall 10 days ago, the newspaper said.

Review/Music; 'Bouncin' With Bud,' Be-Bop Tribute in 2 Halves
LEAD: ''Bouncin' With Bud,'' a tribute to the be-bop pianist and composer Bud Powell at Lincoln Center on Saturday night, was peppered with moments of still beauty.

Petty Thefts Disable New York Turnstiles A Token at a Time
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority says it has finally found a way to deter the thieves who break into subway turnstiles and make off with hundreds of tokens.
But it is fighting a losing battle against less ambitious criminals, who steal only a few tokens at a time, but leave great numbers of turnstiles disabled.

Review/Dance;  A New Gennaro in London Group's 'Napoli'
LEAD: Maximiliano Guerra danced leading roles as a child.
As an adult, he won medals at several ballet competitions and performed with a variety of companies.
One might expect a certain slickness from a young dancer with such a background.
And so the purity and simplicity of his dancing in the lead role of Gennaro in the London Festival Ballet's production of ''Napoli'' on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House came as a surprise.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The immensely expensive legislation that President Bush is expected to sign this week to rescue the savings industry will ultimately affect the pocketbooks and convenience of millions of American consumers.
But the immediate noticeable impact is likely to be confined to somewhat lower interest rates for a relative few.

Rig Count Climbs a Bit
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States rose by 4, to 874, in the week ended Aug. 4, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
The oilfield services company said the number a year ago was 945.
The largest increases in the rig count occurred in Oklahoma and Texas.


Former Researcher To Run NEC America
LEAD: NEC America Inc., the Melville, L.I., telecommunications subsidiary of the NEC Corporation of Japan, said yesterday that Hisashi Kaneko had been appointed president and chief executive officer.


10 Killed, 25 Injured As Rockets Hit Kabul
LEAD: Anti-Government guerrillas struck Kabul with dozens of rockets again today, killing 10 people and wounding 25.


Topics of The Times; A Bolivian for All Seasons
LEAD: One of the most colorful and remarkable political careers in modern Latin American history ended Sunday when Victor Paz Estenssoro completed his fourth term as Bolivia's President.
His first term began in 1952 and was secured by a revolution of armed miners and peasants.
His second marked the last time, until this week, that a democratically elected Bolivian President served out a full four year term.

Reported Crimes Rise 4.3% in Three Months
LEAD: The number of crimes reported in New York City rose 4.3 percent in the first three months of 1989, down slightly from the 5.2 percent increase in the same period last year, the state said yesterday.


Robert F. Jani, 54, a Producer
LEAD: Robert F. Jani, whose company produced spectacular stage shows for Radio City Music Hall and developed concepts for the Walt Disney organization, died Sunday night at his home in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.
He was 54 years old and had been ill for four years with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the affliction known as Lou Gehrig's disease.

Dallas Comics Lawsuit
LEAD: The Times Herald Printing Company, publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, filed suit today against the A. H. Belo Corporation, the owner of The Dallas Morning News, seeking to prevent Belo from acquiring exclusive Dallas-area rights to 26 comics, columns and other features.
The lawsuit in state court contends that Belo and the Universal Press Syndicate will ''inexorably harm competition in the Dallas market'' if the rights are granted.

LEAD: It was dismissed as a forgiveably immature boast when, in 1960, a 29-year-old politician named Toshiki Kaifu became the youngest member elected to Parliament and enthusiastically told his supporters that if they supported him for 29 more years, he would become Prime Minister of Japan.


Soft-Serve Desserts: How Low in Calories?
LEAD: THE American preoccupation with diet and health is fueling a dramatic increase in sales of frozen desserts that have fewer calories and less fat than regular ice cream.
For each of the last three years, sales of frozen yogurt have increased 30 percent, and 90 percent of all frozen yogurt sales has been in soft-serve products.

Canada's Supreme Court Rejects Ex-Lover's Effort to Halt Abortion
LEAD: Ruling in a major test case, the Canadian Supreme Court yesterday unanimously rejected a man's attempt to prevent his former lover from having an abortion.

Lincoln Journal; Approaching Sundown For the Dairyman's Life
LEAD: In 1945, there were 46 working dairy farms in this town high in the mountains of western Vermont.
Now there are two. ''Lincoln Center,'' as local people call it, is a store, a firehouse, a town hall and the United Church of Lincoln, which holds ecumenical services.

Savings Unit To Prudential
LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has acquired Cartersville Federal Savings Bank of Georgia for $20 million in cash.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Net Off at Grey
LEAD: Grey Advertising said Monday that its net income for the second quarter of the year fell by 2.4 percent, to $4.94 million, or $3.73 a share, from $6.3 million, or $4.82 a share, for the period in 1988.
The company said that last year's second quarter included a net gain of $1.95 million, or $1.40 a share, from the sale of a foreign subsidiary.

LEAD: Responding to growing pressure from the Environmental Protection Agency and environmental groups, a wide range of businesses, military installations and cultural institutions are struggling to curb their use of halons, a highly effective family of firefighting chemicals believed by scientists to be even more destructive to the world's ozone layer than their better-known chemical cousins, the chlorofluorocarbons.

LEAD: A hand injury from his last fight on July 20 has forced former heavyweight champion George Foreman to pull out of his Aug. 17 fight against Michael Greer in Las Vegas, Nev., the USA Network reported yesterday.
The network had planned to televise the bout.

LEAD: In a move that may increase the influence of Japanese companies on Wall Street, CS First Boston Inc. told its employees yesterday in an internal memorandum that it had sold 18.25 percent of the firm to a group of international investors.

West Point Picks Woman to Lead Cadet Corps
LEAD: More than a decade after the first woman was admitted to the United States Military Academy, the 20-year-old daughter of an Army colonel has become the first woman selected to be first captain of the Corps of Cadets, the academy's highest cadet honor.


Resignation at Arizona Papers
LEAD: Pat Murphy, publisher of The Arizona Republic and The Phoenix Gazette, resigned abruptly yesterday after three years in the job.


New Zealand Plane Crash
LEAD: A sightseeing plane crashed in the Southern Alps on Tuesday, killing nine American and Canadian tourists aboard, the police said.
They said searchers recovered six bodies today from the wreckage of the plane, but the bodies had not yet been identified.
A New Zealander was piloting the twin-engine plane, which went down near Mount Aspiring on South Island.


UAL Stock Up Again; Board Meets Today
LEAD: The shares of the UAL Corporation, parent company of United Airlines, jumped again yesterday - rising $8.50, to close at $219.25 - in advance of a meeting today at which UAL directors will consider a takeover offer from Marvin Davis.

LEAD: Bernard M. Barenholtz, co-founder of the Creative Playthings children's toy company, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Marlborough, N.H.
He was 75 years old.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Profit Rises
LEAD: The WPP Group announced yesterday that its pretax profits rose 61 percent in the first half of 1989, to $:26 million, or $41.6 million, from $:16.19 million, or $25.9 million, in the corresponding period last year.
Earnings-per-share for the British company that owns J. Walter Thompson and the Ogilvy Group grew 53 percent, to 33.9 pence, or 54 cents, from 22.2 pence, or 35 cents.

LEAD: The Estonian Parliament today approved the first law in the Soviet Union requiring that candidates and voters fulfill a residency requirement.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Suzuki Narrows Search
LEAD: The American Suzuki Motor Company, the domestic arm of the Japanese auto manufacturer, narrowed its ad agency search to three shops with offices in Los Angeles, Asher/ Gould Advertising; Wieden &amp; Kennedy, whose base is Portland; and Hakuhodo, the Japanese ad agency.
A spokeswoman for Suzuki said the review would take six to eight weeks and would include speculative creative work.

LEAD: In introducing a racy car called the Corrado last week, Volkswagen A.G. provided a reminder that it faces a long, difficult road back from the fringes of the American car market.


Consumer Credit Rose 5.1% in June
LEAD: Consumer credit rose at an annual rate of 5.1 percent in June, down from a 7.3 percent pace in May, the Federal Reserve Board said today.


IRAN IS REPORTED READY FOR A DEAL TO RECOVER ASSETS
LEAD: Teheran press reports said today that Iran would help the Bush Administration obtain the freedom of American hostages if Iranian assets frozen in the United States since 1979 are released.


Jan de Graaff, Tamer of the Wild Lily, Dies at 86
LEAD: Jan de Graaff, a horticulturist whose hybridization of lilies helped make them a favorite garden flower, died of Parkinson's disease Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 86 years old.

Cineplex Expands
LEAD: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it has bought a 50 percent stake in four cinema complexes in Suffolk County, L.I., for undisclosed terms.
Cineplex will operate and schedule movies for the complexes, which were acquired in partnership with a group of New York real estate developers.
The theaters are in Mattituck, Westhampton, Islip and Sayville.

LEAD: A moderately strong earthquake jolted the San Francisco Bay area early this morning, breaking windows and shaking people in their beds.
But when Ed Bortugno's wife telephoned him at 1:15 A.M. to tell him about it, his first reaction was that someone was playing a joke on him.

LEAD: The Columbia, the nation's oldest space shuttle, soared flawlessly into space today on a secret military mission that civilian experts said would focus on the deployment of an advanced photo reconnaissance satellite.


Gibson Out for Season
LEAD: Kirk Gibson, the National League Most Valuable Player last season, will undergo surgery next Tuesday and be lost for the remainder of the season.
The 32-year-old outfielder completes 1989 with a .213 batting average, 9 home runs and 28 r.b.i. while playing in only 71 games.

LEAD: George Gervin, the former scoring star of the Spurs who led the National Basketball Association in scoring four times, was arrested early yesterday in San Antonio on charges of driving while intoxicated and possession of marijuana.
The five-time All-N.B.A. first team selection, who retired at the end of the 1985-86 season, was released on a personal recognizance bond.

Study Finds Female Athletes Play as Hard but Study Harder
LEAD: Female basketball players in colleges with major programs spend as much time at their sport as their male counterparts, but the women study more, attend class more regularly and get higher grades, according to a study conducted for the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

LEAD: Individual retirement accounts at banks could be disrupted by a recent opinion from the Labor Department that interest on I.R.A. deposits may lose its tax-deferred status if the deposits are used to qualify customers for free checking accounts, banking officials said yesterday.

Abraham P. Conan, Lawyer, 91
LEAD: Abraham P. Conan, a lawyer who specialized in labor and immigration matters and helped European refugees after World War II, died of pneumonia on July 26 following a stroke at his home in Manhattan.
He was 91 years old.


Cypriots Gain Access To Disputed Mosaics
LEAD: A local art dealer agreed today to release four sixth-century mosaics to the Autocephalous Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus after the Cypriots promised to leave them in an Indianapolis vault for two weeks.


Rangers Approach Roger Neilson
LEAD: The Rangers, apparently at this late date still expanding the field of coaching candidates, have most recently spoken with Roger Neilson about taking over the team.


Grand Met to Buy Fast-Food Chain
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. has agreed to buy the restaurant, manufacturing and distributing operations of United Biscuits P.L.C. for $:180 million, or $288 million.
United Biscuits, based in Britain, owns Wimpy hamburger restaurants, Pizzaland restaurants and Perfect Pizza outlets.
It reported profits of $:11.2 million, or $18 million, on sales of $:147.4 million, or $236 million, in 1988.

LEAD: President Bush will make his toughest calls on terrorism and dealing with hostages in the coming weeks.
Whatever he does will involve political risks - like yesterday's rejection of an Iranian feeler to help with the hostages in return for release of Iranian assets in the U.S.
He will also need backing from Congress and the public.

A. W. Wilson, Minister, 87
LEAD: The Rev.
A.
W.
Wilson, whose church became a rallying point for the 1955 bus boycott here that set off the civil rights protests, died Friday at his home after a long illness.
He was 87 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: A map on July 27 with an article about recent fighting in Nicaragua located two towns incorrectly.
Llano Grande is about 70 miles east of Managua.
El Dorado is in the Atlantic Coast region.
In some editions Waslala was also located incorrectly; it is near the center of the country.

LEAD: In the first pleas to be entered since the Government announced the indictment of 46 commodity brokers last week, two brothers who deal in Japanese yen futures, Brian E. Sledz and James G. Sledz, pleaded guilty today to charges that included commodities fraud, wire fraud and mail fraud.


Phone Workers Settling In for a Long Strike
LEAD: Striking workers from three regional telephone companies settled in yesterday for what many expect will be a long strike.


'90's Political Turf War Promises to Be Fierce
LEAD: The anticipated battles over how to draw the political map for the 1990's - the new district lines for Congress and state legislatures - will be more complicated, more litigious and more partisan than ever, specialists from both parties said here today.

LEAD: Sir James Goldsmith today offered to place the American insurance operations of B.A.T.
Industries under the control of an independent trust if the investor group he heads succeeds in its $21 billion bid for the company.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle will travel next month to South Korea, Japan and the Philippines, his office announced today.
The trip, Sept. 19 to 28, will include meetings with Presidents Roh Tae Woo of South Korea and Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Arbitron's 'Mediawatch'
LEAD: The Arbitron Company said yesterday that its commercial monitoring system will become electronic in the second quarter of next year.
The current manual system measures advertising expenditures and commercial occurrences on network, spot, cable and syndicated television franchises.
The change will enable Arbitron's Broadcast Advertisers Reports to measure television commercials 24 hours a day in the top 75 television markets, compared with the 17 markets it now assesses on a full-time basis.


New Product Lifts Medtronic Shares
LEAD: Medtronic Inc. shares rose $2.375 yesterday, to $116.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, on the announcement of a new product and on the heart pacemaker company's strong earnings outlook, analysts said.
The Minneapolis-based company said on Monday that it would introduce a single-chamber cardiac pacemaker system.


Sugarcoating Chips to Fight Disease
LEAD: There is no talk yet of Hershey teaming up with Intel or of a joint venture between Mars and Motorola, but sugarcoated semiconductors may have a bright future.
Researchers at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., have been mixing up sweet toppings for semiconductor wafers to study what it takes to make living cells adhere to each other.


Syria Is Said to Join Hostage-Release Effort
LEAD: The Government of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has joined efforts to arrange the release of Western hostages in Lebanon and has invited a senior Iranian official to Damascus for talks, Arab diplomats say.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about genetics referred incorrectly to genes that are chemically altered or ''imprinted'' before being passed to offspring.
The genes are inactivated, not activated.

LEAD: President Bush will meet with Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo to discuss White House opposition to the Governor's plan to dismantle the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, aides said today.
Mr.
Cuomo's request for the meeting stemmed from a suggestion last month by White House chief of staff, John Sununu, that the Long Island nuclear plant be mothballed, not dismantled.


Palo Cedro, Calif.
LEAD: WALK in almost any food shop here and you may find California orange blossom honey, manzanita honey, wildflower honey, clover honey, star thistle honey, sage honey or raspberry honey.

LEAD: One year ago, Congress authorized Federal reparation payments to some 55,000 Japanese-American survivors of World War II internment camps.
But not one dollar has been paid, and the outlook for adequate funding is bleak.
The national shame of putting these people behind barbed wire is now compounded by shirking on a promise to make amends.

It paid $1.7 million for the land for its six-acre campus in Salem, Ore., opposite Willamette University.

A Man of the Earth Reaps the Good Life
LEAD: STANDING in the middle of his garden one sunny morning, Angelo Pellegrini leaned on his ever-present walking stick and cast a grave eye over a dozen transplants of Swiss chard that he had set out from a seedbed earlier in the day.
As transplants often do, the chard looked weary, flopped over on its side in the dusty garden soil, and the old man shook his head as if reprimanding naughty students.

LEAD: WITH growth stalled and ambitious plans for market reforms on hold, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is playing his remaining economic card.

Town Bans Plastic Food Wrap
LEAD: The Legislative Council of Hamden has voted to ban the use of all non-biodegradable food packaging in Hamden starting March 1, 1990.
The vote Monday makes Hamden the first community in Connecticut to ban material that does not break down in the environment, such as polyvinyl chloride and polystyrene food wrapping, bags, boxes, cups and plates.

Steven Jayson with a display of restoration glass, which simulates antique glass, at S. A. Bendheim. (NYT/Michelle V. Agins) WHERE TO FIND IT; Reproducing Windowpanes of Old
LEAD: IF you are restoring an old house that has broken or missing windowpanes, you might use new or ''float'' glass, which lacks the distortion of old glass.
But most purists balk at the idea.
Faithful restorers will either replace the panes with old, salvaged glass or use new glass that is made to look antique.

22 Arrested in Nuclear Protest
LEAD: The authorities reported 22 arrests at the Nevada Test Site today as anti-nuclear demonstrators marked the 44th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki, Japan.
Nineteen people were cited on misdemeanor trespassing charges and released.
Three were being held on Federal trespassing charges because they entered the office of the Los Alamos National Laboratory here.

Cummins Engine Amends 'Pill' Plan
LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company, fighting off the latest potential takeover threat, said it had amended its ''poison pill'' defense.
Under the plan, directors of the diesel-engine maker may grant shareholders the right to buy new shares for $1 each if someone acquires 15 percent of the company's stock.

He was 74 years old and lived in Alexandria.


New York's Air, Washington's Duty
LEAD: The latest surveys by the Environmental Protection Agency merely confirm what every sensate New Yorker knows just by going out the front door: New York City has some of the foulest air in the country.
The city needs to reduce hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide emissions by a staggering 60 percent just to meet existing Federal health standards for ozone, the main component of urban smog.

LEAD: After 24 years as one of the most influential voices in Albany, State Senator John R. Dunne of Garden City said today that he would resign his seat next month.
Although he is prominent among Republicans across the state, the 59-year-old Mr.
Dunne is considered a maverick by the powerful Nassau County Republican organization because he often challenged its choices for offices.

Personal Health
LEAD: Breast-feeding, widely hailed for its health benefits, economy and ''naturalness,'' has caught on among modern American mothers, two-thirds of whom now nurse their babies.
As recently as 1970, only one mother in four breast-fed, so the change in infant feeding practices has been swift and dramatic despite the growing numbers of young married women in the work force.

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said two Spanish airlines had converted a total of 12 options on MD-80 aircraft into firm orders.
Iberia S.A., Spain's national airline, which holds 24 options on MD-80's, converted seven of them into orders for MD-87's.
Aviacion y Comercio S.A., the national domestic airline, converted five MD-80 options to orders for MD-88's.

LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  A fundamental remaking of the savings industry was quickly set in motion as President Bush signed legislation intended to end years of staggering losses.
Mr.
Bush expressed pride in the bill passed by Congress early Saturday, saying it would ''put in place permanent reforms.'' The law calls for outlays of $166 billion over 10 years to close and merge insolvent institutions, and many more billions after that.

A Yankee Dinosaur Called Rags
LEAD: Behind the left-center field fence in Yankee Stadium there is kept on the bullpen bench a dinosaur, in pinstripes.
Depending on your sightline, he may be seen directly beyond one of the retired numbers on the row of painted baseballs on the fence, behind either No. 4 (Gehrig), 3 (Ruth), 5 (DiMaggio), 7 (Mantle), 37 (Stengel) a pair of 8's (Berra and Dickey), 16 (Ford), 15 (Munson), 32 (Howard), 9 (Maris), 10 (Rizzuto), or 1 (Martin).


2 Shutouts in a Row Put Mets on Right Track
LEAD: Davey Johnson wouldn't exactly call it a drive or a comeback or a leap into the homestretch of a four-team race in the National League's East. ''More of a move in the right direction,'' he said. ''Everybody settling into a role, and carrying it off.''

A Hotel's Last Tenant Clings to Memories
LEAD: Over the 25 years in which the Brooklyn Arms changed from a residential hotel favored by retired judges and doctors to a densely packed shelter for homeless families, only one man, Leon Horniker, remained.
He stayed because he had work to do: he was writing scholarly articles on his specialties, Ottoman-Turkish diplomatics and Turkish warriors in the Middle


Close to Home
LEAD: THE first of the fall catalogues has arrived.
Normally, I would have tossed it in the wastebasket, as I do most catalogues, and felt guilty about not having paid just a little bit of attention.
All that work on the part of stylists, copywriters and photographers buried under coffee grounds and shrimp shells: ah, the waste.

Woman Who Left Baby in Jet Gets 6 Months
LEAD: A woman was sentenced today to six months in jail for abandoning her newborn daughter in the bathroom of a jetliner.


Corrections
LEAD: An article and an illustration in Science Times on July 18 about tree planting to reduce global warming misstated part of the process in which trees absorb carbon dioxide and give off oxygen.
The oxygen comes from the water taken in by trees.
It is produced by photolysis, the light-induced splitting of water molecules.

LEAD: The Leucadia National Corporation said it and the Brae Corporation had agreed to sell their railcar-leasing businesses and Brae agreed to sell its railcar-management business to the General Electric Company for $178.5 million in cash, plus about $4 million in lease obligations.

Realty Trust Bid Dropped
LEAD: The Income Opportunity Realty Trust and two pension funds in Detroit said they had signed an agreement to end the funds' hostile takeover bid for the trust and to settle lawsuits between them.


Michaels Stores To Be Acquired
LEAD: Michaels Stores Inc., a retail chain specializing in materials for home decorating and crafts, has agreed to be acquired for about $130 million by a company formed to take it private.
Under the accord, the holders of Michaels' nine million common shares will receive $9.50 a share in cash and $2.50 in liquidation value of preferred stock in the acquiring company, MSI Holdings Inc.

Pierce Jr., according to internal H.U.D.

Iavaroni to Play in Italy
LEAD: Marc Iavaroni, a forward with the Utah Jazz, will play basketball in Italy next season.


Cuba Plans to Try Rights Workers for Slander
LEAD: The Cuban Government said today that it was taking steps to prosecute the country's most prominent human rights worker and two others on charges of spreading false information.


Bilingual Union Ads
LEAD: The AFL-CIO said yesterday that its first bilingual advertising campaign would begin on Sept. 14.
The Spanish and English television ads, which will continue to employ the labor movement's ''Union Yes'' slogan, will feature the actor Edward James Olmos.
The premier ad, in Spanish, will be broadcast on NBC's English-language ''Cosby Show.


Margaret Batts Tobin, Arts Philanthropist, 91
LEAD: Margaret Batts Tobin, a longtime board member of the Metropolitan Opera, died of bone cancer last Thursday in San Antonio, her hometown.
She was 91 years old.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Allied Security Inc., Pittsburgh, said that a special committee of directors had rejected a management buyout proposal at $53 a share and that company officials were considering whether to raise the bid.


Unresolved Issues
LEAD:  Jurisdiction A Federal judge ruled July 31 that Rose's lawsuit against Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti belongs in Federal court in Columbus, Ohio, where Giamatti wants it, and not state court in Cincinnati, where Rose wants it.
On Tuesday, Rose's lawyers filed an appeal of that ruling with the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati.


U.S. Envoy Robbed at Waldorf
LEAD: America's ambassador to Iceland and his wife were robbed at gunpoint yesterday in their Waldorf-Astoria Hotel suite of more than $35,000 in jewelry, the police said.
The ambassador, Nicholas Ruwe, 55 years, and his wife, Nancy, were not injured, said a police spokesman, Officer Joseph Gallagher.
The robber, dressed in a light gray suit, told the couple he was a hotel security guard when they opened the door at 12:45 P.M., Officer Gallagher said.


Father and Son Found Dead in Union Office
LEAD: Two officials of a longshoreman's union local, believed to be a father and son, were found shot to death this evening, the police said.


Residents Honor Slain Officer


Few Choices in Commodity Markets
LEAD: The scandal that led to the indictment last week of 46 commodity traders appears to have dealt a serious blow to the prestige of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
But it is unlikely to put much of a dent in their business.


San Francisco Bay Journal; One Man Organizes Pollution Patrol
LEAD: Michael Herz's 26-foot outboard cut through the morning fog as he searched through binoculars for anyone fouling his beloved San Francisco Bay.


Topics of The Times; The Game of the Name
LEAD: Say it ain't so, Joe.
Not Shoeless Joe Jackson of Black Sox fame, but Joe DiMaggio, the living, breathing, nice-guy hero of yesteryear's Yankees.
Joltin' Joe is not alone in taking money for his autograph, but his reported price of $30 per, is, well, jolting.
Among today's stars, the slugger-outfielder Jose Canseco of the Oakland A's and Cincinnati's Pete Rose get $15, the Red Sox's Cy Young award-winning pitcher Roger Clemens gets $9, and there are many more in that range.


Group Discloses EECO Discussions
LEAD: A group of Minnesota investors, who control 5.5 percent of EECO Inc., said it had held talks with the management of the computer-equipment manufacturer in the last year about a possible sale.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it intended ''to monitor closely EECO's operations and may seek, at some point in the future, a more active interest in the management of the company.

Lomas Financial's Bankers Unit Sold
LEAD: The Lomas Financial Corporation said it had completed the sale of its banking unit, the Lomas Bankers Corporation, to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch &amp; Company's private equity group for $435 million in cash and $65 million in 10-year redeemable preferred stock.
Under the agreement, Lomas Bankers, which has a credit card business with 1.7 million customers, will continue to operate as an independent financial services company with operations in Texas and

LEAD: Compagnie Industrielle will resist a $2.5 billion offer made by Compagnie Financiere de Suez, its president said today.


Modern Algerian Rhythms With Touches of the West
LEAD: New Yorkers had their first chance to hear the impassioned singing and heady rhythms of rai - West Algerian rock - when Cheb Mami performed Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s.
Rai arose in Oran, a port city, when musicians adapted traditional melodies to electronic instruments while letting in some Western musical influences.

At Least 85 Are Killed in Mexican Train Crash
LEAD: A Pacific coast train plunged off a bridge into a rain-swollen river in northwestern Mexico today, killing at least 85 people and injuring 107, an official involved in the search said.


Market Place; Buyout Corner Turned by Kroger
LEAD: LATE last year, the Kroger Company, one of America's largest supermarket operators, dodged a takeover attempt by the Dart Group and a leveraged buyout offer by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company by opting for a sweeping reorganization.
When the dust settled on what analysts called a public leveraged buyout, 35 percent of the company's shares were in the hands of its employees, the dividend payment that had been made regularly since 1902 was discontinued and the company's debt jumped from $600 million to $4.7 billion.

Summer of the Booboisie
LEAD: Mencken!
Thou should'st be living at this hour. (With apologies to W. Wordsworth.) Through the 1920's and 30's H. L. Mencken savaged the follies of American life.
His special targets were the narrow minds, the intolerant certainties of what he called ''the booboisie.'' He reveled scornfully in the trial of John Scopes for teaching evolution, describing the onlookers - who believed that God literally created the world in six days - as ''gaping primates.

LEAD: A disappointing auction of 10-year notes sent prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds lower yesterday, and dealers questioned whether interest rates would have to move still higher to generate demand for the $9.75 billion worth of 30-year bonds to be sold today.

Swiss Computer Fails
LEAD: Dealers at Switzerland's fully automated options and futures exchange have gone back to doing deals by telephone because their $40 million computer system has failed. ''All our experts are working flat out to solve the problem.
We don't know how long it will take,'' said Otto Naegeli, director of the Swiss Options and Financial Futures Exchange.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 463 money market mutual funds increased $1.24 billion, to $338.35 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased $954.00 million, to $86.53 billion.
At the 227 general-purpose funds, assets were up $676.80 million, to $107 billion.

A Time for Compromise in Poland
LEAD: Solidarity says it will try to topple Prime Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak's Cabinet later this month.
It is openly competing for the votes of the Peasant party - once the Communists' docile satellite, but today a decisive swing bloc.

Appearances deceive.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company said it would lay off 120 employees in the catalogue unit of its Merchandise Group and 104 workers at a telemarketing operation in Downers Grove, Ill.

LEAD: Two futures traders pleaded guilty today to making fraudulent deals and committing other violations in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Swiss franc pit.
Another Swiss franc trader pleaded not guilty to racketeering charges.

No on Shoeless Joe
LEAD: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti has turned down a request to consider reinstating Shoeless Joe Jackson to major league baseball, saying he did not ''wish to play God with history.'' Jackson, who died in 1951, had a .356 career batting average, but was one of eight Chicago White Sox players banned from baseball for their part in the 1919 ''Black Sox Scandal.

Man Held in Writer's Death
LEAD: A man wanted in the death of a television writer was arrested in New York City Wednesday night on an unrelated drug charge, the police said today.
The man, John Doherty, 27 years old, of Jersey City, is charged with felony murder and first-degree robbery in the death of the writer, Robert Stevens, 68 years old, of New York City, who was robbed and beaten early Monday in a Westport home he had rented, the police said.


Polish Prelate Assails Protests By Jews at Auschwitz Convent
LEAD: Expressing bitterness over recent Jewish protests, the Cardinal who oversees the diocese that includes the site of the Auschwitz death camp announced today that he was abandoning plans to construct a center for Christian-Jewish dialogue near the site.

Industries, department officials said yesterday.

Jet Kickers Don't Fret About Getting the Boot

Restaurants
LEAD:  The Odeon  **  145 West Broadway, at Thomas Street, 233-0507.
Ambiance: No-frills Art Deco cafeteria; lively late-night scene.
Service: Young, friendly and competent staff.
Recommended dishes: Cornmeal-coated calamari, tuna and lentil salad, fennel and white bean salad, cold black-bean soup, steak au poivre, grilled flank steak, roast chicken and mashed potatoes, grilled salmon with tomato and basil, grilled mahi-mahi, apple tart, profiteroles, coffee parfait.


Concentration of AIDS Cases Posing Serious Problem for Some Hospitals
LEAD: The nation's AIDS cases are concentrated in selected hospitals in major cities throughout the country, causing serious financial losses, forcing reduced care and threatening to crowd out other patients in those hospitals, a new study shows.

Nintendo Plans Network System
LEAD: Nintendo of America Inc. has set up a unit to develop its Nintendo Entertainment System as a home computer terminal for services like news, home banking, and long-distance video game playing.
It wants to have an entertainment and informational network on the market in 1990.
Nintendo said Jerry Ruttenbur, a senior vice president with Home Box Office's video division, was named vice president of network products.

Trash Hauler And Relative Killed on L.I.
LEAD: A garbage hauler who assisted in investigations of organized-crime involvement in Long Island's garbage-collection industry was killed, along with his brother-in-law, in their company offices early this morning, the authorities said.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Guide Decision
LEAD: TV Guide concluded its search for a publisher yesterday by not hiring anyone.
The position has been vacant since April, when Valerie B. Salembier left the Rupert Murdoch-owned magazine to become the president of The New York Post.
Joseph W. Cece, TV Guides's president, said that he and Mary Berner, the magazine's advertising director, will take on the duties customarily assumed by a magazine publisher.

Soldier, Leader, Black American
LEAD: America's armed forces face a different but no less daunting task today than they did after the Vietnam War.
Then, military leaders had to restore respect for the uniform after a war for which they took an unfair public pounding.
Now, they need to shape a new strategy to fit a complicated strategic environment in a time of declining budgets.

A.B.A. Dons Aloha Shirts and Eats Macadamia Nuts in its Annual Flirtation with Frivolity
LEAD: The American Bar Association could hold its annual meeting in Shangri-la - or Beirut, for that matter -and some things wouldn't change.
There would still be the office-seekers, the glad-handers, the networkers working the crowds.
There would be the awards ceremonies and the cocktail parties, the parliamentary debates and the prayer breakfasts.


Review/Art; Some Masterly Work of Microcosmic Stature
LEAD: One of the rewards of high summer in midtown is ''Miniature Environments'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, just across from Grand Central Terminal.
As the title indicates, the objects on view are small.
Just over 30 of them have been got into the little room, and almost everything in the show asks to be looked at as a watchmaker looks at a watch - at close quarters and with eyes alert.

LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average traded above its record high yesterday afternoon before settling back to close at 2,712.63.
That was its second-highest close, following the 2,722.42 it reached on Aug. 25, 1987.


LTV Says Its Net Fell 75% in Second Quarter
LEAD: The LTV Corporation, the struggling steel giant now entering its third year of reorganization, said today that its net income fell by 75 percent, to $30.3 million, for the second quarter that ended on June 30.

LEAD: New Jersey's efforts to clean up an illegal dump that was piling trash under Interstate 78 were frustrated in Federal and state courts for two years, first by the dump operator's filing for bankruptcy and, last spring, by a state court's decision that the Chief Justice of the state today called a ''serious judicial error.

Bridgehampton Group
LEAD: The resident ensemble of the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival is to perform at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tonight at 9 o'clock.
Among the performers are Ani Kavafian and Carmit Zori, violinists; Fred Sherry and Ronald Thomas, cellists; Marya Martin, flutist; Nancy Allen, harpist, and David Shifrin, clarinetist.


New Forensics Lab Joins War on Wildlife Crime
LEAD: A new laboratory here in the dusty foothills of southern Oregon is applying forensic analysis to solving a growing number of crimes involving endangered species.


Ravitch Details Efforts to Help The City's Poor
LEAD: The inner city, once a ''staging ground for upward mobility,'' has become a wasteland for thousands of New Yorkers trapped in a cycle of poverty, despair and crime, Richard Ravitch, a Democratic mayoral candidate, said yesterday.
Breaking that cycle, he added, is a key to the city's future.


Estonia Prohibits Further Strikes By Russians Protesting New Law
LEAD: The Estonian authorities reacted firmly today against angry Russians complaining of discrimination and banned further protest strikes as a threat to the Baltic republic's economy.


Japanese Report Confession Of Man in Slaying of Girl, 5
LEAD: The Tokyo police said today that a 26-year-old man had confessed to the kidnapping and slaying of a 5-year-old girl in June and that the man could be linked to other killings of girls that have shocked Japan.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about New York City's effort to restrict the space reserved by those attending concerts on the Great Lawn in Central Park misstated the policy of the city's Parks and Recreation Department.
It no longer confiscates blankets or bedspreads left unattended on the lawn before the concerts.


Alcohol Gauged In Toran Death
LEAD: Stacey Toran, safety for the Los Angeles Raiders, had a blood-alcohol level more than three times the legal limit when he was killed in an automobile accident Saturday night, the Los Angeles County coroner's office said today.


How Big East Threatens Civilization
LEAD: It was clear that American civilization was doomed when they showed the film clip a few months back.
The Vice President of the United States, off on one of his educational field trips, stopped to shoot hoops at a military base.


Exchange's Fines Raised
LEAD: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to increase the fining authority of the exchange's directors to $250,000 for each violation, from $75,000.
The move is the latest effort by the exchange's membership to strengthen public confidence in the board after the indictment of 46 commodity traders here last week.


MOSCOW WILL PAY ITS OWN FARMERS IN FOREIGN MONEY
LEAD: In a novel attempt to slash grain imports and increase domestic harvests, the Soviet Government announced today that it would begin paying farmers in foreign currency for part of their crops.

LEAD: The issue posed by the killing of Maria Hernandez in Brooklyn on Tuesday is stark and basic: Who will control the neighborhoods of New York City, the police and law-abiding citizens or drug dealers and their armed enforcers?

LEAD: It may be that Red Grooms, past and present master of the rollicking walk-in environmental cartoon, is a better artist in two dimensions than in three.
This is one idea to be gleaned from the artist's print retrospective, a traveling exhibition currently at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

LEAD: Theodore Kaghan, a former Foreign Service officer and journalist, died of heart failure Wednesday at Brattleboro (Vt.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 77 years old and lived in Brattleboro.

LEAD: Federal investigators from Washington have been sent to Denver to look into the failure of the tail engine of a Northwest Airlines DC-10 on Wednesday evening.

LEAD: A lawyer for Leona M. Helmsley in her tax-evasion trial is expected to oversee tax prosecutions at the Justice Department, sources in the department said today.
The lawyer, James A. Bruton 3d, is the choice of the head of the tax division, Shirley Peterson, to run the criminal-tax section, the sources added.

COMPANY NEWS
LEAD: *
Banponce Corp., San Juan, P.R., is continuing to evaluate the unsolicited $50-a-share merger proposal made by Banco Popular de Puerto Rico.
Banponce's board also authorized an increase in the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share, from 37.5 cents, payable Sept. 29, to holders of record Sept. 14.


Shakespeare in Park Becoming Less Free
LEAD: To the Editor:


Mood in China: Hope Gains on Fear
LEAD: China's jails brim with ''counterrevolutionaries,'' and its airwaves are full of calls for greater faith in Communism.
But so far the worst fears of the democracy campaigners of early June have not come to pass, and there seems to be somewhat greater hope among them these days.


Missouri Fetus Unlawfully Jailed, Suit Says
LEAD: A Missouri law restricting abortions has been used by a pregnant inmate to file two lawsuits against the state for what she contends is the illegal imprisonment of her fetus.

Namibia Rebels Say Pretoria Is Rigging November Election
LEAD: Charging that South Africa is interfering in the preparations for Namibian independence, the South-West Africa People's Organization, the territory's leading nationalist movement, warned today that it might not accept the results of Namibia's first free elections.


Goldin Offers a Plan to Cut New York City's Income Tax
LEAD: Saying it was time to recognize that New Yorkers feel ''overtaxed and underserviced,'' the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, yesterday unveiled a plan to cut the city's income tax by more than $100 million a year.


Sentences in Steroid Case
LEAD: Three former South Carolina assistant football coaches were sentenced today for their convictions stemming from the use and distribution of steroids within the athletic department.
Their sentences ranged from three months to six months in a halfway house.


3 Metropolitan Airports to Bar Noisy Night Flights
LEAD: In a major step toward easing the din of jets around New York City's three major airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that starting Jan. 1 it would begin phasing out flights between midnight and 6 A.M. by a whole generation of noisy aircraft.


MAI Allows Offer For Prime to End
LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. said it had allowed its $525 million bid for Prime Computer Corporation's minicomputer business to expire, leaving a friendly bid from J. H. Whitney &amp; Company as the only offer on the table.
MAI, based in Tustin, Calif., first began its bid in November 1988.
Whitney has offered cash and stock worth about $1.22 billion, or $18.50 a share, for the company.


Tambrands Stock Rises on Rumors
LEAD: Shares of Tambrands Inc. rose $3.25 yesterday, to $71.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, on rumors that the company, a maker of feminine hygiene products, is a takeover target.
Tambrands officials declined to comment.
The columnist Dan Dorfman in USA Today said Centaur Partners, a New York investor group, had acquired 3 percent of Tambrands.

Melanson Joins Devils
LEAD: The Devils, with a surplus of young goaltenders, added a veteran yesterday when they signed Roland Melanson as a free agent without compensation.
Melanson, 29 years old, who broke into the National Hockey League with the Islanders in 1981, played briefly last season with the Los Angeles Kings.
He has a 3.65 goals-against average for 281 regular-season games.

LEAD: An agreement was reached today between the court-appointed guardian for the artist Willem de Kooning, who is 85 years old and has Alzheimer's disease, and a lawyer for the artist's 33-year-old daughter, Lisa, that would allow the daughter and the de Kooning family lawyer, John L. Eastman, to be named conservators of the artist's assets at a court hearing next week.

Chase Medical Trading
LEAD: Trading in Chase Medical Group resumed yesterday, with more than 50,000 shares changing hands over the counter at prices of $4 to $6.50 each.
The south Florida medical centers chain, whose shares were the subject of an alleged corner, had last traded officially on Jan. 12, at $13 a share.
The American Stock Exchange delisted the stock on Wednesday.

Review/Music; Donizetti's 'Anna Bolena' Is Revived by City Opera
LEAD: Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena'' belongs as much to modern history as to the age into which it was born.
The composer wrote it for the Teatro Carcano in Milan where the opera had its premiere in 1830.
Giuditta Pasta sang the title role.

LEAD: An Agriculture Department report projecting smaller corn and soybean harvests than grain traders had expected is likely to bolster futures prices, ending a monthlong decline in the markets for those commodities, analysts said yesterday.

LEAD: New York City's next mayor may confront huge budget gaps, some of the most daunting social problems in decades and a local economy that is no longer generating substantial new tax revenue.
All of this, warns Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, might make the fiscal crisis of the 70's seem ''benign.


Auctions
LEAD: It has, of course, been a while since baseball cards were simply ephemera for boys to trade and mothers to throw away during surreptitious cleaning sprees.
With a 1909 Honus Wagner selling recently for $110,000 - hear that, Mom? - and with professional collectors taking over what used to be a children's pastime, individual baseball cards have come to be worth more than many players earned during their entire careers.


Preborn Children or Blastocysts?
LEAD: Mary Sue Davis wants to have a baby.
But since 1979, when she married Junior Lewis Davis, she has suffered several ectopic pregnancies, a ruptured fallopian tube and the tying off of the second.
She and Mr.
Davis have participated in an in vitro fertilization program too, but the implantation of two out of nine fertilized eggs was unsuccessful.


Kelly Uneasy at the Center of Debate
LEAD: Playing as the center fielder for the Yankees isn't easy.
Surviving as center of the latest controversy for the Yankees is plain scary.


Corrections
LEAD: A Man in the News article yesterday about Gen.
Colin L. Powell misstated the source of his Army commission.
General Powell was already commissioned as a second lieutenant, through the Reserve Officer Training Corps program at City College in New York, when he went to Fort Benning, Ga.
There he attended officer courses at the United States Army Infantry

LEAD: Trevor Pinnock is to lead an orchestra of period instruments in an all-Vivaldi program at Mostly Mozart on Sunday at 7:30 P.M.
The program includes ''The Four Seasons'' - with Simon Standage, the concertmaster of Mr.
Pinnock's English Concert ensemble, as violin soloist - and the Gloria in D (RV 589).


22 Die in Beirut in Artillery Duels
LEAD: At least 22 people were killed and 140 wounded today in artillery duels between Syrian gunners and the Christian units of Gen.
Michel Aoun, officials said.
The police said the barrage began at 11 A.M. and lasted until dark, with artillery shells and rockets falling on Beirut at a rate as high as 40 a minute.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court has set aside a decision that had cleared T. Boone Pickens's investment group of violating securities and racketeering laws in its attempt to acquire the Phillips Petroleum Company five years ago.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I am ready to help free the Western hostages provided Western countries help release Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners in Israel.''  - Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah of the Party of God.  [ 1:3. ]


PANAMA URGES U.N. TO SEND OBSERVERS
LEAD: The Panamanian regime of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega asked the Security Council today to send observers to monitor what it called its growing military confrontation with the United States.


Letter: On Medicaid; The Poor Need Access to Prenatal Care
LEAD: To the Editor:


Producer Prices Fell 0.4% in July
LEAD: In another sign of slowing inflation, the Labor Department announced yesterday that producer prices fell four-tenths of a percent in July.


No Boom on Wall St. for Printers
LEAD: While the stock market reaches new highs, the crash of 1987 is still taking its toll on the financial printing business.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about negotiations between New York City hospitals and their workers misidentified a Federal agency that refused to block a strike next week.
It is the Office of the General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, not the National Labor Relations Council.


Doing Battle Amid the Fog of Statistics
LEAD: At one point in yesterday's mayoral debate, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin took an aerosol spray can from his lectern and shot gray mist into the air.


Reid Is Leader in P.G.A. Championship
LEAD: Ponce de Leon was looking in the wrong place.
The Fountain of Youth is at Kemper Lakes Golf Course, just northwest of Chicago, where the 71st P.G.A.
Championship is in progress.


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 46.


Power to 30 Houses Doubles And All Appliances Burn Out
LEAD: Videocassette recorders started smoking, light bulbs exploded and ceiling fans raced as if they were going into orbit when a power company mistakenly doubled the normal amount of electricity in 30 houses.


Pay Cut Is Accepted By Detroit Symphony
LEAD: To keep the orchestra alive, musicians for the Detroit Symphony voted, 82 to 8, on Wednesday to take a pay cut of nearly 10 percent in a four-year contract.


Abbott Labs President Resigns
LEAD: Jack W. Schuler, the president and chief operating officer of Abbott Laboratories, resigned yesterday over ''differences in philosophy'' with Robert A. Schoellhorn, Abbott's chairman and chief executive, a spokesman for the $5 billion diversified health-care concern said.


No Help For Viola In Debut At Shea
LEAD: The Mets produced no runs and a grand total of three singles in Frank Viola's Shea Stadium debut last night, and the result was a 3-0 loss to the St.
Louis Cardinals.


Party of God Mentor Offers Help In Promoting a Trade of Captives
LEAD: The spiritual leader of pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims believed to be holding hostages in Lebanon said today that he would help free the captives if Western countries used their influence to obtain the release of Arab prisoners in Israel.


Giants Prepare to Run Through the Motions
LEAD: Do not expect anything fancy Saturday night when the Giants open their preseason campaign by playing the New England Patriots in Sullivan Stadium.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Angio-Medical Corp., a maker of intravascular and related products, said it might have to curtail the scope of its operations because of expected losses.
The company also said that its license agreement with Helene Curtis Industries Inc., Chicago, a holding company, was being terminated because Helene Curtis did not introduce Angio-Medical's hair products as required.


Bishops Map Strategy in Abortion Battle
LEAD: Calling the recent Supreme Court decision on abortion ''the beginning of a new debate,'' a committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops has drawn up a broad strategy for abortion opponents.


The Case of the Littered Pianos
LEAD: Steinway tries to run an upright piano factory, but a pack of alley cats who have been using the factory at nights for their own catty purposes are sounding a sour note.

Xoma In Pact To Acquire Ingene
LEAD: The Xoma Corporation, a biotechnology company in Berkeley, Calif., agreed to acquire International Genetic Engineering Inc., more commonly known as Ingene.
Each of Ingene's 7.9 million shares would be exchanged for 0.278 shares of Xoma stock, giving the transaction a value of about $40 million.
Xoma specializes in monoclonal antibody technology and has applied for permission to market two drugs: one for treatment of septic shock received from hospital infections and the other for graft-versus-host disease, which strikes recipients of bone marrow transplants.


Orioles, Red Sox Win One Apiece
LEAD: Roger Clemens, limited to 11 pitches in his previous start, threw 123 this time, allowing three hits in seven innings tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 6-4, in the first game of a doubleheader.
Baltimore won the second game, 4-1, behind a three-hitter by Pete Harnisch, his first complete game ever.


Larger Farms, but Fewer of Them
LEAD: The United States has slightly fewer farms this year than in 1988, but they are slightly larger than they were last year.
The Agriculture Department estimated the number of farms at 2.17 million.
That is a drop of 1.1 percent from 1988, when the department said there were 2.19 million farms.
The decline continues a slide that began in 1982, when there were 2.4 million farms.


2 Days in Office, Japan's Leader Defuses a Potential Sex Scandal
LEAD: Two days after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu became momentarily entangled today in a report that he had fathered a child outside marriage.
But he later appeared to free himself of the rumors and avoid a sex scandal like the one that dogged his predecessor.


Dinkins TV Ad Criticizes Koch On High-Rises
LEAD: David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign yesterday fired an unexpected shot in its opening round of television commericials, with a 30-second spot that accuses Mayor Edward I. Koch of favoring high-rise luxury apartment buildings at the expense of affordable housing.


Simms Went From Top To Bottom
LEAD: A sublime pleasure of spectator sports is counting other people's money.
Nowhere does it matter so much to the watchers what the doers are earning than in sports.


Homeless Respond to Aid at Terminal
LEAD: A five-day experiment to help the homeless in Grand Central Terminal has resulted in 169 people agreeing either to go to shelters or into drug or alcohol treatment programs, transit and social service officials said yesterday.


Steeplechase Leader Is Dead
LEAD: Census, an 11-year-old gelding who had earned more money than any other steeplechaser, suffered a fatal heart attack today during a morning workout at Saratoga Race Track.


Auschwitz, the Poles and the Jews; Shared Losses
LEAD: To the Editor:


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe Trounces Witsken: Second-seeded John McEnroe lost only 12 points on his serve to defeat Todd Witsken, 6-1, 6-0, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the United States hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis.
The eighth-seeded Witsken, from Carmel, Ind., lasted just 69 minutes.
Earlier, fourth-seeded Aaron Krickstein beat Pete Sampras, 7-5, 6-3.


Pilot Accord At Northwest
LEAD: Northwest Airlines has reached tentative agreement on a long-term contract covering its 5,000 pilots, it was announced today.


Pillsbury Unit Sale
LEAD: The Pillsbury Company said it had agreed to sell its Van de Kamp Frozen Seafoods division to the Whitman Corporation for about $140 million in cash.
The transaction is expected to be completed by mid-September, it said in a statement.
Van de Kamp has annual sales of more than $100 million.
The statement gave no further details.


Voyager 2 Finds Rings at Neptune (But Not All the Way Around It)
LEAD: In its first major discovery at Neptune, the Voyager 2 spacecraft yesterday detected two partial rings of debris around the planet, providing the first direct evidence that Neptune has rings and that they are strikingly different from those of any other planet.


'Killing Fields' Draws Crowds in Cambodia
LEAD: Thousands of Cambodians have thronged to see ''The Killing Fields,'' the film that brought to Western screens the horror of life under the Khmer Rouge, since its premiere in Phnom Penh a week ago, an American relief worker reports.


Jewish Groups Angered By Rappers' New Start
LEAD: Jewish groups responded angrily yesterday to the announcement by the rap group Public Enemy that it was rehiring Richard (Professor Griff) Griffin.


The Pentagon's Farewell to NASA
LEAD: The space shuttle Columbia is now in orbit on a military mission, said to be the deployment of a KH-12 reconnaissance satellite.
But it's one of the last military missions the shuttle will fly.


3 in Officer's Shooting Face Attempted Murder Counts
LEAD: Three men were charged yesterday in the shooting of an undercover narcotics officer Thursday in a vacant Bronx apartment during a drug deal that went bad.


RETAIL SALES SHOW UNEXPECTED SURGE FOR LAST 3 MONTHS
LEAD: In a report that shows the economy has been considerably stronger than had been thought, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales surged by nine-tenths of 1 percent in July and were also buoyant in the late spring and early summer.


Actuary Resigns Amid Tax Inquiry
LEAD: New York City's highest-paid official, its chief actuary, resigned yesterday rather than testify under oath and give city investigators permission to examine his official income-tax records amid an inquiry that found he failed to file returns on time, city officials said.


Mother Nature, the Pest Killer
LEAD: Concern for the environment is making steady inroads on the use of chemicals in the battle against garden pests and plant diseases.


Francois Colos, Illustrator, 60
LEAD: Francois Colos, an illustrator whose work appeared in many publications, died of encephalitis Wednesday at New York Hospital.
He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.


A Phone Card in Braille
LEAD: U S Sprint Communications Company has introduced a Braille version of its calling card, making long-distance credit service easier for people who are blind or partly blind.


William J. Prater Is Dead at 70; In Prison for Yablonski Killings
LEAD: William J. Prater, a former official of the United Mine Workers serving life sentences for his role in the slayings of a union dissident and his family, died in his cell today, apparently of natural causes, officials said.
He was 70 years old.


Yankees' 18 Hits Overwhelm Twins
LEAD: The Yankees came into tonight's game looking for a strong pitching performance from Walt Terrell and some consistent offense.
They got both and whipped the Minnesota Twins, 11-3, at the Metrodome.
