Savings Withdrawals Rise
LEAD: Net deposit withdrawals at the nation's savings and loan institutions more than doubled in June, to $4.6 billion, the Government said today.


Dollar Surges Despite Effort By Central Banks to Stall It
LEAD: The dollar surged yesterday, prompting a concerted round of central bank intervention that was unable to stall the rally.


Anchor Glass
LEAD: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation urged shareholders not to take any action on a $280 million tender offer by a subsidiary of Vitro Sociedad Anonima, until a special board committee announces its findings by Aug. 23.
The offer is for up to 13.9 million Anchor shares at $20 each.
Vitro Sociedad, a glass maker based in Monterrey, Mexico, is making its bid through a subsidiary, the THR Corporation.


No 'Public Giveaway' in 42d St. Redevelopment
LEAD: To the Editor:


Central Park Victim Learns Fundamentals of a New Life
LEAD: There is not much time for sadness at Gaylord Hospital.
Each of the 121 men and women being treated at this medical rehabilitation center has survived a traumatic event: a stroke, a car accident, a fall, a shooting or, in the case of one patient, the Central Park jogger, rape and a beating.
Now they must somehow rebuild their lives.


Bridge; World Junior Championships Prove A Double Success For the British Hosts
LEAD: The second World Junior Championships ended yesterday in Nottingham, England, and proved a double success for the host country.
The first world bridge championship ever to be played in Britain was excellently organized, and the British team captured the title, defeating Argentina in the 96-deal final by 90 imps.

About New York; Nervous Rookie Ready for Debut In Peale's Pulpit
LEAD: Billy Hester was 4 years old when his father died in their hometown of Savannah, Ga.
He ached and ached but knew boys aren't supposed to show it.
So Billy would sit alone staring at his father's sports trophies.
And when he went to the barber, he presented a dogeared photo he otherwise kept hidden.


A New Mood, at Least, on Civil Rights
LEAD: Given their differences over the failed nomination of William Lucas and the Supreme Court's recent civil rights decisions, President Bush's speech to the National Urban League could have been a tense, awkward occasion.
Instead, the atmosphere was one of mutual ease and respect.


Review/Theater; Growing Menace, Without Words
LEAD: Learning is what ''No + (No More)'' is all about, but who - including the audience - learns what, is anybody's guess.
Taking his inspiration from ''The Students Want to Teach,'' a short story about role reversal by the Austrian writer Peter Handke, the Chilean playwright Raul Osorio has created a wordless play that repeatedly tempts a viewer into imagining he knows what is going on and then makes him question his own judgment.

New Hampshire Utility Is Near Bankruptcy Pact
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday told the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy that it was nearing an agreement that would allow it to satisfy the demands of its creditors and equity holders.


Sandra L. Read Marries in Aspen

Col.
Foley, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs.
Foley of Durham, N.C.

DEFAULTS ON LOANS TO STUDENTS DROP
LEAD: The Education Department has reported that defaults on student loans have declined.


Reed Moves From Bench to Front Office
LEAD: After a season and a half as head coach of the hapless Nets, Willis Reed abruptly relinquished the position at the request of the team's owners yesterday and accepted a long-term contract as a club vice president.


Koch Is Lone Voice in Debate For Tax Rise to Add Police
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch was the lone candidate prepared to support higher city taxes at a debate among the four Democratic contenders yesterday.
He defended his plan to use the revenues to add 4,000 police officers.


The Basics of School Reform
LEAD: The economic and social health of New York in the year 2000 and beyond depends on the ability of the school system to educate today's youngsters.
But while the mayoral candidates are talking about education, they remain preoccupied with how quickly or slowly the search for a new schools chancellor ought to proceed and, more generally, with how to make the 20-year-old decentralized system work better.

LEAD: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, the Avenue of the Americas between 44th and 59th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 12:30 P.M. to about 3:30 P.M.

Dow Retreats From Record Territory
LEAD: After advancing to a record high in the first hour of trading, stocks bounced downward following a precipitous decline in bond prices.
Heavy futures-related selling also helped puncture several attempts to rebound.


Second Stealth Test Planned
LEAD: The Stealth bomber is scheduled to make its second test flight in California in the next few days, the Air Force announced today.
The first test flight, on July 17, was a success, but the House voted the next week to order a reduction of the 132-plane program.
The Senate approved most of the request for the bomber but also passed a resolution saying it was not committed to the fleet now planned.


Dump Owners Arrested After Huge Fire
LEAD: The owners of Hub Recycling Inc. were arrested today on charges stemming from the trash fire under Interstate 78 that buckled part of the elevated highway on Monday.


Israelis Lengthen Detention For Arabs Held in Uprising
LEAD: The Defense Ministry issued an order today extending the period that Palestinians can be held in detention without formal charges or a trial from six months to a year.

LEAD: Lincoln Center has presented a good deal of contemporary music in its free Out-of-Doors series, but until this year it had not commissioned new works for it.

Lucas Named to Justice Job; Search On to Fill Rights Post
LEAD: William C. Lucas, whose nomination to be the nation's top civil rights enforcer was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee, was named today as Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's ''personal representative'' to law-enforcement groups, civil rights groups and state and local governments.


AMR Revises Takeover Guards
LEAD: Directors of the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, strengthened the company's anti-takeover provisions even though the company said it was unaware of any imminent takeover attempt.
Under the amended plan, if a person or group buys 10 percent or more of AMR's outstanding common shares, stockholders would be entitled to buy additional shares at half price.

Vincent P. Mallon, Missionary, 79
LEAD: The Rev.
Vincent P. Mallon, a Maryknoll missionary and teacher, died from complications of kidney disease Aug. 4 at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y.
He was 79 years old and lived in Maryknoll, N.Y.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company and Fine Homes International Limited Partnership announced yesterday that they have agreed to sell Merrill Lynch Realty, Merrill Lynch Relocation Management, and some related businesses to the Prudential Insurance Company of America for more than $300 million.


Harvey Publications Sold
LEAD: Harvey Publications Inc., which owns the rights to a number of cartoon and comic book characters including Casper, the Friendly Ghost, has been sold for an undisclosed price.
The family-owned concern, which publishes comic books and has a library of 248 film cartoons from the 1950's and 1960's, is being sold to HMH Communications Inc.

Patents; A New Material For Metal Sculptures

Hollywood's Truly Golden Oldies

The movie in 35th place is celebrating its 50th anniversary.

LEAD: Representative Mickey Leland's staff accused the State and Defense Departments today of not doing enough to find the Congressman, whose plane was reported missing in Ethiopia on Monday, and urged President Bush to give it his personal attention.


MAI Basic Expects a Loss
LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. said today that it expects to report a ''significant'' third-quarter loss because of write-offs associated with its abandoned tender offer for Prime Computer Inc.
In addition, the company said it was restructuring and would cut 10 percent of its work force in the next three months.


Family of 5 Dies in Blaze
LEAD: A fire started in a garage and spread through a wood-frame house early today, killing a family of five as neighbors frantically pounded on doors and honked car horns to alert them, the authorities said.
The victims were Bill Fullerton, 51 years old, his wife, Marylyn, 42, and their children, Lori, 14, Justin, 10, and Curtis, 3, said the Lawrence County Sheriff's Department.


Corrections
LEAD: A television review on Thursday about ''The Rivals'' on the Arts &amp; Entertainment channel gave an incorrect figure, provided by the show's producers, for the time allotted to commercials.
The commercials in the 2 1/2-hour program amounted to 28 minutes, not 45.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page on Aug. 4 about Mollie Orshansky, an economist who developed the index known as the poverty line, misidentified a Federal agency.
It is the Wage Stabilization Board, not the Weight Stabilization Board.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation today priced its 1990 cars 3.4 percent higher than its 1989 models, with nine-tenths of 1 percent of the increase covering the cost of new passive restraints required by the Government.

Afghan Rebels, Divided but Resolute, Fight On From Peak Above Jalalabad
LEAD: From a rebel bunker on Samarkhel Mountain, the ancient city of Jalalabad is visible eight miles away, a sprawl of mud-walled homes shimmering beneath a canopy of flame trees that stretch to the horizon.
But a line of the Government's Soviet-built tanks sits in the plateau between the city and the rebels, their barrels trained on the enemy's redoubts.

LEAD: A group of prominent Americans concluding a weeklong visit to Namibia said today that they had found ''major obstacles'' to the free and fair elections scheduled in November as part of the territory's transition to self-rule.

LEAD: Gord Stellick, who at 32 became the youngest general manager in National Hockey League history when he was appointed in April 1988, announced his resignation from the Toronto Maple Leafs yesterday.

Patents; Reducing Wood Stove Pollutants
LEAD: It may not be true that trees cause pollution, as former President Reagan once asserted.
But pollution certainly results when logs are burned in traditional wood stoves, which belch an average of 22 grams - three-quarters of an ounce - of particulate matter an hour.

Job Cuts Are Set By Smith Corona
LEAD: The Smith Corona Corporation said it would lay off 10 percent of its work force, or 450 workers, at its Cortland, N.Y. and Singapore plants by Aug. 28 in order to adjust portable-typewriter inventories and respond to softening domestic retail demand.
The company provided no further details.
Smith Corona is controlled by Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate.

Now he will take on another assignment at the school in Louisiana, vice president for athletic relations.
Joseph Johnson, the university president, said Robinson had requested the move.

LEAD: A court sentenced a primary-school teacher to life in prison today for splattering paint on the huge portrait of Mao that hangs above Tiananmen Gate in central Beijing.
The teacher's accomplices were given terms of 16 and 20 years.

Patents; An Oral Contraceptive Without Estrogen
LEAD: Michael Cohen, scientific director of Applied Medical Research Ltd., a start-up company in Washington, patented a proposed oral contraceptive this week that the company believes could replace current birth control pills.


MUCH OF LEBANON POUNDED BY SHELLS
LEAD: In the worst round of fighting since a new wave of violence in Lebanon's civil war began five months ago, some 20,000 shells and rockets struck towns and villages across a third of the nation's area in fierce exchanges from Thursday afternoon until daybreak today.


F.D.A. Revokes Approvals At 2 Generic Drug Makers
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has revoked its approval of generic drugs made by two pharmaceutical companies, and an internal memorandum from the F.D.A.
Commissioner, Frank E. Young, implied that further disciplinary moves in the generic drug industry may soon be needed.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Corn on the Cob
LEAD: Now is the season for fresh local sweet corn.
Yellow, white and a mix of yellow and white are available.
Buy corn that has been picked the same day because the longer an ear of corn is off the stalk, the less sweet it will be; the sugar starts turning to starch as soon as it is picked.
Very fresh corn will have a dewy moistness about the husk and silk, and the stem will not be brown.


Automated Planes Raising Concerns
LEAD: Airlines are starting to fly a new generation of highly automated jets, raising concerns among safety researchers that pilots will rely too much on the technology and will lose or never learn the sharp skills and reflexes needed in emergencies.


Trade Surplus Of Japan Falls
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus declined 16.5 percent in July, to $5.99 billion, the Government announced today.


New Policies Critically Ill Collect On Life Insurance
LEAD: A new kind of life insurance, which pays part of the death benefits while the policy holder is still alive, is attracting attention these days.


Interlake Restructures To Fight a Takeover
LEAD: The Interlake Corporation, an industrial manufacturer fighting a takeover threat, today announced a restructuring under which it intends to pay a special dividend, sell operations and repurchase stock.
The restructuring is expected to cost the company at least $550 million.


Mira Trailovic, Director, 65
LEAD: Mira Trailovic, a Yugoslav theater director and founder of the Belgrade International Experimental Theater Festival, which invited many American theater groups to Europe, died of cancer on Monday in Belgrade.
She was 65 years old and lived in Belgrade.


Your Money; Is Small Investor Late for the Rally?
LEAD: Many small investors are wondering, now that the broad measures of the stock market are at their all-time highs and the Dow Jones industrial average is flirting with its August 1987 peak, if they, too, could realize profits in the stock market.


Krueger Is Moved
LEAD: Phil Krueger, the Indy-car driver who was severely injured Sunday when his car struck a wall in the CART Marlboro 500 race in Brooklyn, Mich., was transported yesterday by a private plane from St.
Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., to Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he was admitted to the neuro-critical care unit and pronounced in good condition.


Many Jets Are Missing As Play Begins Today
LEAD: The exhibition season starts for the Jets on Saturday, a day when fine-tuning under game conditions is supposed to begin.
And, everyone agrees, the Jets need all the time they can use.


Mental Exams Ordered
LEAD: Thomas P. Gioiosa, a former friend of Pete Rose who is awaiting trial on Federal cocaine-distribution and tax charges, was ordered yesterday to undergo two mental examinations next week.


Aide in Housing Deal Tells Of Link to Pierce's Ex-Firm
LEAD: A former Federal housing official promoted the use of Samuel R. Pierce Jr.'s old law firm in bond sales for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a former Paine Webber Inc. executive involved in the sales said today.


Nissan Workers in U.S. Test Union and Industry
LEAD: Workers at the Nissan automobile plant here were called in for overtime work on a recent Saturday to meet brisk orders for Sentra cars and Pathfinder trucks.
At the midday break that Saturday, about 1,000 workers who had been called in for the day shift were greeted by the sight of their supervisors grilling a hamburger lunch for everyone.

LEAD: This much is certain: Manford Byrd will be a finalist in the selection of Chicago's next superintendent of schools.


Organic Bean Crop Is Accidentally Sprayed
LEAD: A farmer who spent years developing organically grown beans saw his effort wasted when his field was accidentally sprayed with pesticides last month.

LEAD: The Seaman Furniture Company, the second-largest furniture retailer in the United States, said yesterday that it is having difficulty making interest and principal payments and is seeking a restructuring of its debt because of higher interest rates and particularly weak store sales in the New York City area.

LEAD: Edward Gordon has announced his retirement after 22 years as executive director of the Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill.
The 59-year-old Mr.
Gordon, a concert pianist, said he was leaving to pursue personal interests, including the piano, writing and traveling.
He will serve on the search committee for a successor, he said, and will remain in his post until a ''qualified successor can be engaged.

LEAD: The Solidarity-dominated Polish Senate today condemned the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and asserted that the armed forces of Poland took part against the will of the nation.

RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
LEAD: I do not consider myself a member of a Second Thoughts ''group.'' And if I have ''distanced'' myself from the activities of Peter Collier and David Horowitz, it was not because I preferred them ''to organize the grass roots'' rather than to remain ''an intellectual current.'' I simply found that I did not belong to that current as their actions and statements seemed to define it.


The Chalets Of Montana's Glacier Park
LEAD: WELL up in the mountains of Glacier National Park in Montana, not far from Sperry Glacier, a pair of weathered, fitted-stone structures cling to cliffs as gray as themselves.
Together they are Sperry Chalet, an outpost for visitors to the park that can be reached only on foot or horseback, offering an ideal alternative for the hiker not wishing to be encumbered with provisions, cooking equipment, sleeping bag or tent.


CAMPUS LIFE: Utah; Burning of Flag Leads to Fight And Court Case
LEAD: A former vice president of the student body at the University of Utah who took part in the burning of an American flag has accused a Vietnam veteran of assault.
The veteran, Dale H. Osborne, was found to be carrying a loaded .38-caliber revolver.


Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
LEAD: It is difficult to determine to what extent the Yankees' losing record and poor pitching can be attributed to Dallas Green.
But it is incomprehensible to have Roberto Kelly, with the team's highest batting averge as well as its highest on-base percentage, bat ninth.
Surely, a .330 hitter batting further up in the lineup will have more at bats and, therefore, increase his team's run production.

LEAD: I HAD just turned 22 that eventful summer of 1969.
My husband, 20-month-old son and I were living with my parents in their summer home on Kauneonga Lake, in Bethel, N.Y.

Chimney, Fireplace Checkup
LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces.
But if you neglected the task this year or have not examined these items within the last 12 months, you should do so before fall to make sure they are in safe working condition before the next heating season begins.


Father Confesses to Killing His 4 Children
LEAD: A man has confessed that he intentionally crashed his family's car through a barrier and into the Detroit River to kill his wife and children, the police said on Friday.
All four children drowned.

Domestic Architecture in Yonkers
LEAD: A DOCUMENTARY composed of photographs, maps, diagramatic drawings and books, ''Yonkers Architecture'' at the Hudson River Museum, sounds like parochial ''filler.'' THE BOXER THE CHAMPS WON'T FIGHT
LEAD: IN A SPANKING NEW GYM IN VAN NUYS, Calif., Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, is working the heavy bag.
A left-handed fighter, Nunn sets, plants and throws the big hook, then skips back nimbly to repeat it from a different angle.
With each punch, his eyes light up, the brows arching, much in the manner of Muhammad Ali, to whose legendary ring style his own is often compared.

FICTION
LEAD:  HORTENSE IS ABDUCTED.
By Jacques Roubaud.
Translated by Dominic Di Bernardi. (Dalkey Archive, $19.95.) A dark Parisian night, an eerie mansion, midnight bells.
A shot rings out and a life ends.
A conventional detective story?
No, no, a significant 37 times no.
Although ''Hortense Is Abducted'' is a mystery with a plot literally as intricate as a sestina, its real fascination lies in Jacques Roubaud's conversational asides, inside jokes and self-referential word play.


Skitch Henderson in an Informal Recital
LEAD: WHEN pianists come to Merryall Center, the performance hall on the banks on the West Aspetuck River in New Milford, they perform on a Steinway grand borrowed for the season from one of the center's neighbors, the conductor Skitch Henderson.
On Saturday, Mr.
Henderson and his piano will be reunited for ''An Evening With Skitch Henderson,'' as he plays and reminisces about his life as concert performer, television performer, symphony conductor and New York

LEAD: Despite the efforts of Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, Stewart International Airport will remain without the services of American Airlines for the foreseeable future.


Brian De Palma Explores Vietnam and Its Victims
LEAD: At some point in their careers, most top motion-picture directors turn to the broad canvas of war, a subject that has within it the elements - action, character and conflict - that make for commercially successful, sometimes even estimable, films.
With his 19th movie, ''Casualties of War,'' scheduled to open Friday, Brian De Palma at last brings his sanguineous style to the battlefield.


For South Africa, a Diplomatic Riddle
LEAD: A potential diplomatic breakthrough from South Africa's regional isolation has set off a debilitating new crisis in the governing National Party three and a half weeks before national elections.


PASTIMES: Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Plant crops for fall harvest: seedlings of broccoli, cabbage and kale plus seed for rows of spinach, mache, peas, beets and leaf lettuce.
Transplant azaleas, rhododendrons, abelias, hollies and conifers.
Pinch back overgrown petunias for rebloom in early fall.
Remove faded flowers of geraniums to prevent disease.

Outdoors; Duck Limits Likely to Stay
LEAD: Breeding populations of ducks in prime nesting areas of this country and Canada were at near-record lows this spring, and the Fish and Wildlife Service's proposed regulations for the forthcoming 1989-90 waterfowl seasons are much the same as last year's regulations, which included fewer days in which to hunt and lower bag limits.

LEAD: In August, partygoers in Saratoga run almost as fast as the horses.

ITALY: Where Connections Unlock the Till
LEAD: Censorship, in the form of a government official telling artists what they may or may not do, is not an issue in Italy.
But it hardly means that politics and the arts are not intertwined.
This is a country where party connections determine who becomes the doorkeeper at a government ministry, and the same principle applies to public funds for the arts.

LEAD: ''Titus Andronicus,'' the young William Shakespeare's violent drama of murder and revenge in ancient Rome, features rape, mutilation, ritual sacrifice, decapitation and family cannibalism.
Throats are cut, hands and a tongue removed and sons served to their mother in a pie.

McGauley, the hands-on chief for more than a decade, sparked upheaval and defections by dismissing a top executive a year ago.

With all the search and indexing devices available on modern VCR's, such haphazard hunting isn't necessary.

Advertising Mail: People Really Want It
LEAD: In response to a letter in the Long Island Weekly of July 16, 1989, regarding receiving too much advertising mail, I realize the frustration with having to discard unwanted mail, especially with Long Island facing serious disposal problems.
The courts have held that censoring or otherwise refusing to deliver such mail is beyond the authority granted to the Postal Service by Congress.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Bittner Captures Slalom: Armin Bittner of West Germany clocked the fastest time in the first run and held on for the victory yesterday in a World Cup slalom race at the Australian resort of Thredbo.
Bittner, 24 years old, the defending World Cup slalom champion, clocked 1 minute 2.52 seconds in the first run over a 74-gate course with a 205-foot vertical drop, and 59.41 seconds in the second, with 72 gates.

POSTINGS: An Ice Storm Casualty; Restoring a 1680's Tidal Grist Mill
LEAD: When a group of people from Lynn, Mass. - led by a woman named Nan Heatherton - settled on Long Island's North Shore in the 1680's, one of their first tasks after planting crops was to erect a mill to grind their grain.
At what came to be known as Mad Nan's Neck, now called Saddle Rock, the settlers dammed a pond adjoining Little Neck Bay and built a tidal grist mill.

LEAD: As a collectible, the fish decoy has surfaced.

LEAD: The Detroit mayoral race, usually a yawner easily won by the city's longtime Mayor, Coleman A. Young, has turned into a bitter contest pitting the Mayor against a former ally, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan.

The $6 Million Man
LEAD: Larry Bird, who missed most of last season after foot surgery, will become the first athlete in any team sport to earn more than $6 million in a year, sources told The Associated Press yesterday.


PASTIMES: Gardening; An Update on Caring for the Lawn
LEAD: This has been an unusual year for lawns.
Spring started out dry and there were dire predictions of drought.
Then the rains came, and more rains, and cool growing weather.
This turn of events was followed by an unusual summer, which so far, has had more than an adequate amount of rainfall.
In ordinary seasons, lawns go dormant and turn brown at this time of year, but the grass has remained green.


Relativism and the American Way
LEAD: To the Editor:


RADICAL TRANSFROMATIONS
LEAD: Sharon Churcher writes that once a young Communist, I am ''now a historian intent on exposing leftist bias in the college curriculum.'' As a lifelong opponent of McCarthyism of both the right and the left, I believe firmly in academic freedom, faculty autonomy and the right of scholars of differing persuasions to have complete freedom in determining course curriculum.


The Beginning of Something Big
LEAD: A few years ago, a friend and I were ambling down the main street of an English town in Oxfordshire called Woodstock.
A microbus with Belgian plates pulled up, and the driver poked his head out the window to ask, ''Excuse me, do you know where ze festival was?'' I told him he was on the wrong side of the Atlantic; luckily for him, he drove off before I could add that I'd been at the festival.

Walter Steiger's low, thick heels now have rounded edges and a thin coating of gold.
Diego Della Valle sticks to the classics, and Giorgio Armani puts softening touches on tailored styles.

Anti-Pollution Campaigns Declare War on Old Cars
LEAD: EIGHT Northeastern states said last week that they would join California in a plan to clean up the nation's dirtiest air.
The strategy is not only aimed at tightening emission standards for cars rolling off the assembly lines.
In an attempt to put the squeeze on the country's two largest pollution sources -the Los Angeles basin and the Northeastern megalopolis - officials on both coasts are turning their attention to a problem that had gone largely unregulated: old cars.

THE MIDWEST: Kings Island - Kings Island, Ohio
LEAD: Each year, millions of visitors brave the Beast at Kings Island in Ohio.
And brave they need to be.
This entire wooden coaster is secluded - hidden from the rest of the park by dense, towering trees and rugged terrain that cuts off views from one part of the ride to the next.
The result: You never know until the last minute what surprises await you.

Homeless Enabled to Vote
LEAD: To insure the voting rights of the homeless, Maine has adopted a policy allowing people to register to vote even if they have no residence other than a park bench. ''To the best of our knowledge, Maine is the only state to handle it in this manner'' without pressure from the courts, said Richard Pinner of the New York-based National Coalition for the Homeless.


As Pitch in Opera Rises, So Does Debate
LEAD: A LITTLE-KNOWN New Jersey opera company is playing an active role in an international debate to lower the reference pitch by which orchestras tune their instruments.
The issue is that the reference pitch, the tone A, has gradually risen over the last 200 years and the consequences may be severe for performers and instruments.

Grenade Attacks in Guatemala
LEAD: Terrorists hurled grenades in three separate attacks around Guatemala City, killing a woman on a bus and injured eight other passengers in one attack, the authorities said today.
The other explosions damaged buildings but caused no casualties.
The police said they had not determined who had carried out the attacks.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  STEVIE SMITH: A Biography.
By Frances Spalding. (Norton, $19.95.) ''Stevie Smith is an unusually difficult subject for biography.'' So begins this book by Frances Spalding, the British biographer of Roger Fry and Vanessa Bell.
The problem is that there is not much to go on: days spent as a secretary in London, evenings eked out in a household of spinsters in a suburb so outer it was virtually outre.

ABROAD AT HOME
LEAD: On a street corner in a poor neighborhood of New York, a 12-year-old boy sits on a milk crate and sells crack.
His mother stands by, patting his head.
Other boys, as young as 7, 8 and 9, hang out nearby.
They have most of the crack to be sold, so the 12-year-old will not be caught with it in his possession.

THE WEST: Knott's Berry Farm - Buena Park, California
LEAD: When Cordelia Knott served her first chicken dinner to paying guests at Knott's Berry Farm in 1934, she and her husband, Walter, could not have realized that 55 years later guests would follow the dinner by being zipped from 0 to 55 miles an hour in Montezooma's Revenge or by piloting their own cockpit in the new XK-1 airplane ride.


A Palladian Journey in Vicenza
LEAD: PALLADIO himself could not have designed a better view of the subtle symmetry of his 16th-century Villa La Rotonda than from a four-seater plane high in the sky above the province of Vicenza in northeastern Italy.
La Rotonda, the architect's most celebrated building, appears as a giant crab grasping its Berici hillock at its highest and most logical point.

Patricia Shiland: Unconventional Portraitist
LEAD: Patricia Shiland calls them ''miniature life-style portraits,'' and although the name may not immediately evoke an image, that's exactly what they are.
The finished product is framed, protected by glass and hung on a wall, but instead of a painting or drawing it's a three-dimensional portrayal of an individual in miniatures that reflect the person's style of living.

FICTION
LEAD:  IN EXTREMIS: And Other Alaskan Stories.
By Jean Anderson. (Plover/Talman, $16.95.) The Alaska of Jean Anderson's first collection of short stories is a magical place whose remoteness and harshness make its inhabitants' emotions and relationships stand out in great relief.
Many of the characters in ''In Extremis'' discover this truth only after having fled other, seemingly more complicated lives in states such as Texas or California, Ohio or Michigan.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  THE FRONTIER OF LOYALTY: Political Exiles in the Age of the Nation-State.
By Yossi Shain. (Wesleyan University, $25.95.) Political exiles are, arguably, the most passionately committed of all political dissidents.
Unlike members of a ''loyal opposition'' seeking political reform from within a nation's borders, or refugees who attempt to create a new life in a new country, political exiles are suspended in a kind of ideological limbo.


ISRAEL: Politics as Usual, But Not Over the Arts
LEAD: In Israel, where politics seems to be part of every issue, arts administrators and government officials say public support of the arts is free of political coloration.
That doesn't mean Israeli politicians are reluctant to criticize plays or exhibits that fail to suit their ideology.
And Israel does occasionally censor the arts, for what the government calls ''security reasons'' (though theater censorship has been abolished for a two-year trial period).

AIDS-Test Rules In 29 Countries
LEAD: THE State Department issued on July 25 a list of 29 countries requiring, or planning to require, evidence of tests for HIV, the AIDS virus, from some or all visitors.
The list is based on inquiries sent to United States embassies around the world.
Michael M. Mahoney, the director of the State Department's Citizens Emergency Center, said that the list was prepared because many travelers had asked the department for information about countries' requirements; it will be brought up to date on a regular basis, he said.

POSTINGS: Bursting the Seams; Chinatown Condos
LEAD: A growing demand for housing in New York City's Chinatown is pushing the neighborhood north and west.
The Mandarin Plaza condominium apartment project is the latest example of this trend fostered by the increase in the number of Asians.
Developers of the 25-story building at 378 Broadway, which also faces White Street and Cortland Alley, said they have already sold half of the 164 units, mainly to Asians who have either moved to the United States or plan to do so soon.

A Congenial Chinese Newcomer
LEAD: CHINESE restaurants have traditionally offered good value for families dining out.
Even today, when restaurant prices are steadily rising, this continues to be true, as Uncle Dai's, a new Chinese restaurant in downtown Stamford, demonstrates.
Uncle Dai's does not put a lot of emphasis on decor.
A few pictures, a lacquered screen masking flowers do their bit to dress up a long, drag storefront with red plastic chairs and booths and matching carpet.

Review/Music; Seattle Opera Pulls All the Stops Out On a New 'Meistersinger' Production
LEAD: New productions of ''Die Meistersinger'' remain scarce even in a time when radically rethought stagings of Wagner's most formidable music drama, the ''Ring,'' no longer qualify as rarities.
A comedy on a distinctly Wagnerian scale, it deals at marathon length in heavyweight, Breughel-like humor.
The work consumes more than five hours of an audience's time and can strain the resources of any opera company.

What sends them scurrying down the exit ramp is the sight of the Magnum's first hill - a stomach-churning, 20-story incline followed by a sheer, 60-degree drop that hurtles riders through the coaster's dips and curves at 70 miles an hour.

Some New Twists in Life Insurance
LEAD: Recent tax and demographic trends are changing the role of life insurance.
Traditionally, the insurance has provided family protection: in case of an untimely death, the proceeds help pay the rent, buy groceries, take care of college bills.
The need for such insurance was reduced or eliminated once the insured's children were grown.

Chicago Must Modernize or Perish
LEAD: Tension is running high at the Chicago futures exchanges.
So far, 46 traders have been charged with trading practices that the Federal Government says systematically robbed the trading public on a major scale.
More indictments are expected.
But in the midst of the turmoil, it is important not to lose sight of another crucial and more important challenge facing the Chicago exchanges - competing with foreign markets There is a major battle looming over who will control the international 24-hour market for futures and options contracts.

Question Box
LEAD:  Stealing Home  Q. An answer last week to a question about Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig's steals of home reported that Ty Cobb, with 50, and Max Carey, with 33, head the career list for this feat.
Where does Jackie Robinson rank?
A.
He placed ahead of Tinker and behind Evers once he got the chance to play in the major leagues.


West Germans to Shut Embassy in Budapest Today
LEAD: West Germany will close its embassy in Budapest on Monday because it is filled to capacity with more than 180 East Germans trying to emigrate to the West, the Foreign Ministry said today.

LEAD: As the latest of the college bowls to succumb to the trend toward corporate commercialism, the former Orange Bowl has been fastidious about giving its new title sponsor its corporate due.

Arson Blamed in a Fatal Fire
LEAD: Arson caused a fire in a rooming house last Tuesday in which three people died, investigators said today.

Tax Watch; Contractor Status Vs. Employee's
LEAD: SOME people are clearly employees: the secretary or manager who works when scheduled, uses the company's equipment at a company office and does what the boss says.
Others are clearly outside contractors: a consultant who agrees to do a task for company A one week and company B the next, setting his or her hours, hiring a staff and deciding on the methods and priorities for accomplishing a task.

Help the Homeless, and Win Votes
LEAD: As New York's homeless grow ever more visible and its citizens ever more irritated, New York's mayoral candidates grope ever more awkwardly for solutions.
But a plausible strategy for helping the most pitiful of the homeless - the mentally ill -is within easy reach of any candidate.
It requires expanding upon an existing city project that combines aggressive outreach with the development of cost-effective, humane new housing.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Vast sums of illegal drug profits are being clandestinely sent from the United States, hidden by electronic money transfers through computers and facsimile machines.
Although many U.S. banks are being used unwittingly in these transfers, estimated to total as much as $100 billion a year, at least two are under investigation to determine whether they knowingly assisted drug operations.

Arson Blamed in a Fatal Fire
LEAD: Arson caused a fire in a rooming house last Tuesday in which three people died, investigators said Sunday.
About 10 people representing local, state and Federal agencies met for two hours to discuss the fire and concluded that ''it was arson involving the use of an accelerant,'' like gasoline, said Howard Whitehead, Assistant District Attorney for Essex County.

Curse of the Coffin
LEAD: While digging recently in the ancient Assyrian city of Nimrud, Iraqi archeologists uncovered a stone chamber containing the coffins of two women accompanied by 55 pounds of gold jewelry.
Iraqi officials said the tomb bore inscriptions in cuneiform writing identifying the women as possibly the daughter and granddaughter of Sargon, ruler of the Assyrian empire in the 8th century B.C., the Associated Press reported.

P.
Leonardo Mascheroni, said his former employer, the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, refuses to grant him adequate access to his own research materials and findings.

Bridge
LEAD: Players who use conventions are not always as careful as they should be in giving explanations to the opposition.
If an opponent opens one no-trump and your partner bids two clubs, you should not respond to an inquiry by saying ''Landy.'' Your opponents may not wish to appear ignorant by inquiring further, or they may have a misconception.

LEAD: More than 30 minutes after tonight's game, Dave Righetti sat solemnly in the Yankees' clubhouse, staring blankly into his locker.
Righetti had just lost a two-run lead in the ninth inning.
The Yankees had just lost a 5-4 heartbreaker to the streaking Milwaukee Brewers at County Stadium.
And now Righetti, feeling the weight of the crushing defeat on his shoulders, was almost at a loss for words trying to explain what had happenned.

Rig Count Falls in Week
LEAD: After posting several increases in recent weeks, the number of oil and gas rigs exploring for oil in the United States declined by 16 last week, to 858, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
The rig count the week before stood at 874, a rise of four from the previous week.
In the last 11 weeks, the rig count has increased eight times.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday about the financial performance of the UAL Corporation, which owns United Airlines, referred incorrectly to the earnings figures shown, culminating in 1988 with $8.98 billion.
The figures are for revenue, not profit.

Business and Health; Efforts to Reduce Retiree Costs
LEAD: MANY companies are looking hard at their open-ended promises to pay for the health care of retired employees.
The total paid for retirees by all employers came to at least $9 billion in 1988, and some payouts are growing by 15 percent a year or more.


Rep. Larkin Smith, 45, Dies In Mississippi Plane Crash; Specialist on Drug Problem
LEAD: Representative Smith spent most of his life in law enforcement and emerged in his first seven months in Congress as a specialist on the drug problem.


Dollar's Rally Continues; Gold Prices Also Advance
LEAD: The dollar finished higher against important foreign currencies in brisk trading yesterday, extending last week's strong rally.


Review/Music; Two Make City Opera Debuts in 'Rigoletto'
LEAD: Four new singers have taken over principal roles in the New York City Opera's staging of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' since the production returned to the New York State Theater a few weeks ago.
Of the newcomers who were heard on Sunday afternoon, two were making their company debuts.

LEAD: It looks as if James (Buster) Douglas may be next in line for a shot at Mike Tyson.

Lobbyists, Unmasked
LEAD: Shaken by the confessions of well-connected lobbyists who made a bundle for housing developers, Congress has groped for ways to curb their excesses.
The Senate whisked a bill through, and the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, has endorsed it.
They're on the right track, but they could do much better if they're really serious.


Review/Art; Exploring Dadaism's Legacy As Words and Images Collide
LEAD: Long before the Dadaists, words played an integral role in the visual arts.
Inscriptions of one kind or another were carved into antique statues and monuments and texts accompanied everything from medieval panel paintings to Cubist collages.
But what happened between words and images early in this century was the replacement of description with confusion, order with chaos, edification with obfuscation.


Exchanges Set Options Study
LEAD: Three stock exchanges announced today that they would study the possibility of linking equity options markets electronically.

Justice White Blocks Desegregation Order
LEAD: Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court today blocked a Federal court order intended to desegregate Louisiana's 17 public colleges and universities.

Eugene R. Sullivan, Lawyer, 85
LEAD: Eugene R. Sullivan , a retired Wall Street lawyer, died after a long illness Sunday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y.
He was 85 years old.
Mr.
Sullivan, a graduate of Holy Cross College and Harvard Law School, was a partner in Fruehaff, Farrell, Sullivan &amp; Bryan.
He represented the Cities Service Company in the divestiture of its gas utilities, and then many of the utilities.


Bee Extract As Mite Bait
LEAD: FRENCH scientists have identified natural substances secreted by bee larvae that could be used as bait to trap parasitic mites.
The parasites have become a serious threat to honeybees in many parts of the world.

LEAD: Most lawyers involved in Eastern Airlines' five-month-old bankruptcy case have filed applications for fees, amounting to a total of $7.4 million.

LEAD: The Bush Administration sought today to minimize differences with the Federal Reserve, after the budget chief, Richard G. Darman, accused it of running unnecessarily big recession risks by keeping interest rates up.


Lilco to Make First Payout In Five Years

LEAD: SCIENTIFIC rivals in a bitter dispute over the extinction of the dinosaurs have agreed to a hammer-wielding showdown in the mountains of central Italy next month.


Pro Athlete Commits Suicide
LEAD: Ricky Berry, a forward with the Sacramento Kings and the club's top draft pick last year, shot himself in the head today and died at his suburban home after a quarrel with his wife, authorities said.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the ''Your Money'' column in Business Day on Aug. 5 misstated the extent to which some ''golden parachute'' payments would be affected by proposed Treasury regulations.
For executives whose companies are taken over, the proposals clarify which compensation counts as part of a ''golden parachute.

Estonian Leader Urges End to Strike by Russians
LEAD: The Communist Party leader of Estonia urged Russian workers today to end a six-day strike against a new residency law that bars recent immigrants to the republic from voting.
He called on the Russians to negotiate their differences with the Estonian authorities.


Kean Rejects License Plates
LEAD: Gov.
Thomas H. Kean today sent back to the Legislature a bill requiring reflectorized license plates, calling the proposed design ''ugly'' and saying the fee to cover costs of production was too small.
In his conditional veto of the license-plate bill, the Governor said the proposed 25 cents in added registration fees would be too little to pay for the new plates which are considered safer because they would be more visible.


Air Quality Bonds For Ohio Power
LEAD: A $50 million bond refunding by the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority was tentatively priced yesterday, through Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.

A First Step Toward Clean Racing
LEAD: rrPerhaps all the tough talk about drugs in horse racing at the Jockey Club's annual Round Table Conference here Sunday was only the usual hot air.
But it could have been a first step on an addict's road to recovery: an end to denial and an acknowledgment that a terrible problem does exist.

George Andreasen, 55, Orthodontics Inventor
LEAD: Dr.
George F. Andreasen, an orthodontist who introduced an alloy of nickel and titanium for use in arch wires to straighten teeth, died of multiple myeloma Friday at Mercy Hospital in Iowa City.
He was 55 years old and lived in Iowa City.

LEAD: As AIDS patients and their advocates go to the ends of the earth to obtain unapproved drugs, an approved drug that is already on the market has languished in neglect, even though it shows some signs of effectiveness in delaying the onset or progress of the disease.

Moscow Invites Wallenberg Relatives to Visit
LEAD: The Soviet Union has invited relatives of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared in Soviet-occupied territory near the end of World War II, to visit Moscow.
The invitation comes amid signs that the Kremlin may be ready to disclose the fate of the man credited with saving tens of thousands of


Metro Datelines; Living Will Measure Approved by Senate
LEAD: The State Senate narrowly approved a measure yesterday that would allow residents to say in advance whether they want life-sustaining medical treatment withheld if they become seriously ill and incapacitated.


Isolation of AIDS Prisoners Ends
LEAD: The state of Connecticut has agreed to stop segregating AIDS-infected inmates from the general prison population, settling a 1988 Federal lawsuit and establishing guidelines that could have nationwide impact.

Swimsuits Are Stars of Resort Shows
LEAD: Swimsuits turned out to be the stars of the showings of resort fashions.
The swimsuit specialists, including Gottex of Israel, which supplies stores like Saks Fifth Avenue, and Cole of California, which has been in the swimsuit business since 1925, presented collections of great variety.
Sportswear designers like Donna Karan and Louis Dell'Olio for Anne Klein produced styles of startling sophistication and direct simplicity.


A Musical Tribute to a Legend: Marian Anderson
LEAD: Braving threats of thunderstorms, some 2,500 concertgoers gathered here on the soggy lawns of the Charles Ives Center for the Arts tonight to pay tribute to an artist who became a legend: Marian Anderson.

Indians in Vermont Tribe Need No Licenses to Fish, Judge Rules
LEAD: A Vermont state judge ruled today that members of a small Indian tribe may fish without licenses because they were here before the state existed and never gave up their ''aboriginal'' rights to fish.

Review/Music; 'Joan of Arc at the Stake,' A Honegger Extravaganza
LEAD: If shared traits had been a test of membership, France's famous group of post-World War I composers would have been called Les Cinq, not Les Six.
Clear-eyed simplicity in the face of Romantic obfuscation was a common idea among Francis Poulenc, Darius Milhaud, Germaine Tailleferre, Georges Auric and Louis Durez.


Finally, a Guide for Voters
LEAD: In red, white, blue, English and Spanish, the first voter guide distributed by New York City was published yesterday.
The booklet, published after voters endorsed the idea in last year's election, includes information about the Sept. 12 primary election and sketches of the candidates.


Dinkins Offers Plan to Reduce Auto Emissions
LEAD: As passing cars, trucks and buses belched smoke into the air, David N. Dinkins stood on a Manhattan street corner yesterday and promised that if he is elected mayor he will begin cleaning up New York City's air by converting city-owned vehicles to run on compressed natural gas.


Dealers Will See New Ford Truck
LEAD: A new truck from the Ford Motor Company called the Explorer will be shown to dealers this week in advance of its formal introduction next spring, the general manager of the Ford division, Thomas Wagner, said.

MCI Gets Contract
LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said Montgomery Ward &amp; Company had awarded it a three-year, multimillion-dollar contract to provide a private communications network linking 400 Montgomery Ward stores, offices and distribution centers to its Chicago headquarters.
Montgomery Ward said it selected MCI after a six-month comparative test against other vendors and that it expected cost savings from the agreement.

Hospital Partners Makes Bid for HEI
LEAD: Hospital Partners, a limited partnership controlled by Dana F. McGinnis, a San Antonio broker, has offered to acquire the HEI Corporation for $4.25 a share in cash, or a total of $20.82 million.
In a letter to HEI, Hospital Partners said that the offer was subject to obtaining sufficient financing, negotiating a friendly agreement and receiving the approval of the company's shareholders.

LEAD: Prosecutors dropped rape and kidnapping charges against Gary Dotson today, 10 years after he was convicted on the basis of testimony later recanted by his accuser.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that based on preliminary estimates, operating results for its third quarter, ended July 31, would be below Wall Street analysts' forecasts.

Counterattack on Child Care
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Department of Defense comments on a child-care amendment approved 94 to 5 by the Senate on July 31.
A main provision of the amendment, sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, would require the Pentagon to more than double the amount it spends on operating child-care centers for the military by fiscal 1991.


Cutbacks at Harrods
LEAD: In a cost-cutting move, Harrods, the famous London department store, has eliminated the jobs of 15 senior managers, a company spokesman said.
Harrods, owned by House of Fraser P.L.C., said that high interest rates and strikes by public transport workers had resulted in lower sales. ''We looked at the management structure, which had become a little top heavy, and rationalized it,'' a Harrods spokesman, Michael Cole, said.


Shock Hazard Leads To Hair Dryer Recall
LEAD: Four companies voluntarily agreed to recall about 250,000 hair dryers that can cause electrocution when dropped into water even when they are not running, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

As an Urban Rite, Stoop-Sitting Endures
LEAD: The stoops along 46th Street in Manhattan between Ninth and Tenth Avenues satisfy a variety of interests.
Prostitutes primp on the stoops, making of them concrete dressing tables for their cosmetics.
Drunks nod off there, crack addicts get high and, often on these summer evenings, neighbors carry down pillows from their apartments to sit together on the stoop as neighbors did in the days before television eclipsed the show on the street.


Review/Television; The Mean Streets of Los Angeles, on NBC
LEAD: ''Gangs, Drugs and Cops,'' the NBC News special at 10 o'clock tonight, starts off with grimly familiar details of the murderous inclinations of youth gangs in south central Los Angeles.
We are told that an estimated 700 gangs with 70,000 members compete for turf on the basis of color and national origin - black, Mexican, Salvadoran, Vietnamese and young men from Tonga.


Astronomers Strain to Hear Voyager's Last, Weak Signals
LEAD: GROPING in the dim vastnes far from home, arthritic and partly deaf, feeble of voice and prone to memory lapses, the aging Voyager 2 is resolutely heading for a rendezvous next week with Neptune, its last planet of call at the edge of the solar system.

Real Estate
LEAD: IN the last few years, huge developments like the International Design Center of New York and the Citicorp office tower have been the driving force for the transformation of Long Island City from a manufacturing stronghold into a varied commercial district.
Many property owners have exploited their proximity to these projects by remodeling the neighborhood's factories and warehouses into offices and showrooms.

LEAD: P. W. Botha's resignation as President of South Africa merely advanced by a few weeks a transition ordained six months ago.
The important question now is whether F. W. de Klerk, sworn in yesterday as Acting President, will advance South Africa's transition from apartheid to democracy with protected minority rights.

LEAD: Several chemicals derived from blue-green algae have been found to be ''remarkably active'' against the AIDS virus in test-tube experiments, Federal scientists are reporting today.

Playing Sports Dosen't Lift Grades, Study Finds
LEAD: Although participating in high school athletics tends to keep student-athletes in school, leads them to participate in other extracurricular activities and makes them feel more popular than nonathletes, it has virtually no immediate effect on academic achievement for most minority-group students.
And it has even less impact on their later success in college and the work force.


New Tenor in 'Davidde'
LEAD: The tenor Frank Lopardo will replace Vinson Cole in the Mostly Mozart performance of ''Davidde Penitente'' next Tuesday and Wednesday.
Patricia Schuman, a soprano, is the other soloist.
Also on the all-Mozart program are Divertimento in D (K. 2251), and the Violin Concerto No. 4 in D with Midori as soloist.

Merrill in Gilt Cutback
LEAD: Merrill Lynch Europe Ltd. confirmed speculation today that it had stopped market-making in British Government bonds, which are known as gilts.

'Cocktail Hour' Is Closing
LEAD: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' a semi-autobiographical comedy by A. R. Gurney, will close on Sunday after the matinee at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street.
Directed by Jack O'Brien and starring Nancy Marchand, Burt Edwards, Holland Taylor and Richard Buckus, the play will have run for 15 previews and 351 regular performances.


Hoechst Profits Decline
LEAD: Hoechst A.G., the large West German chemical company, said today that its pretax profits in the second quarter slipped 1.8 percent, to 1.1 billion marks, or $565 million, after a 23 percent gain in the first quarter.
Hoechst said its profits were squeezed because it was unable to pass the entire rise in raw material costs on to consumers.

Saturday at St.
Anne's Catholic Church in Houston.

New Tools Aid Oil Hunt in U.S.
LEAD: Experts on energy thought for years that oil production in the United States would shrink to insignificant levels by the middle of the next century, making imports the nation's only meaningful supply.
Now they are finding that steady advances in the technology for finding oil from large but hard-to-reach reserves discovered years ago seem likely to stretch the nation's era of oil production, possibly well beyond the year 2100.

'Dry' Beers Flood Market: A Wave or a Mirage?
LEAD: ON television, in magazines and on the sides of city buses, the advertisements trumpet ''dry'' beer.
Dry beer was first produced in Japan in 1987, and then American, Canadian and European brewers got into the act.
At least 19 imported and domestic dry beers have been introduced in the United States in the last year or so, many just in time for the summer surge in beer drinking.

Criminals Would Clamor for Exile in Australia

WINE TALK
LEAD: The secret of great wine is selection.
When a famous chateau blends its wine each year, only the best batches are kept.
The rest used to be sold off to a negociant, or shipper, who would blend it with the discards of other chateaus and sell it under the name of the region the wine comes from: Margaux, St.-Julien, Pauillac.

LEAD: State park officials investigating a huge fraternity-sponsored party at Jones Beach last month that ended in violence say they have not been able to assign responsibility for the party to any one person or group.

LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly down for the week ended yesterday, as the slide in bank deposit rates entered its 15th week.

LEAD: The Administration's decision not to oppose the Dec. 8 deadline for disbanding the Nicaraguan contras offers hope for El Salvador.

In the Supermarket, a Long, Hard Search for Quality Produce
LEAD: ONE morning last month, at an hour when less compulsive souls on vacation are still asleep, four Americans armed themselves with large straw baskets and invaded the Marche Forville, the large central market in Cannes on the French Riviera.
Three hours later, after a shop-till-you-drop spree, they emerged, baskets brimming with spectacular produce.

LEAD: Glenn McCutchen, managing editor of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution since 1985, has been promoted to executive editor of the newspapers, they announced over the weekend.


Pandick Sells Unit
LEAD: Pandick Inc., a large financial printer, said it had agreed to sell its Pandick Technologies division to Pitney Bowes Inc..
Terms of the sale were not disclosed, but people close to the purchase said the Stamford, Conn., business supplies company would pay slightly less than $100 million.
Pandick, which was taken private in a $250 million leveraged buyout in December 1986, will use the the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt, said Anthony K.


Suicidally Stubborn in Beirut
LEAD: The unspeakably bad has become the unimaginably worse.
Fourteen years of civil war have killed more than 100,000 of tiny Lebanon's people, destroyed its economy and left its communities in ruins.
Now five months of artillery battles between Christian and Syrian forces have almost emptied Beirut of its 1.5 million residents.


Eastern Adds Flights and Many Discounts
LEAD: Eastern Airlines expanded its daily schedule yesterday to 390 flights, from 350, and announced that it would offer 602 daily flights beginning Sept. 7.
The airline also said it would sell tickets for at least half its seats at large discounts to fill the additional flights.

LEAD: A Brooklyn woman, Linda Jouet, 29 years old, has been indicted in the stabbing of a neighbor who often fought with drug dealers on his block andwhose wife was shot to death 10 days later, Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday.
Ms.
Jouet's husband, Raymond Gonzalez, 39, was charged last week with stabbing their next-door neighbor, Carlos Hernandez, in the arm during an argument on July 29.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error a diagram in some editions with an article in Science Times yesterday about the lunar eclipse tonight incorrectly described the path of the Moon through the shadow of the Earth.
To a viewer looking south, the Moon appears to move from left to right over the horizon.
During the eclipse tonight, the shadow of the Earth will also move from left to right, eventually overtaking and passing the Moon.


JARUZELSKI URGES A POLISH SUMMIT
LEAD: President Wojciech Jaruzelski called today for a meeting of Poland's leading forces to break a government deadlock.

Review/Film; An Uncouth Uncle Against the Suburban Grain
LEAD: Uncle Buck (John Candy) is the sort of character that no American suburb should be without.
Everything about him offends middle-class manners, fashions and aspirations.
Though his ancient automobile needs a muffler and travels around in its own permanent cloud of exhaust smoke, Uncle Buck is a breath of fresh air.


Black Resort in South Splits Over Developing
LEAD: Tucked among the condominium glitter of South Carolina's Grand Strand beach front, Atlantic Beach is an oddity: an enclave of small cottages, overgrown lots and 800 year-round residents, virtually all of them black, that has intentionally avoided development.


Algae Tides Make Adriatic Murkier
LEAD: Like a symptom of a hidden sickness, a vast plague of algae has spread over much of the Adriatic Sea, sullying some of Europe's finest beaches and killing marine life in this part of the Mediterranean.


Review/Music; A Vivaldi Treatment Without Kid Gloves
LEAD: The prolific Antonio Vivaldi has always had detractors who believe the old joke about his having written one concerto 500 times.
And now that classical radio stations are using Baroque music as all-purpose aural wallpaper, the composer's advocates find it even harder to persuade unreconstructed Romanticists that there is more to this music than pretty figuration.

EATING WELL
LEAD: AMERICANS are so used to seeing microwave ovens among the kitchen appliances that they give them little more thought than conventional ovens.
Yet microwave ovens pose safety problems that conventional ovens do not.


Wadkins and Watson on Ryder Team
LEAD: Tom Watson and Lanny Wadkins, a pair of 39-year-old pros with considerable Ryder Cup experience, were named to the United States Ryder Cup team today by their long-time friend and fellow touring pro, Raymond Floyd, who is the nonplaying captain of this year's squad.


New Tool for Chefs: Oils With Extras
LEAD: SOMETHING important is happening in luxury cooking.
For several years, chefs around the nation, responding to heightened concerns about health, have been experimenting with alternatives to butter-rich sauces.
Now, a small group of New York chefs is in the vanguard in using oils infused with a dazzling array of herbs and spices to create deep, rich flavors that beguile butter-shy diners.

LEAD: PERHAPS it should be called the case of the vanishing value.
Integrated Resources Inc., a syndicator of tax-shelter partnerships that sought to grow into a major financial services company, said yesterday that its financial condition was even worse than it had previously disclosed.

LEAD: Hundreds of people who wandered over the grassy pasture where the Woodstock music festival began 20 years ago today pointed out features of the terrain as if they were revisiting a historical battlefield.


Date Is Set for Hearing on North's Appeal
LEAD: Oliver L. North's appeal of his convictions in the Iran-Contra case will be heard on Feb. 6 before a three-member panel of judges.

ARCO Offers New Gasoline to Cut Up to 15% of Old Cars' Pollution
LEAD: In a first step in its strategy to make gasoline environmentally competitive with cleaner alternatives, ARCO announced today that it would replace leaded gasoline at its California pumps with a ''reformulated'' fuel that could cut pollution from cars manufactured before 1975 by as much as 15 percent.

Indiana Man Is Found Dead In a Truck Parked for 9 Days
LEAD: The body of a trucker has been found in the cab of a tractor-trailer that sat in a parking lot for nine days with its engine running.

History of 'Jimmies'
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Interco Names A New Chief
LEAD: Interco, the St.
Louis-based diversified company, said today that it had named Richard B. Loynd chief executive, replacing Harvey Saligman, who announced that he would retire next May.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''If the Soviet Union is to be competitive, we must hit the inside curveball.'' - Aleksei L. Nikolov, at the Soviet Union's first baseball stadium.  [ A1:6. ]


A Top Official Quits Turner
LEAD: Robert J. Wussler announced today that he would resign from Turner Broadcasting System Inc., after 10 years in which the senior executive vice president helped guide the international expansion of the cable television concern.

Review/Film; Arousing the Old Populism For a New Antiwar Protest
LEAD: ''Rude Awakening,'' opening today at the Embassy 3 and other theaters, is hapless but endearing, much like its principal characters.
They are a small group of 1960's flower children who come together in the 1980's, determined to reawaken the old populism that began as protest to the Vietnam War.

Executive Leaving ABC For a Post at CNN
LEAD: Pamela Hill, an executive at ABC News whose documentaries have won several broadcast journalism awards, said yesterday that she would leave ABC to head a new documentary unit for the Cable News Network.
At CNN, she will be a vice president and executive producer, titles she has held at ABC since 1979.


Alaska Sues 7 Oil Companies for Damages in Spill
LEAD: Alaska sued the Exxon Corporation and six other oil companies today, charging that they were negligent in failing to prevent the grounding of the Exxon Valdez and the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound.


Charles T. Coiner, 91, Ex-Art Chief at Ayer
LEAD: Charles T. Coiner, a painter and former art director of the N. W. Ayer Inc., advertising agency, died, apparently of natural causes, Sunday at home in Mechanicsville, Pa.
He was 91 years old.


Suitor Challenging Dunkin' E.S.O.P.
LEAD: The DD Acquisition Corporation said it would challenge Dunkin' Donuts Inc.'s employee stock ownership plan in the Delaware Chancery Court.
DD said that if the plan, which Dunkin' Donuts established as a takeover defense, is invalidated, it will raise its offer for the company, based in Randolph, Mass., to $45 a share from $43.


Nicaragua Will Release Up to 1,500 Contras
LEAD: In a broad new gesture of conciliation toward anti-Government rebels and their sympathizers, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that the Government would release up to 1,500 Nicaraguans who have been imprisoned for taking part in the contra war or supporting the rebels.


Better Uses for Our Money Than the Dubious B-2
LEAD: To the Editor:


Cable Group's Loss Widens
LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest operator and developer of cable television systems, today reported a second-quarter loss of $63.6 million, almost three times its loss of $21.9 million a year earlier.


Sports People: BASKETBALL; K. C. Jones Leaves Celtics to Join Sonics
LEAD: K. C. Jones, who spent 20 years with the Boston Celtics as a player, coach and administrator, resigned from the club's front office yesterday to join the Seattle SuperSonics as an assistant coach and basketball consultant.


Pro Bono
LEAD: BBDO Atlanta is creating a broadcast campaign for Literacy Action Inc., a nonprofit organization in Atlanta that teaches adults to read.


Lessons on Sparkle, From the Source
LEAD: New York's fledgling sparkling-wine industry, thirsty for expert technical advice, was given a short course by three specialists from the Champagne region of France and two from West Germany last week at the State University campus here.

MORE YOUTHS TAKE TOUGHER COURSES, STUDY FINDS
LEAD: The number of high school students taking advanced mathematics and science courses increased significantly from 1982 to 1987, the Educational Testing Service says.

LEAD: On July 27 and Aug. 3, I reported that the State Department had notified U.S. investigators into the Iran-contra diversion of new information: It had heard from Swiss officials that the unidentified recipient of $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei was a Swiss financier named Bruce Rappaport.

Captain Video Bringing Mike To Big City
LEAD: What the heck.
Roger Neilson has already coached for Bick's Pickles and for Harold Ballard, the ogre of Maple Leaf Gardens.
He might as well coach for the Rangers, too.


Agencies to Merge
LEAD: Gearon Hoffman, a Boston agency, and Conlon &amp; Nye in New York have said they will merge their accounts, names and futures at the end of August, creating a $40 million agency named Gearon Hoffman Conlon &amp; Nye.
Its accounts will include indigenous representatives of the agency's two home ports: the Boston Beer Company, brewer of Samuel Adams beer, and The Daily News in New York.


Better Uses for Our Money Than the Dubious B-2; Save Minds Instead
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Monday about indictments in a Brazilian stock scandal misstated the ensuing loss reported by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.
The company reported a loss of less than $4 million after taxes for the second quarter of this year from all activities involving Banco de Investimento Planibanc S.A., a Brazilian bank of which it owns 49 percent.

Eating to Beat the Band at Tanglewood
LEAD: AS the musicians of the Boston Symphony gather backstage at the Music Shed at Tanglewood in anticipation of the evening's concert, the curtain has already risen for Charles Voos, the chef at the Seranak Supper Club.


U.N. Council Calls for Cease-Fire And Arab Mediation in Lebanon
LEAD: The United Nations Security Council called for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon late Tuesday and urged the Arab League to resume mediation efforts it discontinued last month.


Furor Over Castro Foe's Fate Puts Bush on Spot in Miami
LEAD: When President Bush comes here Wednesday to campaign for a Republican Congressional candidate, he will find himself in the middle of a bitter debate that has split Miami and raised the issue of whether there is such a thing as a good terrorist.


Treasury Securities Move Higher
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in moderately active trading yesterday as dealers snapped up securities at yield levels they had not seen in weeks.


Discounts Spur Sales Of Vehicles
LEAD: Steep discounts aimed at clearing bloated inventories of 1989 models lifted sales of domestically made cars to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.9 million in early August, the strongest level in six months, the auto makers reported today.


Tim Richmond, 34, Auto Racer
LEAD: Tim Richmond, a former Indianapolis 500 rookie-of-the-year driver whose subsequent stock-car racing career was cut short by controversy and illness, died Sunday.
He was 34 years old.


New Yorker Defying British Is Seized in Ulster
LEAD: A New York lawyer who is a leading fund-raiser for Irish nationalists was arrested in Northern Ireland today after breaching a Government order banning him from Britain.

LEAD: Not all victories are created equal.

Handyman Charged in Killing
LEAD: A 21-year-old handyman was arrested yesterday in the murder of a Brooklyn woman whose neighbors delayed in reporting her screams to the police.
Franklin Rivera, of 165 West End Avenue in Brooklyn, was was charged with second-degree murder in the killing of 39-year-old Ruth Velez of 65 Amherst Street on Saturday, said Deputy Chief Francis X.


Artist Who Outraged Congress Lives Amid Christian Symbols
LEAD: ''There are dangers faced by artists who deal provocatively with religious symbols,'' said Andres Serrano, the photographer whose picture of a crucified Christ submerged in urine has helped set off probably the strongest Congressional attack on the National Endowment for the Arts in that agency's 25-year history.


Bid for Sea Containers Raised by $13 a Share
LEAD: Temple Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it had raised its unsolicited offer for Sea Containers Ltd., the cargo shipping company, to $63 a common share from $50.


Bach to Bach
LEAD: A new star of anthropomorphism has flashed across the heavens and unlike C3PO, R2D2 and other machines invested with human qualities, it is real.
Voyager 2, which left Earth 12 years and 2.8 billion miles ago, is nearing Neptune.
After so monumental a journey, it's understandable that people now refer to it as brave little


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., a computer graphics company, said General Business Investment Corp., had called off a merger in which General Business would have owned 58 percent of the combined company.


That Other Wine Country, Sonoma, Celebrates Itself
LEAD: Joy Sterling, who is a partner in Iron Horse Vineyards, was the high bidder on the Old-Timers Collection at the Sonoma County Wine Auction on Saturday.
She paid $820 for 13 bottles of California wine, many of which, in their heyday a half-century ago, probably sold for less than $1.


U.S. MOVES ON TRADE SCHOOL
LEAD: The Education Department, acting under new rules designed to crack down on student-loan abuses, has moved against the Wilfred American Educational Corporation, one of the nation's largest and oldest commercial school chains.


LOUIS THAYER, 82, SAFETY OFFICIAL
LEAD: Louis M. Thayer, who was a member of the National Transportation Safety Board for nine years after retiring as a rear admiral in the Coast Guard, died of a heart attack Aug. 9 at his home in St.
Augustine, Fla.
He was 82 years old and had lived in the Washington area for 25 years before moving to Florida last year.


Union Asks Pilots' Support in Bid for UAL
LEAD: Leaders of the pilots' union at United Airlines told its 7,000 members in a letter yesterday that they should prepare to participate in an attempt to take over the UAL Corporation, the airline's parent company.

TALKS APPEAR AT STALEMATE IN 2d DAY OF HOSPITAL STRIKE
LEAD: As thousands of hospital workers in metropolitan New York stayed away from their jobs yesterday on the second day of a planned three-day strike, management and labor appeared close to a total breakdown of their three- month-long negotiations.


HUDSON COUNTY IS TRANSFERRING INMATES TO TENTS
LEAD: Under a court order to ease overcrowding at its jail, Hudson County is to transfer 100 inmates Wednesday to New Jersey's newest correctional center: an encampment of Army tents in a field of mud in the Hackensack Meadowlands.


KOCH CAMPAIGN RETURNS $25,000 FROM BUILDER WHO GOT VARIANCE
LEAD: A real-estate developer's $25,000 loan to pay for Mayor Edward I. Koch's television commercials violated new campaign finance laws, and Mr.
Koch returned the money yesterday as one of his challengers, Richard Ravitch, denounced the loan.


Zahringer and Zabriski Tied for Met. Open Lead
LEAD: The 74th Met.
Open, the nation's second oldest district tournament, started its three-day event here today by breaking away from tradition.


WASHINGTON TALK: The Capital
LEAD: President Bush said something today that neither of his two immediate predecessors would have dared to say quite so bluntly.


INFORMATION TUG OF WAR: CONSUMERS VS. CREATORS
LEAD: The technological and information revolution, long considered an incalculable boon to scholarly research, is beginning to cause friction on campuses, as scholars, libraries and publishers are increasingly at odds over who owns information, who controls access to it and how much it costs.


Rudolf Nureyev, Actor and King
LEAD: The rehearsal pianist launches into the opening bars of ''Shall We Dance.'' Suddenly the actress who plays Anna, the English governess who is hired to tutor the crown prince of Siam in ''The King and I,'' coaxes the new actor playing the King into trying the polka.
The lip-biting monarch with two left feet takes a few tentative steps, then the two of them sweep off, circling the battered studio floor at a ferocious pace to the laughter, cheers and whistles of the other cast members.


Bush Endorses Strategy Outline For Drug Battle
LEAD: President Bush endorsed the outline of a national strategy to attack the drug problem today, placing more emphasis on local law enforcement and less on international drug trafficking.
He pledged to find money to pay for the program without raising taxes.


Time to Replace Spofford
LEAD: New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice has prepared a sensible plan to replace the inaccessible, inadequate Spofford juvenile detention center with two smaller, better designed facilities.
The plan deserves the Board of Estimate's backing.
There is broad agreement on the merits.
Juvenile Justice managers find Spofford poorly designed - long walks between dormitories and dining hall, for example, require a heavy investment in supervision, and program space is limited.

LEAD: Bill Fitch, the former coach of the Houston Rockets, can reportedly take over the Nets' coaching position if he wants the job.


Rising Worry on 'Partner' Benefits
LEAD: Employers have begun to worry about the potential costs of health benefits sought by employees for people they live with outside marriage.

Review/Theater; Shakespeare, Surreal and in Spanish
LEAD: When it is set in a Caribbean city William Shakespeare may never have heard of, in a future not even this age has reached and in a language that is not English, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' runs considerable risk of turning into a nightmare.
Well, the National Theater of the Dominican Republic has done all this with the Bard's comedy and, far from rudely awakening, the company has created an adaptation that sails amusingly along in its own Spanish dreamboat.

Bridge
LEAD: In one matter of bidding style, there is a wide gulf between European and North American experts.
On this side of the Atlantic, the strong jump shift is rarely used and is sometimes shelved altogether in favor of the weak jump shift.
In Britain, the bid is used freely to suggest slam possibilities, and it helped British players reach the final of the World Women's Team Olympiad in Venice last

LEAD: The Soviet Union has notified the Red Cross that it has ratified the two 1977 protocols to the Geneva Convention.
