Fund Yields Edge Higher
LEAD: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report edged up for the week ended yesterday, as a result of economic reports and large government security sales last week.


GENERAL MINORU GENDA, 84, DIES: PLANNED ATTACK ON PEARL HARBOR
LEAD: General Minoru Genda, who planned the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died of heart disease in a Tokyo hospital Tuesday on the 44th anniversary of the end of the World War II.
He would have been 85 years old yesterday.


L.I. Bank Challenging Part of Savings Bailout
LEAD: A savings bank has challenged the provisions of the legislation signed last week by President Bush that impose tougher capital requirements on savings associations, asserting that the new rules violate contracts it signed with Federal agencies.


6 OF 13 PROSECUTORS RESIGN FROM A FEDERAL CRIME UNIT IN BROOKLYN
LEAD: Six of 13 remaining prosecutors in the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force in Brooklyn announced yesterday that they were resigning.


Trade Delay In Toronto
LEAD: The biggest computer failure in at least 12 years delayed most trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange for three hours today.


Tultex Stock Rises
LEAD: The share price of the Tultex Corporation jumped $2 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $12.25, in response to takeover rumors.
Officials of Tultex, a textile company based in Martinsville, Va., said that they did not know why the stock was rising but that the company was not for sale. ''We plan to paddle our own canoe,'' said Don Shook, the company's vice president.

GAUGE CUTS SHORT NEW STEALTH TEST
LEAD: The second test flight of the B-2 Stealth bomber was cut short today because of a low oil-pressure reading, the Air Force said.


Bite the Bullet Wins the Sanford
LEAD: On July 7 at Belmont Park, a pair of unheralded 2-year-olds named Graf and Bite the Bullet made their debuts and finished first and second in that order in a $22,000 maiden race.
Yesterday, in the $91,200 Sanford Stakes, they met again, and this time the order of finish was reversed.

Americans Trail in Walker Cup
LEAD: A dozen amateur golfers from Britain and Ireland threatened today to make it a clean sweep of the three oldest international golf trophies when they took a surprising 7 1/2-4 1/2 lead on the first day of the Walker Cup competition at the hot and humid Peachtree Golf Club.


New York Medicaid to Limit Number of Visits to Doctors
LEAD: In an effort to control rising Medicaid costs, New York State plans this fall to set annual limits on doctor and laboratory visits and prescriptions for its 2.3 million Medicaid recipients.


Egypt's Useful Smoke
LEAD: To contemplate the prospects for an Israeli-Palestinian peace is to sink into sadness.
Every avenue to negotiations seems too complicated or too risky.
No approach pans out.
In April, Prime Minister Shamir of Israel sketched out a plan with a measure of plausibility.
The idea was to hold elections on the West Bank and Gaza Strip to establish limited Palestinian self-rule.

Kathleen Maguire, Actress, 64
LEAD: Kathleen Maguire, an actress who won an Obie Award in 1958 for her performance in ''The Time of the Cuckoo,'' died of cancer of the esophagus on Aug. 9 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.
She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

An Investor Group Buys Fleer Corp.
LEAD: The Fleer Corporation, the 104-year-old maker of baseball cards and Dubble Bubble gum, has been acquired by a group of New York investors, its chairman and chief executive, Frank M. Mustin, said today.
The deal, completed Friday, was made through a new company formed by Charterhouse Group International Inc., a New York company that specializes in leveraged buyouts.


Fischbach Corp.
LEAD: The Fischbach Corporation said it had been informed by counsel for FAC Acquisition Inc. that the financing for the previously announced merger of the two companies would not be available.
Fischbach was the second-largest percentage loser yesterday among issues on the New York Stock Exchange.
It plunged $6.75 a share, to $18.75, a drop of 26.5 percent.


The Editorial Notebook; The Hole in the S &amp; L Lifeboat
LEAD: Take out a check.
Fill it out for $1,000 and send it to the Treasury.
That's how the new thrift bailout law solves the problem of bankrupt savings and loan institutions.
The taxpayer pays.


Vietnam experience has made the Joint Chiefs cautious about using military force.
LEAD: The Pentagon contends that the primary role of the armed forces is to deter war, not to fight one.
Since Vietnam, a succession of military officers making up the Joint Chiefs of Staff has elevated that policy to a fine art.


Services for Leland
LEAD: The family of Representative Mickey Leland announced Tuesday that a burial Mass would be held at 10 A.M.
Saturday at St.
Anne's Catholic Church in Houston.
A community memorial service was scheduled for Friday at Texas Southern University.

Crazy Eddie Closings
LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., the retailer of consumer electronics products, said it would close eight of its 26 stores in early November as part of its business reorganization plan.
The company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said it would reorganize around its 18 remaining stores, which operate in the New York metropolitan area.

Trader Pleads Not Guilty
LEAD: A Chicago Mercantile Exchange yen trader pleaded not guilty to fraud and racketeering charges.
James M. Marren, 39, was the 14th trader to plead not guilty to charges stemming from the Federal Government's investigation of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.
He was accused of racketeering conspiracy, mail and wire fraud, and violations of the Federal Commodities Act.

Review/Television; A Southern Journalist and Civil Rights
LEAD: Ralph McGill was a man who gave moderation a good name.
As editor and, more importantly, a front-page columnist for The Atlanta Constitution during the civil rights upheavals, he spoke for the liberal middle that helped Atlanta to avoid the racial clashes of other Southern cities and that offered a hope of reconciliation to the country.

Islanders Sign Healy
LEAD: Glenn Healy, a free-agent goalie who played with the Los Angeles Kings last season, has signed with the Islanders.
The Kings will receive a fourth-round draft choice as compensation.
Healy, 26 years old, was the Kings' starting goaltender for most of the season before Los Angeles acquired Kelly Hrudey from the Islanders in late February.

COURT TO HEAR APPEAL OF 3 IN ATTACK CASE
LEAD: New York State's highest court decided yesterday to hear the appeals of the three young men who were convicted of manslaughter in the Howard Beach racial attack.
A lower court unanimously upheld the convictions just two weeks ago.


Salman Rushdie Remains In Hiding and on the Move
LEAD: Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born author whose novel ''The Satanic Verses'' prompted Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to call for his death, has spent the past six months living in British intelligence safe houses, cut off from friends and protected by armed guards, friends have said.


JAMBALAYA PASSION FEEDS LENGTHY LINES ON BROADWAY
LEAD: Lilly Bunn, a third-grade student at the Spence School, waited in a two-and-a-half-hour line for dinner on lower Broadway the other night.
It was not the usual thing for her, or for her 10-year-old sister, Palmer. ''Maybe for the movies but not for dinner,'' Lilly reflected, sucking on a strawberry Mento.

King Excludes Dokes
LEAD: Don King, the promoter, said yesterday that Michael Dokes would not be Mike Tyson's next opponent.
Tyson's promoter insisted that it would be either Razor Ruddock or Buster Douglas and that the Las Vegas Hilton contractually had first shot at the world championship fight, targeted for October. ''After that,'' said King, ''depending on how Mike feels, he could fight again in December and there's a February date in Tokyo.

LEAD: The Congressional Budget Office projects the Federal deficit at $141 billion in the next fiscal year, figures obtained today show.

LEAD: The city will be allowed to tear down seven apartment buildings but must provide new units under an agreement settling a challenge of the nation's largest planned demolition of public housing, a Federal official said today.

Commodities Boards Plan Computers to Avert Abuses
LEAD: Moving to bolster investor confidence following the indictment of 46 of their members, the nation's two largest commodities exchanges announced today that they would develop new tamper-proof hand-held computer terminals that would prevent the sort of abuses that occurred under their decades-old pencil-and-paper system.

SAVINGS AND LOAN LAW IGNORES KEY REFORMS EX-U.S. REGULATOR SAYS
LEAD: With the stroke of his signature on the $150 billion savings and loan bailout bill last Wednesday, President Bush abolished the three-member Federal Home Loan Bank Board and created the Office of Thrift Supervision.


Fitch Reports a Conversation But No Offer Yet From Nets
LEAD: Bill Fitch, whose 762 coaching victories with Cleveland, Boston and Houston from 1970 through 1988 are the fifth-highest total in National Basketball Association history, said yesterday that while he had talked to the Nets about their coaching vacancy, the job was not his for the asking, as had been reported.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: If you are over 65, black, pregnant, or of Hispanic or native American descent, there is a greater-than-average chance that your blood pressure is dangerously elevated and you do not know it.
Or, if you know it, there is a greater-than-average chance that it is not being properly treated, recent studies have shown.

South African Signals
LEAD: A few hours after F. W. de Klerk became its Acting President, South Africa substantially eased a problem threatening the transition of neighboring Namibia to independence.
Its officials recalled to base 1,200 policemen, former members of a brutal paramilitary unit, who were accused of harassing civilians.

E.
Mark Beckman, professor of clinical obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday at St.

Eugene F. O'Malley, considered the inspiration for the character of the same name portrayed by Bing Crosby in the movies ''Going My Way'' and ''The Bells of St.
Mary's,'' died Monday of cardiac arrest at the St.
Joseph Hospital and Health Care Center.
He was 87 years old.

Toys 'R' Us Income Up
LEAD: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that its earnings were $23.5 million, or 12 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $23.1 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago.
The per-share figures were adjusted to reflect a three-for-two stock split on May 26, 1989.
The large toy retailer, which is based in Paramus, N.J., said revenues were $775.5 million in the quarter ended July 30, compared with $686.8 million a year ago.


Pulitzer to Sell Station
LEAD: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said today that it had agreed to sell its television station in Fort Wayne, Ind., to the Granite Broadcasting Corporation.
The station, WPTA-TV, is an ABC affiliate.
The sale price is $26.5 million in cash.
Granite, a private company, owns NBC-affiliated television stations in Duluth, Minn., and Peoria, Ill.

Treasury Securities Rise Again
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, regaining more ground lost in the big selloff on Friday and Monday.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: THE restaurant we had planned on - cheap, decent food and Ella Fitzgerald on the stereo - was closed for August.
So we wandered along a street near the waterfront. ''Here,'' my friend said, stopping. ''Here's the place I ate in last week.
I hope we're too early for the jukebox.''


Chevrolet Cutting Some Base Prices
LEAD: The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation said today that it was cutting the base price of 1990 versions of its top-selling cars in a bid to regain market share lost to its chief competitor, the Ford Motor Company.
The price cut comes as the auto makers announced overall increases in 1990-model prices.

LEAD: Several large employers have been stymied in their efforts to shift some of the soaring costs of medical care to unionized workers in contract settlements this year.

PARTENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: OF the thousands of adolescents who will be going off to college in the next month, a disturbing number will not graduate.
For many of those students, the freshman year will be a watershed.
Within days of starting their first classes, they will find themselves facing rigorous academic and social challenges unlike anything they have ever experienced.

Lebanon's Warring Factions

Korean Growth Outlook
LEAD: After three years of rapid growth, the South Korean economic pace is steadying, making continued growth dependent on a stable currency and increased corporate investment, a research group said today.
The group, the Korea Development Institute, predicted that the gross national product this year would grow by 7.7 percent, a respectable figure by global standards but far lower than South Korea's 12.2 percent growth in 1988.

I.B.M. Computers To Get Unix Soon
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would have Unix-based operating software available for its most powerful computers early next year, fulfilling a pledge made early last year.
I.B.M. had said in March 1988 that within two years it would have Unix-based software for its full range of computers.

Sea Containers Rejects Higher Bid
LEAD: Sea Containers Ltd., a container, ferry and port operator, said it had rejected the enhanced $63-a-share offer made Tuesday by Temple Holdings Ltd., a bidding partnership formed by Tiphook P.L.C. of Britain and Stena A.B. of Sweden.
The previous Temple bid had been $50 a share.
Sea Containers said the bid was inadequate and not in the best interests of its shareholders.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: THE mortar joints in nearly all brickwork eventually deteriorate.
Prompt repair is essential, because even small cracks and crumbled areas let moisture in between bricks, setting the stage for major damage.

Review/Music; A Joyful Jazz From Al Grey And His Band
LEAD: It has often been forgotten, given the political and esthetic upheavals of the last 25 years, that joy is one of jazz's great pleasures.
Joy reigned at Fat Tuesday's Tuesday night during the veteran trombonist Al Grey's show.
It was a joy that was linked to an obvious pleasure in creating, in replacing the blank spaces of silence with well-detailed ideas.

WHEN NATURE PALES, THERE ARE MANSIONS, MUSIC AND ART
LEAD: There is a delightfully anomalous, pre-suburban quality to northeastern Westchester County.
Just beyond the bedroom communities of the early-and mid-20th century, and barely 50 miles from Manhattan, a surprising sense of rural gentility still reigns in such communities as Katonah and Bedford.
Along the heavily wooded country roads that string together a patchwork of still-quiet hamlets are such noteworthy house museums as Caramoor and the John Jay Homestead, not to mention the Katonah Gallery, that suggest a world far away in spirit from metropolitan New York, 1989.

LEAD: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie is leading a group tonight on Musicruise (496-7070), a concert aboard the Hudson River Dayliner.
The boat leaves Pier 81, at 41st Street, at 9 P.M. and returns at midnight; boarding begins at 8 P.M.
Tickets are $25, available through Ticketron (399-4444).


Economic Scene; The White House Vs. the Fed
LEAD: NO Federal Reserve chairman is a hero at the White House.
President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, has fluttered the dovecotes from Constitution Avenue to Wall Street by maintaining that the Fed has kept interest rates so high that it was risking a recession.
And he has the President's backing.

LEAD: Opponents of apartheid said today that their organizations planned to resume operating Sunday ''openly and without the shackles of unjust restrictions'' in defiance of bans the Government imposed in a crackdown on dissent in February 1988.

A SOPRANO MAKES DEBUT IN CITY OPERA 'BOHEME'
LEAD: Mimi is a good debut role and Renee Fleming made a good debut in it at the New York City Opera Wednesday evening, when ''La Boheme'' was given for the first time this season.
Ms.
Fleming is a young soprano from Pennsylvania whose career is taking off quickly (her program biography detailed operatic engagements in Salzburg, London, Houston, Seattle and San Francisco), and on this showing she seems poised to make a worthwhile contribution.


NEARBY IN WESTCHESTER, A WILDERNESS (YES, A WILDERNESS)
LEAD: JUST one hour north of midtown Manhattan is a large patch of wilderness on the edge of suburbia.
It is a place that has been left to develop without the aid of man, where bobcats slink through rocky outcroppings and ring-necked pheasants and wild turkeys roam the underbrush.
The only sounds are the rustling of leaves, the rush of water over rocks and the maddening chant of katydids.


Claiborne's Approach to Today's Man
LEAD: IF the old man went to John Ford westerns, drank double Scotches and splashed himself with colognes named for brutes, Liz Claiborne Inc. reasons that the new man who attends Rob Reiner romances and tipples kir royales might also want to take an introspective and vulnerable approach to the way he smells.


Key Officer Quits Wang
LEAD: Financially troubled Wang Laboratories lost another key executive yesterday when Ian W. Diery resigned as executive vice president for worldwide operations.

President Resigns At Columbia Savings
LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said yesterday that Lawrence K. Fish, its president and chief operating officer, had resigned after 18 months with the company.


Wings for Omon
LEAD: Little Omon New York said it had reached $25 million in billings with the acquisition of the Buffalo Bucket chicken wings account from Great Wings Inc.
Buffalo Bucket wings are frozen chicken wings prepared with hot sauce, often served with blue cheese dressing and sold in supermarkets.
The account bills $2 million, Omon said.

LEAD: New York City will no longer use the Irving Trust Company as custodian of $3 billion in short-term funds held by the city and its five pension funds because the bank cannot meet deadlines for submitting a plan to insure equal employment opportunity, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday.

LEAD: Twenty-seven years after Clarence Earl Gideon made legal history from a Florida prison cell as he persuaded the Supreme Court to hear his case and later grant indigents accused of a felony the right to a lawyer, inmates here are following in his tradition.
They are writing similar pleas, but with a tool that the state now has taken away.

Newark Agrees To Curb Razing Of City Housing
LEAD: Eight rundown and mostly vacant public housing high-rises will be dynamited, perhaps starting early next year, but other demolitions have been put off under a settlement announced in a Federal court today.


Silence Is Ordered in Case of Drug Official
LEAD: A Federal magistrate in Boston today barred prosecution and defense lawyers from speaking publicly about the case of Edward K. O'Brien, a Drug Enforcement Administration official accused of cocaine trafficking.
His lawyers had complained that Government sources were tainting their client's case in statements to the press.


Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions
LEAD: Lawrenceville School, the prominent, private boarding academy near Princeton, N.J., was accused in a lawsuit yesterday of being responsible for the alcohol and drug abuse of a former student.


Rose's Suit to Remain A Federal Court Case
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today denied Pete Rose's latest effort to shift his lawsuit against Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti from Federal court back into an Ohio state court.


40 Years of Communism in Poland: Stalin's House on a Soft Foundation
LEAD: Stalin said that imposing Communism on Roman Catholic Poland was as absurd as putting a saddle on a cow.
But after World War II, he went ahead and imposed it anyway, even though the roots of Communism in Poland had never run very deep.

Tires for Keye/Donna
LEAD: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein New York was given Bridgestone U.S.A.'s tire advertising account yesterday.
The account, which may be worth $10 million in annual billings, is a shot in the arm for the struggling agency.
The account is moving, apparently without a review, from Lintas Campbell-Ewald's office in Nashville, the home base of the company, which is the American unit of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan.

LEAD: If the $1,088,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Track on Saturday were a winner-take-all event, Easy Goer might enjoy the first Grade I walkover in American racing since Spectacular Bid raced alone in the 1980 Woodward.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 462 money market mutual funds increased by $2.29 billion, to $340.5 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 140 institutional funds decreased by $1.05 billion, to $85.48 billion.
The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $1.74 billion, to $108.76 billion.

LEAD: New York City's Campaign Finance Board yesterday gave 19 municipal candidates $584,613 in matching funds for their campaigns, with one candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, receiving almost 40 percent of the money.

DOW DROPS 13.66, TO 2,679.63, ON INTEREST RATE WORRIES
LEAD: Stock prices fell widely yesterday in the wake of a broadly lower bond market.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 13.66 points, to 2,679.63, after being down about 25 points in the early afternoon.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advances by 887 to 561.

HORACIO GUTIERREZ AND JOSHUA BELL ARE SOLOISTS IN MOZART
LEAD: George Cleve conducted the Mostly Mozart orchestra in a program of Mozart favorites on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.
There were some lovely moments, but for the most part, it was an evening of honorable averageness.
The orchestra played like the competent modern freelance ensemble it is, and Mr.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: From Spain ''Catalan-Mediterranean'' cuisine is how Paradis, a striking new restaurant on East 50th Street, describes its food.
This 150-seat restaurant in the Kimberly Hotel building is the first American outpost of a Spanish chain called Paradis Barcelona, which has five restaurants in Catalonia and a major catering company.

Seattle Bond Issue Totals $80 Million
LEAD: The Municipality of Seattle yesterday priced through competitive bidding $80 million of general obligation bonds that are backed by a limited sales tax.


'LA BOCA DEL LOBO' FROM PERU
LEAD: ''La Boca del Lobo'' (''The Mouth of the Wolf''), Francisco J. Lombardi's Peruvian film opening today at the Public, dramatizes the no-win situation of the Peruvian Indian caught in a war in which he has no part to play except as the victim.

Viola Falls To Hurst In Padres' Fast Rally
LEAD: For the 40,406 fans in Shea Stadium on a rare afternoon, it was a marquee matchup between Frank Viola and Bruce Hurst, two left-handed pitching stars from the American League.
For the San Diego Padres, a chance to leave town without being swept.
For the Mets, after winning 4 straight games and 13 in their last 16, a dose of reality.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: Arrow Bank Corp. of Glen Falls, N.Y., and United Vermont Bancorp of Rutland, Vt., agreed to a merger that will form Arrow Financial Corp.


H. W. Fuller, 81, Dies; Decorated Ex-Marine
LEAD: Horace W. Fuller, a retired United States Marine Reserve brigadier general who served at Guadalcanal and with the French Resistance in World War II, died of cancer Wednesday in a clinic on the Greek island of Spetsai.
He was 81 years old and lived on Spetsai.

LEAD: The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in June to $8.2 billion, the lowest level in four and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today.

INSIDER TRADING SETTLEMENT IN BUSINESS WEEK INQUIRY
LEAD: A former salesman for the company that prints Business Week magazine settled Federal insider trading charges today.
The Government had charged that he had bought stocks based on articles in advance copies of the magazine.

LEAD: Amanda Blake, who played the kindhearted saloonkeeper Miss Kitty in the ''Gunsmoke'' television series for 19 years, died of oral cancer on Wednesday at Mercy General Hospital in Los Angeles.
She was 60 years old.

Two Rabbis Leave Lagacy of Change
LEAD: Forty years ago, Marc H. Tanenbaum and Wolfe Kelman were roommates at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, where they were studying to be Conservative rabbis.
Now both men are retiring after two remarkable and influential, but very different, careers in the American rabbinate.

ACCORD IS REACHED AT BELL ATLANTIC
LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and one of its striking unions reached tentative agreement today on the framework of a new contract.
But unresolved local issues and continuing differences with another union prevented an end to a 13-day strike.


Iowa Court Upholds Curfew
LEAD: The Iowa Supreme Court has freed local governments to impose curfews on minors to fight drug abuse and crime.
In a 5-to-4 ruling Wednesday, the court held that a curfew is only a minor infringement on the rights of children and parents.
It upheld a curfew set in Panora that barred those under 18 from being out from 10 P.M.

Corrections
LEAD: A Company News article in some editions of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the investment group that reduced its stake in the Von Companies.
The Investment Limited Partnership, a group led by Richard E. Rainwater and Dort A. Cameron of Fort Worth, sold a million shares in Vons, reducing its holding to 4.6 percent.

LEAD: The drug AZT can delay the onset of AIDS in people who are infected with the virus but have no symptoms, the Government announced yesterday.

June Trade Deficit Report Bolsters Dollar Worldwide
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply worldwide yesterday on news that the United States trade deficit narrowed in June.
The rise brought the dollar near the highs it reached two months ago, but the gains were capped by profit taking and uncertainty over whether the upward momentum could continue.

LEAD: An armored car guard was shot and killed and another guard was critically wounded yesterday in a botched robbery attempt in Queens.
Dozens of police officers using helicopters and bloodhounds searched in Flushing for three men observed leaving the scene.


What Are They Waiting For?
LEAD: New Yorkers wait on line a lot, probably more than any other Americans.
They line up for buses, train tickets, the ladies' room at the theater, subway tokens, any and all events at Madison Square Garden, lottery tickets and the morning coffee-regular-with sugar and a cheese Danish.

Quebec Signs Mylnikov
LEAD: The Quebec Nordiques announced the signing yesterday of Sergei Mylnikov to a one-year contract with a one-year option.
The 30-year-old Mylnikov will become the first Soviet goaltender to play in the National Hockey League.
Financial details were not released, but Martin Madden, the Nordiques' general manager, said Mylnikov would receive half his salary.

On the Erie Canal, that is a long way.

Treasury Issues Mixed in Active Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities finished narrowly mixed yesterday, although trading was active as many market participants squared their books before going on vacation.
Dealers said retail buying of Treasury coupon issues was evident even before the Government announced a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for July in midmorning, a figure that was in line with expectations.

Two Officials Penalized
LEAD: The National Hockey League has penalized two officials for what it termed violation of curfew regulations in the recent playoffs.
Jim Gregory, the league's vice president of hockey operations, announced yesterday that Don Koharski, a referee, and Wayne Bonney, a linesman, would be fined $1,000 each and assigned to either the American or International Hockey Leagues for a period of two weeks, or seven games, at the beginning of the upcoming season.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Aug. 10 about Gibraltarians' attitudes toward Spain and Britain described the status of Hong Kong residents imprecisely.
Some 3.25 million Hong Kong Chinese are eligible for passports that declare them citizens of the British dependent territory, but they have not been granted the right to settle in Britain after the colony reverts to China in 1997.

Woman Finds Pin in Cookies
LEAD: A Long Island woman, Barbara Meiderdrut, found a straight pin in a package of Stripe Dainties cookies she bought today at a Pathmark supermarket here, the Nassau County police said.
No one was injured.
The store manager had other packages of the cookies removed.
A Pathmark spokesman said the tampering appeared to be an isolated incident.

LEAD: A 67-year-old woman foiled a robbery attempt today when she burst from her bedroom and fired a pistol at two prowlers who had forced their way into her apartment in the city's North End and were attacking her 72-year-old husband, the police said.


Cummins Job Cuts
LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company said it would lay off about 100 production workers in southern Indiana, effective Aug. 28, because of slower industry orders for heavy-duty truck engines and because of production adjustments by some important Cummins truck customers.
Cummins Engine shares closed today at $60.625, down $1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on the Education page on Aug. 9 about college-bound immigrants referred incorrectly to the program Opportunity to Learn.
It is not bilingual; it helps students prepare for college by teaching them in English only.

LEAD: Self-help books address themselves to the ambitions and anxieties of the moment, but in a way that personalizes them.

Whether the answer is to make over your appearance, portfolio or personality, you can do it!
And here's how!

LEAD: The Houston Astros traded Billy Hatcher to the Pittsburgh Pirates for Glenn Wilson last night in a swap of outfielders.
Wilson, 30, has nine home runs and 48 runs batted in and was hitting .282 for the Pirates.
Hatcher, 28, has three homers and 34 r.b.i. and was batting .226.(AP)

Attaching Items to Walls
LEAD: WALLS in most homes are hollow.
That is, they consist of an inner framework of widely spaced, narrow pieces of lumber called studs, which are covered on each side by a layer of wall material like wallboard, plaster or thin paneling.

LEAD: THE sabbatical, once the exclusive perquisite of the academic community, has spread to the business world.

New Drug Study Heralds A Hopeful Realignment In the War Against AIDS

Zucchini With an Italian Accent
LEAD: ZUCCHINI can be a very boring vegetable.
As a child in England I remember how each year local gardeners would compete to grow the biggest, pointing with pride at specimens the size of a man's riding boot.
The marrows, as they were called, were cooked with the typical English solicitude toward vegetables: Boiled, stuffed and then baked until they were reduced to a watery pulp.

POSTINGS: Jersey Expanding Loan Plan; Special for Handymen
LEAD: New Jersey plans to expand and promote an unusual program that lends to the buyer of a dilapidated house the money to both buy and renovate it.
The so-called Buy-It-And-Fix-It Program has been little used since it was started two years ago, and to date only 20 homeowners in the state have taken advantage of its provisions, which include a fixed mortgage interest rate, currently 8.82 percent.

LEAD: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles.
The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface.
But one corner of a tile near the refrigerator has lifted slightly, and the dealer says that the old flooring must be ripped up and new plywood put down before the new tiles can be laid.

A Chunk of Lava in the Sea
LEAD: ON the east end of one of Iceland's neighboring islands there is a vast hill.
It is a hill as dark as the melt of minerals in the earth's heart, and burns with all of their fires.
It sprawls toward the sea and reaches the town.
And from its surface, every few yards, come breaths of steam.

Iran Hangs 79 in Drug Cases
LEAD: Iran today hanged 79 ''notorious and professional'' drug smugglers, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported.
The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the convicts were hanged in Teheran and in 21 cities after being found guilty by the Islamic Revolutionary Court, which runs the nation's anti-narcotics campaign.

Correction
LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine on June 11 about Louisiana's economic, environmental and racial problems referred incorrectly to lung cancer rates.
A recent letter from the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals points out that in 1986, according to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control, the state ranked fifth, not first, in lung cancer deaths.

LEAD: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles.
The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface.

Networking Without the Wires
LEAD: PERHAPS the worst thing about computer networking is the actual physical wiring.
Whether the computers are connected with coaxial cables, twisted pair cables, fiber-optic cables or jumper cables, the cabling itself is usually a logistical, physical and financial nightmare.
Adding a computer to the network, or even just moving someone's desk, is a major ordeal.

By David Price. (Seven Locks Press, $18.95.) In 1980 David Price, an American anthropologist, was solicited by the World Bank to assess the impact of a $1 billion development proposal on the Indians of central Brazil.
The Polonoroeste project, which the World Bank helped to fund, would include the paving of a 1,000-mile highway through this remote region; its effects on the Indians promised to be dramatic.

Blueberry Flavor As It Used to Be
LEAD: I read the article on blueberries with interest (''Picky About Blueberries,'' Opinion page, July 16) and would wish to be in the author's shoes.
I'm about to plant blueberries extensively, but am wary of the new, disease-resistant, large and copious berries that are bland in taste.
I hope someone can guide me to domestically grown blueberries that still preserve the old, wild flavor.

About Men; Giving Up Guns
LEAD: I VIVIDLY RECALL THE first time I held a gun.
My father was a New York City cop.
One day when I was 10, he returned from his annual trip to the firing range and let me and my brother watch him clean his .38 caliber Smith &amp; Wesson revolver.
Dad sat on the kitchen table as the biting odor of gunpowder and gun oil filled the room.

Public Schools On Corporate Campuses
LEAD: Every Saturday morning for 10 weeks during the fall and spring, 60 seventh graders in Washington assemble for four hours to participate in the Saturday Academy.
Designed for bright students who nevertheless have a potential for dropping out, the program aims to keep them in school by building their self-esteem and skills through individualized instruction and reinforcement by the adults in their lives, who are required to accompany students to at least 6 of the 10 sessions.

Going for Broke in Lebanon's Proxy War
LEAD: AS chaotic as Lebanon may have seemed to outsiders in the past 14 years, the civil war there actually followed certain unwritten rules.
What is new about the violence today is that those long-established rules are being shredded.
The political and military boundaries that no one had dared breach - call them ''red lines'' - have now been crossed, and the combatants are entering a new game whose rules are as undefined as its outcome.

Attaching Items to Walls
LEAD: WALLS in most homes are hollow.
That is, they consist of an inner framework of widely spaced, narrow pieces of lumber called studs, which are covered on each side by a layer of wall material like wallboard, plaster or thin paneling.

Correction
LEAD: Because of a concert sponsor's change, a listing today in the Week in Connecticut column of the Connecticut Weekly misstates the site of a Hartford appearance by the Tannahill Weavers.
The concert, at 7:30 P.M. today, will be at the Summit Hotel, not at Lloyd's Restaurant.


All Sounds Blend in a Rich American Mainstream
LEAD: No less than European music from Bach through Brahms, American symphonic music in the 20th century has a mainstream.
The style is broad enough to take in jazz and 12-tone effects, the pastoral and the urban, optimism and (less frequently) melancholy, but it is grounded in tonality and independence of spirit.

Powder Plant Blast Kills 2
LEAD: The second explosion this year at a commercial powder factory killed two workers and injured six on Friday.
The blast, at the Atlas Powder Company, came as employees poured molten primer, an igniting substance, into a mold.
An explosion on March 22 injured two employees in a unit that turns nitric acid and ammonium into ammonium nitrate.

LEAD: A Bronx man who told ambulance attendants that he had been using cocaine died early yesterday, shortly after four police officers who were trying to place him into an ambulance pushed him to the ground and handcuffed him, the police said.

Back to Beauty Basics
LEAD: IT IS THE FASHION equivalent of cleaning house.
Women are tossing out the clutter, stripping away the superfluous and streamlining their beauty and fashion collections to the lean, spare essentials.
Take many of the new handbags.
Not only have they shrunk from Samsonite-luggage size to mere specks on a chain, they can't possibly carry the usual gear: a powder compact, blusher brush, comb, four lipsticks, mirror, wallet, appointment book, newspaper, paperback and gym clothes.

Colleges can never spend enough on academics or athletics, because these are two of the most vital aspects of the college experience.

LEAD: For This Week: Last call to order bulbs for fall planting, particularly the lesser-known kinds.

Select herbs in good condition and dry them for potpourri and culinary needs.

FICTION
LEAD:  STRANGER AT THE GATE.
By Malcolm Bosse. (Simon &amp; Schuster, $19.95.) Indonesia in 1965 was a country in turmoil.
On one side was the P.K.I., the third-largest Communist Party in the world; on the other, the country's Muslim majority and its army.
Caught in the middle was the increasingly ill President Sukarno, who, in an attempt to maintain power and a semblance of order, was performing a delicate balancing act between opposing factions.

Recession? Maybe Yes, Maybe No
LEAD: SINCE the beginning of the year, there have been conflicting indicators about an approaching recession.
When inflation rose above a 5 percent annual rate, suggesting that the economy was overheating, the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates and banks followed suit.
Interest rate-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing, autombiles and some retail sales, slowed and inventories began to accumulate.

Corrections
LEAD: An article last week about Union Carbide referred incompletely to the price history of the company's stock since the 1984 Bhopal accident.
The article noted that the stock traded at $50 before the accident and that it is now trading at below $30.
But the comparison failed to take into account a 3-for-1 stock split in 1986.

Question Box
LEAD:  PGA Earnings  Q. Each week, the PGA Tour lists its leading money winners based on what each golfer has earned for the year, without regard to how many tournaments he entered.
Among the top earners this season, who would be the leader on the basis of earnings per tournament?
A.
Through 33 tournaments this season, not counting this weekend's event in Colorado, the per-tournament leader in winnings is Tom Kite, who is second on the overall earnings list.

He was 71 years old and lived in Bethesda.


Corrections
LEAD: A table in Business Day on Thursday about health care and the strike at the Nynex Corporation referred incorrectly to a contract offer by the company, which is proposing payroll deductions to help cover premium costs.
In the first year of a new contract, the proposed deduction would be $10.27 weekly, not monthly.

LEAD: Among the amazing images of Poland in transition was a smiling Communist Party spokesman, who greeted the change as one in which 'Our days will be broader.' Page A6.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We sang today at the church, 'Poland lives, Poland is growing.' We must believe that this nation, a wonderful nation, can reach the stage where life will be better in Poland, so that no one lacks anything in Poland, that no one leaves it.''  -Tadeusz Mazowiecki, designated as Poland's Prime Minister.

LEAD: As police sirens led air-conditioned buses and dark-windowed limousines through the streets of Tangier on Saturday night, few people here seemed to care whether the big bash at the palace on the hill was a real birthday party or simply a huge marketing extravaganza.


Injury Forces Rosario to Cancel
LEAD: Edwin Rosario of Puerto Rico, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, tore a ligament on the knuckle of his right index finger and withdrew from his scheduled title defense Sunday at the Felt Forum against Lupe Suarez.

So is the Warsaw Pact.

LEAD: Five months after he retired from a 16-year career in the House of Representatives, Gene Taylor of Missouri reached into his old campaign account and took home $345,000.

LEAD: Two years after his religious empire collapsed in sex and financial scandals, Jim Bakker returned here today to stand trial on fraud and conspiracy charges.


Strong Quakes in East Africa
LEAD: Several strong earthquakes shook Ethiopia and caused some damage in neighboring Djibouti, officials reported today.
There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties in Ethiopia.
The first temblor registered 6.4 on the Richter scale and occurred on Sunday aftrnoon 320 miles northeast of Addis Ababa and about 100 miles northwest of Djibouti.

Video-Audio Sony Camera
LEAD: The Sony Corporation has introduced an electronic still video camera for consumers that also records audio, a spokesman said today.


Attack on Fruit Flies Is Begun
LEAD: A batch of sterile Mediterranean fruit flies was released from the air and from trucks in the center of Los Angeles today in an attempt to wipe out the crop-destroying pest, which was recently found in Elysian Park.
In the next two months, 300 million sterile flies will be released over a 60-square-mile area.

Hoesch Purchase
LEAD: Hoesch A.G., the steel and engineering company, said it had taken over Schroff G.m.b.H,, a privately owned West German electronics company.
Terms were not disclosed.
A Hoesch statement said Schroff specializes in making electronic instruments for the engineering industry.
Founded in 1960, the company employs around 1,200 and has third-party sales of about $111.9 million.

Goldin School Plan Would Cut 1,000 Board Jobs
LEAD: Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for eliminating 1,000 jobs on the New York City Board of Education's administrative staff as part of an education-improvement plan.
He also called for higher pay for teachers who work in less desirable schools, dropout prevention programs in all elementary schools and increased autonomy for principals.

LEAD: Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that unless Congress puts into effect the bipartisan agreement reached in April, the Government faces cuts in military and domestic spending of $16.2 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

LEAD: State regulators in New Jersey said yesterday that they were investigating Traders and Investors Alert, a telephone tip service aimed at stock investors, for possible violations of securities laws.

LEAD: On election night in November, a power failure blacked out The Idaho Statesman newspaper office in Boise, which had been serving as the headquarters for reporting the state's computerized election returns.
Joseph W. Marshall, then the Idaho Power Company's executive vice president, went to the scene to help workers restore electricity.

LEAD: The Pratt &amp; Whitney Aircraft subsidiary of United Technologies said that Northwest Airlines had ordered 12 of its PW-4000 jet engines worth $162 million for six new Airbus Industrie A330's.

In the new position, Mr.
Goldsmith, a 16-year veteran of ABC, will be responsible for advertising sales for the network's prime-time programming.

LEAD: Frustrated by chronic food shortages, Moscow has announced that it will pay foreign-currency bonuses to the most productive farms.
But even as the Kremlin dangles Levi's and Sonys in front of Soviet farmers, it is shelving more ambitious plans to let free markets decide who may earn dollars and how they may be spent.

Primary Colors
LEAD:  Q.Why do photographers talk about red, green and blue as the primary colors?
A.There are really two kinds of primary colors, subtractive primaries and additive primaries.


Bridge
LEAD: This column receives hundreds of letters from readers who are proud of their skill in playing the dummy.
But when two letters arrive about the play of the same deal, one from the dummy and one from a defender, it is time to pay attention.
The diagramed deal was played July 10 in the Monday night team game at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan.


Why Insiders Are Mourning DeFrancis
LEAD: The death Saturday of Frank J. DeFrancis at the age of 62 was appropriately noted at the beginning of ABC-TV's national telecast of the Travers Stakes.
But because DeFrancis was merely named and not further identified, many in the viewing audience probably did not know who he was or why racing insiders were mourning his death.


TOYOTA LEXUS LURES BUYERS FROM CADILLAC AND LINCOLN
LEAD: Sales of the Lexus luxury cars from Japan appear to be off to a fast start, and one surprise is that the cars are stealing buyers from the increasingly costly top of Detroit's line, not just from Mercedes-Benz and BMW.


In Men's Wear, The 1990's Have Arrived
LEAD: American men's wear designers showed their first styles for the 1990's last week, and while much of the high glamour of women's fashion shows was absent, there was plenty of glitz, perhaps too much for the average man.
One designer even showed plunging necklines on the runway, a kind of mohair chest look.


DEFENSE AGAINST CHIEFS DISPLEASES GIANTS
LEAD: In many respects, the Giants' performance Sunday night against the Chiefs in Kansas City was overwhelming.


Animal-Rights Suits Opening Up Research Panels
LEAD: The State University at Stony Brook caught the attention of animal-rights advocates in 1987, when someone distributed a three-year-old videotape of a student's experiment on predatory behavior in which a ferret slowly killed a rabbit and several rats.


Brooklyn Candidate For District Attorney Knocked Off Ballot
LEAD: A state judge yesterday removed Norman Rosen, one of three Democrats running for Brooklyn District Attorney, from the Sept. 12 primary ballot.


Perfection vs. Cleaner Air
LEAD: Nobody expected industry to love President Bush's clean air bill.
It will cause great aggravation and cost billions.
What's far more surprising is the passionate complaining of the environmentalists, who seek a more perfect bill.
Yet especially in Congress, perfection has a way of becoming the enemy of the good.

LEAD: *
Art Direction magazine will sponsor Ad Directions '89, a conference for visual arts professionals, in New York from Sept. 26 to 28.


Westward Tide of East Germans Is a Popular No-Confidence Vote
LEAD: Sitting on a bench in the sunny main courtyard of the central reception camp for East German immigrants in this quiet town north of Frankfurt, the East German did not look like someone about to begin a new life.


EDITOR, 97, HELPED START YIDDISH DAILY
LEAD: Paul Novick, a founder and longtime editor in chief of The Morning Freiheit, a left-wing Yiddish daily, died yesterday of congestive heart failure and kidney deficiency at Peekskill (N.Y.) Hospital.
He was 97 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Croton-on-Hudson.


UEBERROTH GROUP TO BUY HAWAIIAN AIR
LEAD: A group including Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner whose deal to acquire Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, has agreed to acquire control of the financially troubled Hawaiian Airlines.


Toshiba To Buiild Big TV's in U.S.
LEAD: Toshiba Display Devices yesterday became the first television manufacturers to make ''super size'' television screens in the United States.
Several other companies also have plans to make the large sets in American plants.


Leland's Body to Come Home
LEAD: The bodies of Representative Mickey Leland of Texas and eight other Americans killed in a plane crash in Ethiopia on Aug. 7 will arrive in the United States on Wednesday, Ethiopian and American officials said today.
Mr.
Leland and 15 others, including 7 Ethiopians, died when the plane taking them to a refugee camp hit a cliff in bad weather.

LEAD: *
Dominick F. Rossi Jr., executive vice president and director of national operations at N. W. Ayer, has been appointed to the additional post of president of the agency's Middle Western division.


Witness Says The Helmsleys Overpaid Tax
LEAD: The last witness in the Leona Helmsley trial, a tax expert, testified yesterday that Mrs.
Helmsley and her husband had overpaid $591,000 on their Federal income tax returns from 1983 to 1985, the period in which the Government contends the couple evaded $1.2 million in Federal income taxes.


Koch Calls for Report in Nazi Slogan Inquiry
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday asked the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Benito Romano, to release an internal report about an allegation that a concentration camp survivor had to face a Nazi slogan while being questioned in the prosecutor's office in 1986.


G.M. to Shut 3 U.S. Plants
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has said it will shut three domestic plants that make light trucks for a week, beginning next Monday, laying off 7,200 people.
The plants are in Pontiac, Mich., Moraine, Ohio, and Shreveport, La.
General Motors has excessive inventories of these models.

LEAD: A gas canister in a parcel detonated at the regional office of the N.A.A.C.P. when the package was opened today, injuring 15 people.

The Black Poor Are Different
LEAD: Of all the problems on the racial landscape, none seems harder than helping the people called the ''black underclass.'' Some conservatives argue against policies aimed at a specific race and instead for programs targeted at the poor generally.
This view is erroneous.


Death in Gramercy Park
LEAD: It's become the standard sequel to New York City tragedies.
The street barricades go up, the crowds gather and the police urge the curious onlookers to ''Keep moving . . .
Nothing to see . . .
Nothing to see.'' In truth, there is always something to see, as the mind's eye imagines what time or the weather or an ambulance have already erased.


Struggle for Work and Family Fueling Women's Movement
LEAD: Despite much talk about the decline of feminism and the women's movement, American women very much want a movement working on their behalf as they try to win equal treatment in the workplace and to balance the demands of work and family.


Amway Halts Animal Tests
LEAD: The Amway Corporation has switched from animal tests to test tubes in its studies on new products but says it may use animals if ordered to do so by the Government.

LEAD: Two extravaganzas this month, one on Long Island and one in Tangiers, have exposed two deep social nerves: the need of some rich people to sponsor opulent entertainments, and the need of the non-rich to recoil in disgust.

Edythe Gilfond, Costume Designer, 79
LEAD: Edythe Gilfond, a costume designer for dance companies, theater and television, died yesterday at her home in Southampton, L.I., after a long illness.
She was 79 years old.
Mrs.
Gilfond, a native of Brooklyn, designed costumes for Martha Graham's dance company - including those for the world premiere of ''Serpent Heart'' (1946) and ''Deaths and Entrances'' (1953) - and for several television series, including ''As the World Turns'' and ''Edge of Night.

LEAD: Linda Lyon Van Voorhis, a poet, died Sunday at her home in Irondequoit in suburban Rochester.

Wang Accord With Lenders
LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc., the struggling minicomputer manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed on a new debt package with its banks and would immediately make some payments.
Wang, based in Lowell, Mass., owes about $962 million.


Steel Output Off 2.1%
LEAD: Domestic raw steel production in the week ended Aug. 19 totaled 1,773,000 tons, down 2.1 percent from the previous week, when the industry produced 1,811,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.
Steelmakers operated at 79.8 percent of their production capacity last week, down from 81.5 percent the previous week, the steel institute said.

LEAD: Catfish farmers continue to increase production, but their harvests are bringing lower prices than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR
LEAD: When he was playing tennis, Bjorn Borg was known for never showing emotion on the court and rarely revealing any off it.
Yet even now, seven years after he stopped playing the professional circuit, the man from Sweden who was the world's No. 1 player from 1978 to 1980 and a five-time Wimbledon champion continues to intrigue tennis fans: they follow every report of his behavior, from a mysterious alleged suicide attempt to assorted romantic difficulties to the recent financial troubles of his designer clothing line.


On Landing Like a Cat: It Is a Fact
LEAD: EVERY year, scores of cats fall from open windows in New York City.
From June 4 through Nov. 4, 1984, for instance, 132 such victims were admitted to the Animal Medical Center on 62d Street in Manhattan.

LEAD: Alex Stewart, who has knocked out his first 24 opponents, will fight against Evander Holyfield in a heavyweight bout at Atlantic City, the Showtime network announced yesterday.

That's the way I felt about it before I walked up to it.
It was black, it was in the ground, it wasn't designed by a Vietnam vet.

Killing of Civilians Haunts Sri Lankan Village
LEAD: This pretty, small fishing village on the northern tip of Sri Lanka is nearly deserted now, tense and fearful nearly three weeks after Indian soldiers are reported to have beaten and shot civilians after a group of soldiers was ambushed.


Canadian Trade Surplus
LEAD: Canada's trade surplus declined to $127 million (Canadian) in June from a revised May surplus of $543 million, the Government agency Statistics Canada said last week.
The surplus for May had originally been calculated at $394 million.
The surplus in June 1988 was $1.39 billion.
Exports in June 1989, seasonally adjusted, were $11.12 billion, down from $12.45 billion in May.


Dean Buying Cates
LEAD: The Dean Foods Company, the second-largest dairy company in the country, has agreed to acquire a pickle maker for about $29 million in stock.
Dean Foods, based in Franklin Park, Ill., said it would exchange 865,000 shares of its stock for all the shares of Charles F. Cates &amp; Sons Inc., a privately held pickle processor based in Faison, N.C.

LEAD: A 4 1/2-year-old Manhattan girl we know recently returned from a five-week vacation in the country with plenty to tell her city friends about the great outdoors beyond Central Park.

LEAD: THE inscrutability of the cat, long a creature of mystery to humans, is slowly yielding to a vigorous new effort among scientists to fathom this wildest and most independent of domestic animals.

LEAD: Jean Fautrier, who is being honored by a long-awaited retrospective at the Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, is a peculiar case.
From time to time, both during his life and after his death in 1964 at the age of 66, he has been almost a cult figure in France.
His World War II ''Hostages'' - patches and clots of matter suggesting stumpy, maimed bodies that almost seem to have been shot at the canvas - drew the attention of eminent French writers like Andre Malraux and Francis

Goldman, Sachs's Stake in Anchor
LEAD: Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company has acquired a 9.7 percent stake in the Anchor Glass Container Corporation for investment purposes.
Vitro S.A., a Mexican glass maker, has offered to buy Anchor Glass for $20 a share, or $280 million.
The board of the Tampa, Fla., glass concern has urged its shareholders not to take any action until it studies the Vitro offer.

Pittsburgh Journal; Changed City Is Trying To Save Steel Heritage
LEAD: In this city that was once the heart of the steel industry, the reminders of that heritage are abundant, from the Steelers football team to Iron City beer.
But steelmaking has declined dramatically in Pittsburgh, and some organizations, local businesses and historians are working to preserve the history before the wrecking ball demolishes what is left of the idled mills.

Prices of Treasury Securities Ease
LEAD: Prices of most Treasury maturities eased yesterday after the Federal Reserve moved to bolster interest rates in midmorning.
Before then, dealers said, prices had trended higher largely on scattered buying by overseas investors and a firmer dollar.
Stock traders rushed to sell equities in response to the threat of higher interest rates, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 40.97 points at an even 2,647.00.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Friday showing the yield on tax-exempt bonds misstated the yields for two types of bonds.

Beneath the Streets, Steam Pipes Give No Hint of Impending Disaster
LEAD: In contrast to the city's network of electric cables and transformers, where a sudden jump in temperature can be a tip-off to trouble, the pipes carrying high-pressure steam beneath the streets of Manhattan give no clues of a catastrophe in the making, Con Edison officials said yesterday.


Officer Kills Man in Brooklyn
LEAD: A gunman was shot and killed by an undercover narcotics officer yesterday after the man fired four shots in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, the police said.
At 5:30 P.M. officers from the Brooklyn North Narcotics Unit pulled up in their unmarked car in front of 378 Greene Avenue and saw a man with a gun shooting at an unknown target, said Officer Edward Feeney, a police spokesman.

LEAD: James Terrell, an architect who developed designs for many of the nation's leading stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue, Macy's and Bloomingdale's in New York and Marshall Field in Chicago, died of AIDS at New York Hospital on Saturday.
He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

How to Select and Care for Peaches...and Where to Pick Your Own
LEAD: PEACHES fall into two categories, white and yellow, with many varieties of each color.
A ripe white peach will be creamy gold, while a ripe yellow peach will be a deep, rich yellow.
Both may be blushed with red, but neither will be tinged with green when truly ripe.
The flesh of a ripe peach will yield to slight pressure and be tantalizingly aromatic.

LEAD: NORTH American folk-art collectors and museums have discovered the arpillera, a South American wall hanging that depicts particular events as well as the hardships and joys of daily life.
Arpillera is the Spanish word for burlap or sackcloth, the material used as the foundation for the needlework, which is executed in embroidery and appliques of gaily colored scraps of cloth.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Removing Wallpaper  Q.I am in the process of removing three layers of wallpaper from a ceiling.
The last layer of paper was painted over, and I cannot use a steamer because I want to preserve the finish on the walls.
I bought a can of a liquid wallpaper remover, but I find that it does not penetrate the painted wallpaper very well and thus does not soften it enough for easy scraping.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: IT is damp, and sometimes the rain is a downpour.
One Saturday afternoon it was literally thrilling, the way it pounded the gardens and bounced off the fence beyond my bedroom windows.
The basements over on the next block have flooded; I am afraid to go downstairs and check ours.
Even so, I love this weather.

Grumman to Shut Tachonics Unit
LEAD: The Grumman Corporation said it would close Tachonics, a division based in Plainsboro, N.J., that makes gallium arsenide computer chips.
Tachonics, which had 47 employees and has been unprofitable since its start in 1985, is the third gallium arsenide company in a year to be shut down.
Gallium arsenide is a material that can be used to make chips that are faster than those made with silicon.

LEAD: BALKY or drafty double-hung windows can often be repaired and sealed quickly by replacing window channels, a project best done now, while the weather is still mild.

CHEMISTRY FAILS METS BUT FUELS THE GIANTS
LEAD: The San Francisco Giants are doing the things that keep a team in first place.
They are getting excellent pitching.
They are hitting with power.
And when their opponents make mental or physical errors, as the Mets did yesterday afternoon, the Giants are quick to capitalize.


KICKBACK INQUIRY BY U.S. SEEN
LEAD: The Government is investigating whether some mutual fund managers who bought slow-selling securities for their funds from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. received what might have amounted to kickbacks - warrants for their own accounts - people close to the inquiry said yesterday.

LEAD: The children of Herman and Frances McMillan have told officials their father buried their two dead brothers in a playground a short walk from their apartment in the Bronx, not in an embankment on the Major Deegan Expressway, as Mr.
McMillan said after his arrest on Monday.


Stipanovich to Retire
LEAD: Steve Stipanovich, the Indiana Pacers center, will retire because of a ''dead spot'' in his left knee that forced him to miss all of last season, according to a published report.
The Indianapolis Star reported that an official announcement could come early next week, after Stipanovich meets with General Manager Donnie Walsh and other team officials.

LEAD: In a bid to shore up its sagging market share amid increasing competition, the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,800 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force.

Israeli Kidnapped in West Bank; Troops Seal Off and Search Town
LEAD: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers searched tonight for an Israeli jeweler who was kidnapped by several masked Palestinians this morning in the West Bank town of Tulkarm, where he had gone to collect debts, the army said.


K Mart Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of the K Mart Corporation rose $2.375, to $43.875, on market rumors that it might be taken over or restructured, traders said.
Although analysts discounted the speculation, they acknowledged that K Mart was vulnerable to a takeover. ''Bigger companies have been taken over,'' said Monroe Greenstein, an analyst with Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.

LEAD: The Commodity Exchange took disciplinary action yesterday against a trader, Preston Semel, and the firm he heads for violations of the exchange's rules and for ''disreputable and fraudulent conduct.''

Michael A. Diana, 80, Doctor and Missionary
LEAD: Dr.
Michael A. Diana, a Manhattan surgeon who served for many years as a volunteer in hospitals in Afghanistan, India and Nicaragua, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington.
He was 80 years old and lived in Ferrisburg, Vt.

Sounds Around Town
LEAD:  Doing the Fugs The Fugs, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880).
The Fugs, the once-notorious, now-venerated East Village band led by the poet Ed Sanders, still makes seriously zany mischief.
The group's show tonight is likely to include excerpts from Mr.
Sanders' anti-Pentagon opera, ''Starpeace,'' anarchistic broadsides by Tuli Kupferberg, and a medley of the group's smutty underground hits from its earliest days in the mid-1960's.


Early Draws Differ For Lendl and Graf
LEAD: If tough early-round opponents can sharpen a tennis star's game, Ivan Lendl should be in top form and Steffi Graf should be ripe for upset by the time the United States Open reaches its late stages in a couple of weeks.

LEAD: Ari Bahat, an architect who was noted for his use of glass block for furniture and interiors, died of pulmonary arrest Wednesday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

They attack three other mayoral contenders and underscore Mr.

LEAD: Alarmed by high asbestos readings in and around Gramercy Park, the New York City Health Department declared a health emergency last night and ordered tenants in a second apartment building - about eight remaining families - to evacuate their homes.


OPENING NEW ERA, POLES PICK LEADER
LEAD: Opening a fresh chapter in the nation's political life, Poland's Parliament ended more than 40 years of one-party rule today by electing Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a devout Catholic and Solidarity supporter, to be the country's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $750 million of 10-year debentures in an unscheduled offering.

Auctions
LEAD: No one pretends that golf memorabilia constitute a major field of collecting. ''There are probably 20 million golfers, and if you've got 3,500 collectors, that's good,'' said Morton W. Olman, an amateur golfer and avid collector whose Old Golf Shop in Cincinnati specializes in collectibles and emblems of golfing history.

LEAD: Behind the scenes of Voyager 2's encounter with Neptune, a family is breaking up.
Most of its members have been together 17 years through adversity and conflict, feverish creativity and sweet moments of triumph.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board today opened the door for banking companies to acquire healthy savings and loan institutions in a move that supporters said would help bring needed capital to the savings and loan industry.

LEAD: The Alcoholism Council of Greater New York is about to start telling pregnant women, ''If you choose to drink, here's to birth defects.'' In a new pro bono ad campaign scheduled to begin after Labor Day, the powerful television and outdoor advertisements play off the act of toasting in a dark and sinister way.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today awarded a $1.8 billion contract to the Martin Marietta Corporation to produce 60 fuel tanks that would power the space shuttle in the 1990's.


Interlake Promotes Official As It Fights a Takeover Bid
LEAD: In the midst of an expensive reorganization intended to ward off a takeover threat, the Interlake Corporation promoted W. Robert Reum, 47, to the post of president and chief operating officer.
Mr.
Reum, whose background is in finance, joined Interlake in 1982 as chief financial officer and was made a director in 1987, and an executive vice president last year.


New Clashes in Cambodia
LEAD: Fighting between rival Cambodian factions flared again along the Thai-Cambodian border, aid workers and Thai officials said today.
Residents reported hearing heavy exchanges in the central sector of the frontier and foreign aid workers said there had been sporadic clashes over the past five days.
The final round of peace talks on Cambodia is to open next week in Paris to try to hammer out an overall settlement before Vietnam withdraws its troops from the country by Sept.


A Ringing Defense of Mass Media
LEAD: RESPONDING to recent predictions by communications executives of the imminent demise of mass media, a leading advertising executive has issued a ringing defense of the strength of network television and other communications organs aimed at mass audiences.


Leon Becker, 70, Dies; An Acting State Justice
LEAD: Leon Becker, a lawyer and acting justice in New York State Supreme Court, died of lung cancer Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Aleksandr S. Yakovlev, who designed World War II warplanes and modern passenger jets in a career of more than 60 years, died Tuesday after a long illness, Tass said today.
He was 84 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Robert Edward Anderson, a retired advertising executive, omitted the list of his survivors.
They are his wife, Zelda, of Hico, Tex.; two daughters, Molly Garcia of San Antonio and Joan Anderson of Austin, Tex.; two sisters, Mary Gardner of Mulberry, Fla., and Ann Tracy of Lake Worth, Fla.; three brothers, Ernest, of Palm Beach Shores, Fla.; Norman, of Port Charlotte, Fla., and Joseph, of Clinton, N.Y., and 11 grandchildren.

LEAD: One day after a Federal judge rejected a request for an injunction, seven daughters and granddaughters of Confederate soldiers were moved Wednesday from the Confederate Home for Women to a new health care center.

He was 89 years old and lived in Shell Point Village, Fla.

LEAD: A 16-year-old black youth was shot to death Wednesday night in an attack by 10 to 30 white teen-agers in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD:  La Reserve Amid the hubbub and hustle of Rockefeller Center, La Reserve, as the name implies, is a sedate sanctuary.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on July 25 about seven species of North American bird that are declining misstated the views of Gregory S. Butcher, director of bird population studies at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology.
Dr.
Butcher has written a letter pointing out that he said the birds should be given immediate consideration for the Federal endangered species list; he did not say they should be listed.

Chesapeake Phone Accord
LEAD: Striking members of the Communications Workers of America reached tentative agreement today with the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company, officials said.
Agreement between the union and the Bell Atlantic Corporation was reached a week ago, but bargaining with subsidiary companies has prevented employees from returning to work.


R.D. LAING, REBEL AND PIONEER ON SCHIZOPHRENIA, IS DEAD AT 61
LEAD: R. D. Laing, the British psychiatrist who broke with traditional psychotherapy and sought new treatments for schizophrenia based on a concern for the rights of mental patients, died suddenly Wednesday while vacationing in France.
He was 61 years old.

Stena Cuts Stake In Sea Containers
LEAD: Stena A.B. has lowered its stake in Sea Containers Ltd. to 5.9 percent from 6.3 percent.
In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Stena gave no reason for the stock sale.
Stena, a Swedish ferry operator, and Tiphook P.L.C., a British cargo concern, have offered to buy Sea Containers for $63 a share, or $1.03 billion.

Federal-Mogul Corp., an auto parts manufacturer, announced the completion of a $150 million revolving credit facility with 10 domestic and foreign banks.

LEAD: L.M.
Ericsson A.B., the giant Swedish telecommunications company, said yesterday that it and the General Electric Company would form a joint venture to produce cellular telephones, mobile radio equipment and communication systems.

Washington Journal; Driving on the Beltway Is Life in the Slow Lane
LEAD: Here in the nation's capital, you can be ''inside the Beltway'' or ''outside the Beltway.'' Or you can be on the Beltway.
The last is where you don't want to be.


Williams Revises Primerica Merger
LEAD: The Primerica Corporation and the A. L. Williams Corporation said a special committee of Williams's independent directors had approved the revised terms of the proposed merger of the two companies.
Under the revision, 82-hundredths of a Primerica share will be exchanged for each Williams share.
The previous exchange ratio was 80-hundredths of a share.


Club-Wielding Police in Kiev Attack Protest on 1939 Pact
LEAD: Policemen with riot sticks attacked demonstrators in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, on Wednesday, wounding dozens of them, to break up a protest marking the 50th anniversary of the 1939 German-Soviet pact dividing Eastern Europe, protesters said today.


Crenshaw Avoids Pond and Takes Lead
LEAD: Ten years ago, Ben Crenshaw had a real hacker's experience playing the par-5 16th hole at the Firestone Country Club's South Course: he took an 11.
This happened during the 1979 World Series of Golf as Crenshaw put three balls in the pond fronting the green at that renowned 625-yard hole.

Paul McCartney Gets Ready to Take It on the Road
LEAD: Outside the Lyceum Theater late Wednesday afternoon, a crowd of Paul McCartney fans, many too young to have known the Beatles when they were a going concern, gathered behind police barricades to catch a glimpse of the 47-year-old songwriter making his way from the stage door to his limousine.
Mr.
McCartney had been rehearsing with his new band at the theater on West 45th Street in Manhattan.


Treasury Prices Little Changed
LEAD: Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged yesterday as trading activity slackened after the Government wound up its auctions this week of more than $40 billion of new debt issues.
Dealers said that with the bulk of the new issues now in retail portfolios, many market makers considered it time for a vacation.

LEAD: The Bronx Arts Ensemble and members of Repertorio Espanol are to perform excerpts from Francisco-Asenjo Barbieri's ''Barberillo de Lavapies'' (''Merry Barber of Laviapies''), a zarzuela, on Sunday at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle, Van Cortlandt Park near Broadway and Mosholu Avenue, in the Bronx.

Top Executive Named By Nikko's U.S. Unit
LEAD: Nikko Securities International, the American arm of Japan's third-largest securities firm, named Hideo Suzuki chairman and chief executive yesterday.
He replaces Toshio Mori, who will return to Japan after seven years at the head of the unit.
The change was not a surprise.
Mr.
Suzuki, who has overall responsiblity, and Tsuneo Iida, the new president, who will manage day-to-day operations, have been in New York since September 1988.

LEAD: The election of a non-Communist Prime Minister in Poland has confronted the Bush Administration with a conflicting set of challenges and opportunities, which, for now, have combined to produce a strikingly restrained American response to what could be a turning point in East-West relations.

War Continues for Vietnam Refugees
LEAD: Some of the last skirmishes of the Vietnam War are being fought, sometimes with words and occasionally with bullets, within the sharply fragmented Vietnamese refugee population of the United States.


Finley on Disabled List
LEAD: Tests on Chuck Finley's injured left foot were inconclusive but the pitcher will be placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to Tuesday, the team announced yesterday.

LEAD: Richard Dortch, former vice president of the PTL television ministry, was sentenced today to eight years in prison and a $200,000 fine for helping to bilk millions of dollars from the ministry's followers.

Henszey &amp; Albert Gains
LEAD: With the appointment of Henszey &amp; Albert to handle advertising promotion for The New York Post, the 16-month-old agency has quickly rolled up more than $11 million in annual billings.
The budget for The Post has not been set, but the agency estimated that it would be at least $1 million.
And just yesterday, Henszey &amp; Albert won another new piece of business: Carol Dauplaise, a costume jewelry manufacturer, worth another $500,000.


As a Treat, Walk 897 Steps
LEAD: For centuries, vandals have scratched their initials in the stones of great monuments or chipped pieces as souvenirs.
So, too, at the Washington Monument, where visitors are not allowed to use the stairs because of damage to the stones in the 555-foot obelisk.

LEAD: The stock market surged to historic highs yesterday, as investors focused on declining interest rates and the rising dollar and put memories of the 1987 crash further behind them.

''Open House,'' which joins Sunday's Channel 5 lineup at 9:30 P.M., lives up uncompromisingly to its unpromise.

Jersey Sewer Bonds Yield Up to 7.29%
LEAD: A $124.99 million sewer revenue bond issue by the Hoboken-Union City-Weehawken Sewerage Authority in New Jersey was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
The tax-exempt issue offers investors a maximum yield of about 7.29 percent for an issue due in 2019.
For shorter maturities, the issue includes serial bonds that yield from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1994 to 6.85 percent for those due in 1999.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a speech by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney on the military budget incorrectly characterized his comments about his former colleagues in the House.
He criticized them for shifting funds from programs given priority by President Bush to programs favored by members of the House, not for cutting the budget.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 463 money market mutual funds increased by $2.68 billion, to $343.22 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $51 million, to $85.58 billion.
The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds rose $1.04 billion, to $109.78 billion.


Soviet Congratulations Sent To New Premier of Poland
LEAD: The Soviet Union moved quickly today to establish cordial relations with the new Polish Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, and introduced the Solidarity adviser to the public here as a political novelty but not a threat to the current order in Eastern Europe.


Diner's Journal
LEAD:  K-Paul's Future


A Ford Shutdown
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said its Chicago assembly plant would end production of 1989-model Taurus and Sable cars on Sept. 1, a week earlier than planned, because orders from its dealers had dropped.
The company said the 2,500 employees there would return to work on Sept. 11, the first day of production of the 1990 models.


Son of Loews Chairman Advances at Lorillard
LEAD: Andrew H. Tisch climbed another step in the family business yesterday, becoming chairman and chief executive of Lorillard Inc., the tobacco company owned by the Loews Corporation.
Mr.
Tisch, 40, is the son of Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of Loews, and the nephew of its president, Preston R. Tisch.


Coffee and Sugar Plunge; Copper Prices Up Sharply
LEAD: Prices of coffee futures fell sharply yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York on news that Brazil will not reintroduce its coffee retention program.
On other markets, copper was up sharply and sugar prices plunged.


Review/Music; Rick Astley's British Soul
LEAD: Among the artists whose recording careers have been nurtured by the English songwriting and producing team of Stock-Aitken-Waterman, Rick Astley, who performed at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening, may be the most promising.


High-Level Officials of U.S. and Colombia Meet on Drug Issue
LEAD: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger met today with Colombia's Foreign Minister to discuss the tide of drug-related violence in Colombia and its latest efforts to combat narcotics traffickers.
