Trident II Doesn't Fly
LEAD: An unarmed Trident II missile recently flew out of control during a test launch and exploded.


Reviews/Film; 'Wired,' in Which Belushi Hails a Cabbie From Heaven
LEAD: Unlike the grimly detailed Bob Woodward book on which it is based, the movie ''Wired'' seems to want to be an upbeat, funny, maybe even life-affirming biography of John Belushi, the television and screen comedian who died of a drug overdose seven years ago at the age of 33.


Gasps for the Big Sloops
LEAD: Sailors who have grown up with fairy tale stories of the golden age of yachting had the chance today to see it for themselves.
For the first time in half a century, two J-class sloops that once competed for the America's Cup returned here to race again.


Mr. Giamatti Plays by the Rules
LEAD: Baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti said yesterday, is an enduring American institution ''with a purchase on our national soul,'' and is thus under special obligation to uphold integrity and fair play.
The Commissioner's decision to banish Pete Rose from baseball for life, and the deliberate manner in which he reached it, stoutly reaffirm those ideals.


Snag in Nuclear Arms Plant Settlement
LEAD: A dispute is threatening to wreck a $78 million settlement in a case that marked the first Federal acknowledgment that a nuclear weapons plant might have harmed people who live near it.


McCann's Hilton Work
LEAD: The Hilton Hotel Corporation sweetened its relationship with McCann-Erickson yesterday to the tune of $5 million.
The company awarded the account for its Flamingo Hilton hotels in Nevada to the Los Angeles office of McCann, which has been its agency of record since 1967.
McCann will create advertising for three hotels in Nevada: the Flamingo-Hilton Reno, the Flamingo Hilton-Laughlin and the giant Flamingo Hilton on the Las Vegas strip.


3 Radio Stations Face F.C.C. Disciplinary Action
LEAD: Three radio stations face Federal Communications Commission action for allegedly airing indecent broadcasts during daytime hours, the agency said Thursday.


Review/Film; El Salvador's Slain Hero Of the Cloth
LEAD: ''Romero'' is an earnest, straightforward reconstruction of the life, political education and assassination of Oscar Arnulfo Romero, the liberal Archbishop of San Salvador, as he was celebrating Mass in 1980.


Bankers Trust Preferred Stock
LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is offering $250 million of fixed- and adjustable-rate preferred stock through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
Proceeds from the sale will be used to make an equity investment in its wholly owned subsidiary, the BT Securities Corporation.


ABC Names Anchor For Sunday Program
LEAD: Forrest Sawyer, a co-anchor of the ABC News program ''World News This Morning,'' has been named an anchor of ''World News Sunday.'' He will replace Sam Donaldson, who has been the news anchor of the program since its premiere 10 years ago.

Pete Rose Got What He Deserved
LEAD: The evidence is that Pete Rose never knows when to stop.
He would bet and he would bet until he owed too much money, and then somebody would cut off Rose's credit or even threaten ''to burn my house down and break my kid's legs if I didn't pay him,'' as Rose has admitted under oath.

About Real Estate; A Troubled Port Chester Project's Second Effort
LEAD: To create an apartment with a loft area, a builder needs residential spaces with tall ceilings.
At the old green and white Life Savers building on Route 1 in Port Chester, N.Y., which a developer was turning into condominiums, the ceilings turned out to be lower than expected.
Because of that, the offering plan had to be amended last year and most of the 170 original buyers backed out of their contracts.


DOW AND REASON: DISTANT COUSINS?
LEAD: When the Dow talks, Wall Street listens.
And yesterday many traders thought they heard a shout of confidence in the economy.

All That Jazz: Who, What, Where and When
LEAD: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival begins today and runs through Sept. 4.
For ticket information, call the individual clubs.
A $15 pass available at Sweet Basil and the Village Gate will allow 50 percent discounts on music charges; table minimums will still apply.
Here is a schedule of events (only the first sets are listed) and locations.


Guest List of the Masters Who Summer at the Met
LEAD: EVERY summer, while their owners spend a few months in the South of France or some similar locale, paintings by artists like Canaletto, Gauguin and Rembrandt take up residence on the walls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
These seasonal guests are distinguishable from works in the permanent collection only by labels that describe them in small print as belonging to an anonymous collector, although it is impossible for the casual observer to know which of the paintings are on long-term loan and which are just passing through.


FOLEY DENIES CONGRESS IS NAIVE ON SOVIET PERIL
LEAD: Taking issue with a stinging attack by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney over military spending priorities, Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley denied today that his colleagues were underestimating the Soviet military threat.


DRUG TRAFFICKERS IN COLOMBIA START A COUNTERATTACK
LEAD: Striking back against a Government crackdown, drug traffickers dynamited offices of the nation's two largest political parties today, burned the houses of two politicians, placed bombs in two radio stations and issued a communique declaring war on the Government.

The museum will screen the commercials from Sept. 5 to Jan. 6.

PASSING NEPTUNE, VOYAGER FINISHES A 12-YEAR MISSION
LEAD: Out in the twilight of the solar system, far from the warmth of the Sun and the vitality of Earth, Voyager 2 cruised over the cold blue clouds of Neptune tonight, its cameras snapping pictures and its sensors gathering data on the composition and dynamic forces of the giant planet.


2d Rebel Group Joins Carter's Ethiopia Talks
LEAD: A second Ethiopian rebel group said today that it had accepted former President Jimmy Carter's offer to play a role in peace talks with the Marxist Government in Addis Ababa.


Dale Berra Is Indicted
LEAD: Twenty-five people, including the former major league infielder Dale Berra, have been indicted in connection with a five-county drug raid, officials said.


U.S. Worried Over Fighting in Angola
LEAD: The cease-fire declared in Angola two months ago is crumbling, and American officials expressed concern today about increased fighting between Government forces and guerrillas there.


Review/Reggae; Soul Vibrations at S.O.B.'s
LEAD: Across the third world, reggae is the international musical language -even in Nicaragua, the home of Soul Vibrations.
The seven-piece band, which adds timbales to a standard reggae lineup, played heartfelt, assured, tuneful reggae on Tuesday at S.O.B.'s.
Except for a song in Spanish, the lyrics were in English, and the word that kept popping up was ''history.


London Journal; Fun or Profit? Black Festival Tries to Have Both
LEAD: At the Flamboyan, where culture and community are celebrated in a whirl of glitter, life is a masquerade.


Cargo Door Latches Sought
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board has recommended the use of ''fail-safe'' mechanisms on airliner cargo door latches to prevent the doors from popping open in flight and to assure that they are properly closed before takeoff.


Review/Film; Cat and Dog Are Friends In a Tale of Real Animals
LEAD: In ''The Adventures of Milo and Otis,'' the Japanese author and film maker Masanori Hata's tale of the friendship between a golden-haired cat named Milo and a snub-nosed dog named Otis, the camera contemplates the world with the wide-eyed curiosity of a child.


Review/Film; Hackman And Chicago In 'Package,' A Thriller
LEAD: ''The Package'' is a feeble attempt to keep the old-fashioned cold-war thriller alive in this era of glasnost.


Court Backs Extraditing Greek
LEAD: A fugitive Greek banker who faces embezzlement charges that helped bring down the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou may be extradited to Greece, a Federal magistrate ruled today.

Review/Film; A Woman In Rebellion And the Life She Hates
LEAD: It would be easy to wrap ''The Little Thief'' in nostalgia, to treasure it as the last legacy of Francois Truffaut.
Before his death in 1984, Truffaut had written, with Claude de Givray, a brief scenario for the story of Janine, a neglected, spirited, imaginative adolescent of the 1950's.
He had invented the girl more than 20 years before as Antoine Doinel's companion in ''The 400 Blows,'' but had cut the character from that film and carried her image to the end of his life.

LEAD: Even without the ponytail, 36-year-old Harry Jameson does not look the part of a corporate mover and shaker.
He wears faded jeans that got there the hard way, without stone-washing, a T-shirt that left its sleeves at home, granny glasses and the kind of boots you use for pouring cement.

What's at the Modern? All the New That Endured
LEAD: AT this moment, the Museum of Modern Art has no major loan exhibition.
Helen Frankenthaler has just been taken down.

KOCH'S CAMPAIGN: THE MAYOR AS UNDERDOG
LEAD: The man who once seemed a candidate to be mayor for life spent much of a recent dank day walking through Hispanic neighborhoods, looking for votes and dodging the rain.
By his third stop, La Caridad restaraunt in upper Manhattan, Mayor Edward I. Koch had honed an almost plaintive appeal.

LEAD: The chief lawyer for Leona Helmsley implored the jury yesterday to ''end the long, terrible suffering of Mrs.
Helmsley'' and ''let her walk out of this courtroom a free woman.''


Fewer Women in Parliaments
LEAD: Women are finding it harder to get into parliament, the Inter-Parliamentary Union said today.
The group said the percentage of women in the world's legislatures fell to 12.7 percent in mid-1989, down from 14.6 percent at the beginning of 1988.
In 1975, the first year of the United Nations' Decade for Women, the figure was 12.5 percent.

BASS P.L.C. TO ACQUIRE HOLIDAY INN
LEAD: The Holiday Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Holiday Inn hotel chain to Bass P.L.C., a British brewer with interests in the restaurant and lodging industries.
Bass will pay Holiday's shareholders $125 million in Bass stock and assume about $2.1 billion of debt.

King and Jones, the defending champion, were the first twosome to complete play in the select international field of 16 golfers competing for a first prize of $83,500 from the $265,000 purse.(AP)

The Challenge in Bensonhurst
LEAD: Add the name of Yusef Hawkins, a black youth from Brooklyn, to the list of victims, black and white, of racial violence in New York City.
The growing list challenges the city's political and moral leadership, but first and foremost it challenges law enforcement.
In that sense, Mayor Koch's call for a special prosecutor is premature.

Ex-Governor Sells Used Cars
LEAD: Former Gov.
Ray Blanton, who served a two-year prison term for extortion after leaving office in 1979, has taken a job selling used cars and trucks.
The 60-year-old Mr.
Blanton said he has been in training at Bolton Ford-Mercury for about two weeks. ''I'm healthy as a horse, broke, but not broken,'' he said Tuesday.


Helms Managing Reds
LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds appointed Coach Tommy Helms as interim manager today.
Helms will run the club while the Reds look for a permanent replacement for Pete Rose.

LEAD: The Westchester District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today that a grand jury investigating allegations of corruption at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park in Rye has found no evidence so far linking political contributions to favored treatment in awarding contracts.

LEAD: Herbert Vogler, a Broadway stage manager, died of AIDS Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

GENERIC-DRUG GUIDELINES SEEN LACKING AT F.D.A.
LEAD: Some makers of generic drugs received preferential treatment in the Food and Drug Administration's approval process because the agency failed to establish adequate guidelines for reviewing the drugs, a new Federal report says.


Economic Scene; Reasons to Fear A Recession
LEAD: THE pickup in retail sales and employment has led the Federal Reserve to stop easing monetary policy for the present.
But anxieties about the risk of the economic slowdown's turning into a recession will keep pressures on the Fed from the White House, Congress and private business to push interest rates down further.


HARVARD WILL SELL A FOREST, A LEGACY FROM AN ALUMNUS
LEAD: After years of uneasiness over the fate of Harvard's Black Rock Forest, the university has agreed to sell the land to a private foundation that will lease it to a consortium of 15 scientific and educational institutions.

Review/Theater; Guided Missives, In 2-Person Gurney Play
LEAD: In ''Love Letters,'' A. R. Gurney has written an evocative epistolary account of two charter members of the privileged set.
In less than two hours, we see Andrew Makepeace Ladd 3d and Melissa Gardner over a period of 50 years, as the author carries them from second grade through the trauma of adulthood, marriage, divorce and middle age.

Before Our Eyes, the Bloc Splinters
LEAD: By the day, almost by the hour, the cold war's tides recede ever further and old assumptions founder.
The West has grown accustomed to Mikhail Gorbachev's startling changes in the Soviet Union.
It was known that the rigidities in Eastern Europe would soften.
But the pace of change just this week defies Western imagination.


SoHo Theater Delayed
LEAD: The Angelika Film Center, a six-screen SoHo movie theater, will not open today as had been announced.
Ted Albert, a spokesman for the theater, which is at Mercer and Houston Streets, said the owners hope to open it within the next few weeks.
The opening has been delayed several times.


IS 1989 LIKE 1987? NO, BY MOST ANY MEASURE
LEAD: Although the Dow Jones industrial average reached a high yesterday, Wall Street remains a far more subdued place than it was at the 1987 peak.
Enthusiasm for stocks is far less, brokerage house profits are down, and many of the thousands of people laid off by Wall Street have not returned to the industry.


Arthur F. Ackerman, Pediatrician, Dies at 85
LEAD: Dr.
Arthur F. Ackerman, a pediatrician, died Sunday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J.
He was 85 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.


Dinkins Is Endorsed By Two Gay Groups
LEAD: Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins yesterday accepted the endorsement of two gay political groups in his race for the Democratic mayoral nomination, saying he would fight for legal recognition of gay and lesbian domestic partnerships.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Driving a Child Safely
LEAD:  For all car travel, even short trips to and from the local grocery or pool, the safest way to transport young children is in a safety seat in the rear of the car.
Small children, usually up to the age of 4, are required by law in every state to ride in approved seats designed for children, and the seats must be secured by safety belts.


Giuliani, on the Stump and on the Phone
LEAD: There are two Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigns for mayor - the public speeches and street campaigning, and the much more difficult private hours on the telephone or at small gatherings trying to raise money in a mostly Democratic city.


Fed Voted for Lower Interest Rates
LEAD: The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted to nudge interest rates lower in July, but they worried about reigniting inflation by going too far, according to a summary of the meeting that was released today.

John Nelson Resigns As Caramoor Director
LEAD: John Nelson has resigned as the music director of the Caramoor Music Festival, the management announced yesterday.

A decision as to a replacement has not yet been made.


Animal Eye-Test Data Is Useless for Humans
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Women's Movement: Here to Stay
LEAD: ''I'm not one of those women's libbers.'' The sentence sounds like a joke now, a laugh-getter out of ''All in the Family.'' But not so long ago it was a sentiment shared by millions.
Many men felt they had nothing to gain from feminism - and many women felt they had everything to lose.
To the latter, the women's movement that began in the 1960's was more a threat than a promise.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a kidnapping and other developments in Israel and the occupied territories characterized the shooting death of a Palestinian-American youth incorrectly.
The youth, Amjad Hussein Jabril, was the first American shot and killed there since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987; at least two Americans have died in other circumstances related to the conflict.

LEAD: The State of Texas is wagering that there is something drug dealers fear more than prison: the tax collector.

LEAD: Thailand's stock market, fueled by optimism over the country's surging economy, has reached record highs.

Most analysts see further advances over the next month.

The Lap-Top Computer Goes to College
LEAD: As students stream back to colleges across the country, a good many will be carrying lap-top computers in their gear.
These were once expensive gadgets with limited use in business, but for $1,000 or so they now compete in price and power with full-size personal computers.


Computer Maker's Glamour Fades
LEAD: Klaus Luft, the chairman of Nixdorf Computer A.G., was given a tough act to follow when he unexpectedly succeeded Heinz Nixdorf, the founder of the West German computer concern, as chairman in March 1986.


Energy Chief Rebuffs Ohio Judge
LEAD: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that he would reject a Federal judge's request that he join a dispute in Ohio on the terms of a proposed $78 million pollution settlement between the department and neighbors of the nuclear weapons plant in the town of Fernald.

Lewis Conn, 73, Business Publications Head
LEAD: Lewis Conn, a former newspaper publisher and labor union leader, died after life support systems were removed from him at the request of the family Tuesday at the Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis, Md.


Police Statistics Show a Drop in Bias Crimes
LEAD: Bias crimes in New York City have dropped in the last year, according to statistics from the Police Department's bias incident investigating unit.


New Data On Steroid Use by Olympians
LEAD: More than 50 male athletes who competed in the Olympics last fall in Seoul, South Korea, have been found to have used anabolic steroids in the six months before the Games.


Woman Gets High Post After Tokyo Aide Quits
LEAD: Japan's new Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, chose a woman for one of the country's top Cabinet posts today in a scramble to quell yet another sex scandal engulfing the governing party.

Despair Comes Twice To a Brooklyn Family
LEAD: For Sharon Sylvester, a 23-year-old nurse's aide, the killing of Yusef Hawkins in Bensonhurst has been a cumulative blow, a final proof of racism that, she says, will drive her from New York despite the promise of good pay that drew her here.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Wet Soil
LEAD: It has been a wet year.
Lawns have seldom been greener, and trees and shrubs have grown like weeds.
But flower and vegetable gardens have been the victims.
Most of the vegetable crops along the East Coast are late.


Your Money; Helping Students Learn to Budget
LEAD: Going to college is the first big step into an adult world for most students, and not all of the lessons are academic.
Some concern day-to-day financial responsibilities.


California Educators Taking New Leaf From Book Exchange
LEAD: When the boxloads of books forced her husband's car out of the driveway and into the street, it was time for Marilyn Levin Nemzer to make a decision about her new project.


Cocoa, Grains and Oil Drop; Copper Reaches New Highs
LEAD: Cocoa futures prices plunged yesterday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange as traders looked ahead to next month's meeting of the International Cocoa Organization in London with an expectation of failure.


Gramercy Is Worried as Asbestos Cleanup Begins
LEAD: As anxious residents pressed vainly for information about what was happening to their neighborhood, Consolidated Edison workers and a team of toxic-waste specialists yesterday began vacuuming asbestos-contaminated mud from a 100-yard zone of streets, sidewalks and stoops in Gramercy Park.


Smith Hires Smith As a Rangers Coach
LEAD: Ron Smith, a former assistant coach of four National Hockey League teams, was named assistant coach of the Rangers yesterday.
The announcement was made by Neil Smith, the team's vice president and general manager.


Ex-Lawyer Is Jailed in Impeachment Case
LEAD: William Borders, a once-prominent defense lawyer who is now disbarred, was jailed today for refusing to answer the questions of a Senate committee in the impeachment case against Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings.


4-Day Workweek Plan at Chrysler
LEAD: Members of the United Automobile Workers at a Chrysler Corporation plant here have voted to allow the union to start bargaining with the company over a four-day workweek, the union said.
If the plan is approved, the mini-van assembly plant would become the first Chrysler plant in the United States to operate on such a system.


CONTINENTAL'S FUTURE NEEDS SAID TO PROMPT IDEA FOR SALE
LEAD: An adviser to Frank Lorenzo said yesterday that the Texas Air Corporation's chairman had decided to give serious consideration to the sale of Continental Airlines primarily because he thinks the parent company will find it difficult to afford the investment needed to keep the carrier competitive with the huge airlines forming under deregulation.


Horror-Film Publicity Horrifies Recipents
LEAD: Hundreds of video rental shops today received promotional kits for a horror movie that included live garter snakes, and outraged animal-protection officials called the stunt ''cruel and irresponsible.''


In Russia of 1800's, Reform Benefited the Czar; Glasnost Then and Now
LEAD: To the Editor:


Shells Hit Beirut Again as Envoys Seek Cease-Fire
LEAD: Beirut resounded with the crash of artillery and rocket fire again today as Lebanon's warring factions ignored new diplomatic efforts to arrange a cease-fire.


Eugene Robel, 78, Dies; Fought a Security Act
LEAD: Eugene Frank Robel a labor advocate who won a Supreme Court ruling against a law that barred Communists from working in military plants, was killed when he was struck by a train last Sunday.
He was 78 years old.

OPPOSITION LEADER INDICTED IN SEOUL
LEAD: The opposition leader Kim Dae Jung and two legislators in his party were indicted today on charges stemming from a lawmaker's secret and illegal trip to Communist North Korea.

Valvano Is Asked to Quit as Athletic Director
LEAD: The president of North Carolina's public university system today asked Jim Valvano to resign as athletic director at North Carolina State because an investigation of the school's basketball program had revealed extensive academic abuses that broke ''the spirit, not the letter of the law.''


Conner Signs Contract
LEAD: After signing a four-year contract yesterday, Lester Conner said he felt confident the Nets would be a playoff contender next season.
Conner, who was a free agent, also had contract discussions with Milwaukee, Cleveland, Denver, Houston and Indiana.
But Conner, a 29-year-old point guard, wanted to return to New Jersey.


Missing Denver Police Officer Surfaces


Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 28 about applicants for Federal housing grants contributing to Sen.
Alfonse M. D'Amato's campaigns misstated the role of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, L.I.
Individuals and companies working on housing projects sponsored by the diocese contributed; the diocese did not.


Reluctant Texas Judge Allows Use of Confederate Symbols
LEAD: A high school in a Dallas suburb can continue to use Confederate symbols for its sports teams after a Federal judge ruled that the symbols are legal, even though they may be distressing.


Salman Rushdie and Wife Living Apart
LEAD: Salman Rushdie, the British author who has been living under an Iranian death threat since February, and his American wife, the novelist Marianne Wiggins, have separated.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about Mayor Edward I. Koch's campaigning in the Bronx misidentified a center for the elderly.
It was the Castle Hill Senior Citizens Center, not the Parkchester HAND Senior Citizens Center, which he also visited.


Sex, Lies and Commercials
LEAD: On a recent Saturday, a New Yorker tired of summer prime-time television braved the lines to get a seat for ''Sex, Lies and Videotape.'' What she got instead was a shock.
No sooner had she settled into her seat than there appeared an all-too-familiar American Express ad, big-screen-sized and in stereo.


G.E. Job Cuts In Louisville
LEAD: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would lay off 500 factory workers in Louisville, Ky., in October because of the sharp decline in appliance sales.


One Hat Too Many
LEAD: When the Citizens Union of the City of New York announced its choices this week in the upcoming primary elections, the spokesman for the 92-year-old organization was its chairman, Robert F. Wagner Jr.
It is a decidedly incongruous role for the president of the city's Board of Education.


No NASA Delay of the Shuttle
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration says it has no plans to ask the Defense Department to delay one of its space shuttle missions so that the rescue of an errant satellite can take place in November rather than December.


Lofty Dow Gives Individuals Pause
LEAD: Only two years after the frenzied bull market days of 1987, the stock market has scaled new peaks, but the euphoria is gone.
Retail investment still trails the 1987 record.


About New York; Reject All Limits: A Blind Athlete Competes Boldly
LEAD: A guide dog would have seen the danger and prevented Tony Candela from walking into a bent traffic sign Thursday morning, an accident that left a nasty gash in his forehead.
His cane provides surveillance only of the lower altitudes.


Soybean Case Pleas Entered
LEAD: Two soybean traders and a clerk pleaded guilty today to charges of improper trading practices, while 12 other people pleaded not guilty to charges arising from the Government's investigation of practices at the world's largest futures exchanges.


Police Unit in Namibia Not 'Paramilitary'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Saturday News Quiz
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 46. 1.
A card that, to the surprise of many, is off-white in color will soon have a pinkish tinge.
What card is it and what is at issue? 2.
According to research, the greater the height from which a cat falls, the more likely its chance of survival.


Recollections of Green: A Sprinkling of Regrets
LEAD: Some people have suggested that New York City, its pressures and politics, even its polluted air, hastened the death of Dr.
Richard R. Green, the Schools Chancellor, three months ago at 52 years of age.
But while Gwendolyn Green says that perhaps too much was expected of her husband she feels no bitterness, only pained regret over what he might have done.


Reports of Mercenaries in Colombia Worry Israel
LEAD: The Israeli Government is trying to distance itself from Israeli mercenaries who were reported to have been supervising Colombian drug traffickers' assassination squads.


Cineplex Odeon
LEAD: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had agreed to buy 56 Canadian movie theaters with a total of 153 movie screens from Carena Developments Ltd. for $55.3 million.
The 56 theaters are part of a group of 57 theaters that Cineplex had sold to Carena in September 1988 for $51.4 million.
Cineplex had continued to operate the theaters.

City Council Members Ought to Be Full Time
LEAD: To the Editor:


Stocks Fail To Extend Advance
LEAD: Stock prices slipped yesterday, as weaker bond prices and profit taking after Thursday's record-setting close squelched a feeble attempt to extend the rally, which left the widely watched Dow Jones industrial average with a net gain of 44.39 points for the week, to 2,732.36.


Shakeup From Housing Police Drug Arrests
LEAD: In the wake of last week's arrest of two New York City Housing Authority police officers on drug and robbery charges, the third-ranking officer in the housing police has retired and four senior officers have been transferred.


However, He Belongs In the Hall
LEAD: Bob Welch, Oakland pitcher, was watching Bart Giamatti and Pete Rose on television the other afternoon when a momentous thought occurred to him: There might be something in this for the kid.


Mattingly Flails at Plate As Yanks Fail Once More
LEAD: Don Mattingly showered and dressed, but the frustration did not wash away.
He struck out three times last night, and the Yankees lost again.
When the night was done, their new manager even suggested that some players were pressing.


Davis Details Money Plan For UAL Bid
LEAD: Marvin Davis said yesterday that he would be willing to commit $1 billion of his family's money and that he hoped to arrange $7 billion in bank loans to finance his $6.2 billion proposal to buy UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines.
He asked UAL's board to reply by next Thursday.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 26, 1989
LEAD:  Markets


CINCINNATI HEADLINES ARE ALL ROSE
LEAD: Despite all the assurances to the contrary, the sun did not rise here today.
In fact, it has not been out since the baseball commissioner, A. Bartlett Giamatti, announced Thursday morning that a baseball icon, Pete Rose, had been banned from the game.


Home Resale Rise Posted
LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in July, posting the first back-to-back increase after high mortgage rates produced consecutive declines in the first five months of 1989, a real estate trade group said today.


Jail Term in Horses' Deaths
LEAD: A Plymouth, Conn., man convicted of starving his four horses to death has been sentenced to one year in prison, but prison overcrowding may result in his release after 10 days, the authorities said today.
The man, Raymond M. Bilosz, 56 years old, was also fined $750, and he must pay $1,350 in burial and veterinary fees and $200 in probation costs.


Mortgage Rate Rises
LEAD: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 10.21 percent for the week ended today, from 10.09 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.
The average adjustable-rate mortgage was 8.69 percent, unchanged from the previous week, the agency said.


Music School's Rule Found Discriminatory
LEAD: A music school's requirement that students sight-read music before being allowed to graduate discriminated against the blind, the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights has ruled.


Anchor Glass Named In Suit
LEAD: A class action suit has been filed against the Anchor Glass Container Corporation over its rejection of a $280 million takeover proposal from Vitro S.A.
The shareholder suit, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, seeks to block Anchor Glass from taking any defensive action to thwart the Vitro tender offer.


Giants vs. Jets: Sort First, Win Later
LEAD: The Giants will play the Jets Saturday night, a matchup that once excited every pro football loyalist in the metropolitan area.
This time, midway through the preseason, winning will be secondary to sorting.


Taiwan to Let U.S. Monitor Drift-Net Fishing Practices
LEAD: The Government of Taiwan, seeking to avoid threatened trade sanctions, has agreed to allow American observers to board its fishing vessels to monitor huge drift nets, which kill marine animals and sea birds.


Singer Elects Chairman
LEAD: The Singer Company said today that Walter A. Drexel had been elected chairman.
Mr.
Drexel was most recently vice chairman of Burlington Northern Inc.
Singer said Paul A. Bilzerian had resigned as chairman June 29.
In June, Mr.
Bilzerian was convicted of securities fraud.


Salespeople Are Getting Incentives for Service
LEAD: The fall shopping season is just about here and commission selling in department stores is likely to be a big part of it.


Nortek Clearance On Federal-Mogul
LEAD: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said Nortek Inc. had received antitrust clearance from the Federal Trade Commission to acquire more than $15 million worth of its stock.
Barry Murphy, investor relations officer for Federal-Mogul, said his company did not know how many shares Nortek owns, but that $15 million worth would represent about 2.5 percent of the company.


U.S. Clears Eastern Air On Safety
LEAD: The Government has concluded that a walkout by machinists, pilots and flight attendants has not affected the safety of Eastern Airlines' flights.


U.S. GIVING BOGOTA $65 MILLION IN AID TO FIGHT DRUG WAR
LEAD: President Bush said today that he would send $65 million in emergency aid to Colombia to help fight the drug dealers who have declared war on the Colombian Government.


Shrinking Pagers
LEAD: James Bond has had toys like these for years, but in the real world, wristwatch communications systems are brand new.
Motorola Inc. and the Timex Corporation have now introduced what they call the world's smallest pager.

LEAD: In his first summit meeting since becoming Acting President of South Africa, F. W. de Klerk met here today with President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire for discussions that focused on how to rescue the foundering cease-fire in Angola.

M.T.A. Turns Down Volume On Subway Platform Music
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to forbid musicians and others from using amplifiers on New York City subway platforms, saying the excessive noise they produce can ''interfere with transit operations'' - not to mention drive some people crazy.


At Hamlet, Crowd Sees Why Lendl Is the King
LEAD: Designed to give players a chance to hone their skills just before the United States Open - and fans a chance to watch the stars at close range - the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup has been serving its dual purpose well this week.


Gains for U.S. Securities Erased by Late Selling
LEAD: Late selling sent the prices of Treasury securities tumbling yesterday.
The sales, which dealers said came in two waves, quickly erased the modest gains posted early in the session, which were attributed largely to European demand.


Free Dance Performances
LEAD: Dancemobile is to present the Charles Moore Dance Company in free outdoor performances Aug. 29 through Sept. 2.
The company will present dances by George Faison and Gary DeLoatch.
Performances are to be at 8:30 P.M. on Tuesday at Balcom Avenue between Dewey and Schley Avenues, in the Bronx; on Wednesday at Springfield Park, 147th Avenue between 183d and 184th Streets, in Queens; on Thursday at Grant's Tomb, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, Manhattan; on Friday at Manhattanville Houses, 133d Street and Old Broadway, Manhattan; on Saturday on 115th Street between Manhattan and Morningside


Abducted Israeli Man Found Alive in a Well
LEAD: After a wide search using troops and helicopters, soldiers found an Israeli jeweler alive and healthy today at the bottom of a 20-foot well in a West Bank village, a day after he was kidnapped by masked Palestinians, the army said.


New Data on Steroids Used Before Olympics
LEAD: An Olympic official said that a more sophisticated examination of 1,100 urine samples has shown that more than 50 male athletes who took part in the Games last fall at Seoul, South Korea, were found to have used anabolic steroids in the six months before the Games.
Article, page 43.


Voyager Thrills Scientists in Farewell to Solar System
LEAD: Speeding away from its fourth and last planetary encounter, Voyager 2 today left jubilant scientists agog as they viewed new photographs showing in dazzling clarity Neptune and especially its largest moon, Triton, where frozen lakes and ridges bespeak a past of slow-flowing icy volcanism never before seen in the solar system.


Fool Me Twice, Shame On Me
LEAD: Ronald Reagan ended the political usefulness of paranoia when he won election by promising to save the country from government, then failed to do it.


ARREST IN MURDER OF HUEY NEWTON
LEAD: A man described by police as a drug dealer has admitted killing Huey P. Newton, the co-founder of the Black Panthers, the police said tonight.


On Issues For Women, It's a Matter Of Nuances
LEAD: On women's rights and family issues, it may well be hard to tell some of the mayoral candidates apart.


Charles Impaglia, PBS Programmer, 39
LEAD: Charles Impaglia, director of program scheduling for the Public Broadcasting Service, died of AIDS on Sunday at the Hospice of Washington.
He was 39 years old.

Woodward Is Next for Easy Goer
LEAD: Easy Goer, who won the Travers at Saratoga last Saturday, will make his next start in the Woodward Handicap at Belmont Park on Sept. 16, his handlers announced today.
That decision means that any rematch between Easy Goer and Sunday Silence will not happen until at least November.


U.S. Embassy Reports Torture In Burmese Jails
LEAD: The American Embassy in Myanmar, formerly Burma, says it has ''credible, first-hand reports'' of routine and sometimes fatal mistreatment of pro-democracy figures in custody there.
The abuses reportedly include beatings and torture.

Review/Pop; Ziggy Marley Carries On In His Father's Tradition
LEAD: Ziggy Marley has used his inheritance well.
As the son of the late Bob Marley, who made reggae music an international force, he had the inside track to reach reggae fans.
He has capitalized on his physical and vocal resemblance to his father, but he has also followed through with serious-minded lyrics and assured music, and in a surprisingly short time he has reconvened the large reggae audience that fragmented after his father's death in 1981.


Crenshaw Manages To Retain the Lead
LEAD: Ben Crenshaw didn't play nearly as well today as he did Thursday.
But he still managed to hold on to the lead in the NEC World Series of Golf halfway through this $1 million tournament with a 45-man select field of winners from around the world.


Patents; Now, Team Chess, With Double the Pieces
LEAD: Getting bored with chess?
Looking for a game that would be more fun at parties?
Richard A. Carlson has patented an alternative: chess played by two-member teams, with a bigger board and twice as many pieces.


Fire Damages Landmark University Building in Madison, N.J.


Voyager's Heartbeat Is Nuclear 'Battery'
LEAD: The stunning pictures of Neptune being transmitted to Earth from the Voyager 2 spacecraft are coming courtesy of an unusual form of nuclear power that runs the craft's cameras, computers and radio transmitters that beam the pictures over.


Rep. Frank Acknowledges Hiring Male Prostitute as Personal Aide
LEAD: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts said today that without his knowledge a male prostitute he had hired to do personal errands had run a prostitution service from the Congressman's Washington apartment.


Patents; An Easier Way To Light a Cigarette
LEAD: For smokers who find lighting cigarettes inconvenient, Richard Mawby of Alexandria, Va., has designed a cigarette pack that does the job for them.

Pakistani Plane Carrying 54 Is Lost in Mountainous Area
LEAD: A Pakistani airliner carrying 54 people disappeared in bad weather today over mountainous northeastern Pakistan.

LEAD: Bobby Allison, out of racing since he was injured more than a year ago, plans to return to the sport next year as the owner of a Winston Cup team on the Nascar circuit.
He has not named a driver or secured a sponsor, but the team will race Buicks and be based at Charlotte, N.C.

Mumbling Won't Move Noriega
LEAD: The Panama crisis offered the Organization of American States a rare opportunity to demonstrate the advantages of cooperative hemisphere diplomacy.
Instead, by its fumbling, mumbling response, the O.A.S. has discredited multilateralism, undermining the very principle it needs to sustain in order to play a meaningful role.


Pole Urges Bush to Speed Economic Aid
LEAD: On his first full day in office, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki met with American Congressmen today and urged President Bush to accelerate economic aid for Poland.


New York Poorer for Vanishing Private Libraries
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A consortium including the General Motors Corporation and Avis Inc. agreed to buy Avis Europe P.L.C. today in a deal that values the European car rental and leasing concern at $1.4 billion.

LEAD: Top officers of the Chicago Board of Trade did not benefit from the exchange's decision last month to order an emergency liquidation of positions in the soybean market, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said in a preliminary report today.

LEAD: A mother convicted of delivering drugs to her two babies through the bloodstream was sentenced today to 15 years of probation and completion of a drug treatment program.


Nutrasweet Plans Increased Output
LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company announced plans to double the production capacity for its artificial sweetener products, which are marketed in more than 70 countries.

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds, playing their first game since Pete Rose was banned from baseball for life, lost to Pittsburgh tonight, 12-3.

Casualties of Change in Italy: The Old People Left Behind

U.N. and O.A.S. Form Panel To Help the Contras Disband
LEAD: The United Nations and the Organization of American States agreed today to create a joint commission to oversee the disarming and resettlement of the American-backed Nicaraguan rebels based in Honduras.


Knight-Ridder Officers Shifted
LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced today that Alvah Chapman, 68 years old, would step down as chairman, effective Oct. 1, and would be replaced by James K. Batten. 53, the chief executive.

Technical 'Magic' Converts A Puny Signal Into Pictures
LEAD: The conversion of whisper-faint pulses of radio energy from the outer reaches of the solar system into spectacular color pictures of Neptune have put communications technology to an extraordinary test that it has triumphantly passed.


Patents; Gout Drug May Help To Curb Cockroaches
LEAD: Physicians have long prescribed allopurinol for people who suffer from gout.
Now three entomologists think it may be a formidable weapon against cockroaches.


Helmsley Judge Tells Jurors To Ignore Personal Feelings
LEAD: The judge in the trial of Leona Helmsley and two co-defendants told jurors yesterday that in trying to reach a verdict they should not be swayed by emotions or any personal feelings they might have about the defendants' backgrounds and life styles.

Hoylake Denied An Injunction
LEAD: A Federal district judge in Texas denied Hoylake Investment Ltd.'s request for a preliminary injunction that challenged the jurisdiction of state insurance regulators in Hoylake's bid for B.A.T.
Industries, a B.A.T. spokesman said.
Hoylake, controlled by Sir James Goldsmith, sought the injunction to keep state regulators from blocking his attempt to take over B.A.T.


Towle in Chapter 11
LEAD: Towle Manufacturing said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Towle, a maker and seller of giftware, said it had made the filing because of excessive debt.
The company had a previous Chapter 11 reorganization that ended in November 1987 but it said its revenues had failed to meet the forecasts on which that reorganization was based.


Acoustical Tinkering at Carnegie
LEAD: Carnegie Hall has been quietly tinkering with the acoustics of its historic main hall during its annual August closing.
It is an attempt to smooth a harshness of sound that many musicians and critics say followed a major restoration three years ago.


Padres Halt Mets on James's Homer in 11th
LEAD: The Mets lost an argument, a manager, a ball game and one full length in the standings tonight when they opened a nine-game trip to the West Coast with a 5-3 loss to the San Diego Padres in 11 innings.


Dollar Is Higher in the U.S. As Gold Prices Fall Sharply
LEAD: The dollar finished higher yesterday in domestic dealings after declining overseas.

Margaret E. Boorman, Missionary, 78
LEAD: Margaret E. Boorman, who was awarded the Medal of Freedom in 1946 for her service in China, died on Wednesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass.
She was 78 years old and lived in Cambridge.


Wanted: Airport Terminal (Nothing Too Modern, Please)
LEAD: East Hampton had planned for some time to do something about its airport terminal, built as a World War II barracks. ''You name a code, and it wouldn't pass it,'' said the manager of the town-run airport, Patrick Ryan.


Breast Cancer Death Rate Found Increasing
LEAD: The rate of death from breast cancer in the United States is increasing and it is highest in the Northern states, Federal health officials say.


Raymond Harris, 70, Geriatric Cardiologist
LEAD: Dr.
Raymond Harris, founder and first president of the Council on Geriatric Cardiology, died of stomach and liver cancer yesterday at his home in Albany.
He was 70 years old.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Fishing Accord for Taiwan  American observers will be allowed on Taiwan vessels to monitor nets that kill marine animals, in what may be a precedent for agreements with other Asian countries.
Page 29.
Arrest in Huey Newton Case  The police in Oakland say that a drug dealer has admitted killing the former Black Panther leader but maintains it was self-defense.


William Constable, 83, Painter and Designer
LEAD: William Constable, an Australian painter and set and costume designer for ballet, opera, theater and film, died of pneumonia Monday at his home in Melbourne.
He was 83 years old.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Sheehan Takes Lead: Patty Sheehan birdied three of the last four holes to complete a six-under-par 66 and take the lead halfway through the L.P.G.A. world championship of women's golf yesterday in Buford, Ga.
Sheehan held a one-shot lead over Betsy King, who shot a 71 for 137.(AP)


Casino Owner Loses License In Wake of Loan Allegations
LEAD: The Nevada Gaming Commission has voted unanimously to revoke the license of the Japanese businessman Ginji Yasuda, head of the financially troubled Aladdin hotel and casino in Las Vegas.


Boston Is to Close or Consolidate 9 Schools
LEAD: Reversing a lower-court decision, a three-judge panel of the state appeals court ruled today that the Boston School Committee may close or consolidate nine schools.


Falconbridge Holders Urged to Take FL Bid
LEAD: In the continuing battle for what mineral experts say are some of Canada's richest mining assets, the board of directors of Falconbridge Ltd. recommended today that shareholders accept last week's offer of $37 (Canadian), or $31.45 (United States), a share from the FL Acquisition Corporation.
FL was formed by two mining giants, Noranda Inc.


Herbert Vogler, Stage Manager, 47
LEAD: Herbert Vogler, a Broadway stage manager, died of AIDS Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 47 years old.


Giuliani Speech: Eliminating the 3 C's
LEAD: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches.
Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.
But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.


Mexican Executive Testifies In Killing of U.S. Drug Agent
LEAD: Granted limited immunity in secret testimony, the brother-in-law of former President Luis Echeverria of Mexico appeared on Thursday before a Federal grand jury investigating the slaying of an American drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar.

Talks on a Cambodian Agreement Are Deadlocked, U.S. Says
LEAD: The United States said today that an international conference on Cambodia, convened in Paris a month ago, had made no progress on the most important issue: the sharing of power between the Phnom Penh Government and its rivals, including Prince Norodom Sihanouk.


Tiny Hydraulic Crack Caused B-2 Problems, Air Force Says
LEAD: The Air Force said today that a hairline crack in the hydraulic support system caused the shortened test flight of the B-2 Stealth bomber last week.


Patents; Big Backlog At Agency Stirs Concern
LEAD: What started as a minor paperwork delay at the Patent and Trademark Office has grown into a large backlog in the publication of patents.


Grieving for Dead Girl, Town Asks: Should Boy, 10, Face Murder Charge?
LEAD: A 10-year-old Pennsylvania boy was charged as an adult yesterday in the fatal shooting of a 7-year-old neighbor.
Experts in juvenile law say that if the case goes to trial, he will be the youngest person tried as an adult in a homicide case in this country in the 20th century.


Police Search for 18-Year-Old In Killing of Brooklyn Youth
LEAD: The New York City police yesterday searched intensively for an 18-year-old white youth who they believe may have shot to death 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins in a racial attack Wednesday night in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.


Whittaker Selling Battery Group
LEAD: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its Battery Group to a group led by the operation's management.
The amount of money involved was not disclosed.
The Battery Group is made up of the Yardney power systems and power storage systems units.
Whittaker said the sale was part of a divestiture plan that will leave it with six of its former operating units.

LEAD: Pete Rose will apparently not have much time to recover from the announcement of his banishment from baseball before he will again come under potentially intense public and law-enforcement scrutiny.

A Sensible Compromise on Indian Bones
LEAD: After more than two years of prodding by American Indian leaders, the Smithsonian Institution promises a more humane policy on returning skeletons and burial artifacts of Indians taken as anthropological specimens.
The change deserves to be widely copied.


Johannesburg Journal; Pretoria's Choice: An Empty School
LEAD: The city of Johannesburg was little more than a year old when the Johannesburg High School for Girls admitted its first pupils in 1887.
Now, 102 years later, the Government plans to close the landmark institution at the end of December, not because there are too few local applicants, but because the applicants are not white.


Long Putters Are Legal
LEAD: The United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St.
Andrews, Scotland, agreed last Saturday to continue to permit use of the long-shafted putters most commonly employed by members of the Senior PGA Tour.
Orville Moody won the United States Senior Open championship in July putting with a club that had a 48-inch shaft.

An Informal Newcomer in Norwalk
LEAD: THE big restaurant news in the Norwalk area in recent years has centered on the rejuvenation of Washington Street in South Norwalk, but little seems to have changed in downtown Norwalk.
A recent addition, though, is Cogburn's, which occupies space formerly belonging to another restaurant, St.
John's River Cafe.


L.A. FIGHTS FOR BREATH
LEAD: Alan Weisman describes the severity of the problem of air pollution in Los Angeles and the plan to alleviate it (''L.A. Fights For Breath,'' July 30).
But he omits mention of an important factor in the development of the problem: the systematic elimination of the clean electric train and its replacement by smog-producing buses and cars.


Perspectives: Residential Design; Two-Family Houses a Success in Queens
LEAD: A STRONG case is being made by the Bluestone Organization in the Jamaica section of Queens for the two-family semi-attached house as an ideal for-sale housing product for New York City's moderate- to middle-income home buyers.


What's Doing In Tulsa
LEAD: Tulsa, a young, sophisticated city on the edge of the prairie, revels in its heritage, the Indian, the cowboy, but predominantly in oil, which propelled it from cow town to ''oil capital of the world.'' Today, that boastful sobriquet is more nostalgia than fact.
The oil business is both depressed and headquartered elsewhere.


PROGRAM KEEPS INMATES ON TRACK
LEAD: As the four-week race meeting at Saratoga nears its end each year, everyone at the track begins looking forward to coming back the next summer.
Few have ever held that hope more dearly than Benny Vazquez and Davis Hudson did here Friday.


Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
LEAD: Yes!
Furthermore, he should be forced to do so.
The City of New York should declare Yankee Stadium a disaster area, invoke the power of eminent domain, claim the Yankees, and give Steinbrenner their market value - and his walking papers.
MICHAEL BROWN  KEN LINDLEY  New York


RESULTS PLUS  Track and Field  Ashford Takes 100 Meters: Evelyn Ashford of the United States, the silver medalist at the Seoul Olympics, won the women's 100 meters in 11.05 seconds at the Chuhei Nambu Memorial meet in Sapporo, Japan, yesterday. Rick Noji won the men's high jump with a leap of 7 feet 5 inches, while his American compatriot Kenny Harrison soared 56-1 1/4 with a tail wind to capture the men's triple jump at Maruyama Stadium. Kyle Hargett of the United States took the men's 400 meters in 48:07. (AP)  Road Running  A Victory for Budd: Zola Budd easily won a 10-kilometer road race yesterday in Johannesburg in her first competition in South Africa since she abandoned her international career. Budd captured the women's Phoenix Road Race in her hometown of Bloemfontein in 37 minutes 35 seconds. Budd, 23 years old, said in June that she had given up plans to compete abroad, where she was relentlessly protested by anti-apartheid protesters. (AP)  Boxing  Konadu Retains Title: Nana Yaw Konadu of Ghana retained his World Boxing Council international superflyweight title when he knocked out Park Dai Yong of South Korea in the second round at the World Trade Center in Singapore last night. Park, ranked 30th in the W.B.C. listing, was on the defense from the opening bell when the champion set a terrific pace with two-fisted combinations. Konadu raised his record to 18-0-1, while Park fell to 15-4-1.(AP)  University Games Cason Takes Gold in 100-Meter Dash: Andre Cason gave the Americans their first gold medal at Duisburg, West Germany, by winning the men's 100-meter dash. Cason, the world junior champion, was timed in 10.29 seconds on a cloudy, cool day. (AP)  Horse Show Victory for Grubb: The British Olympic veteran Tim Grubb rode Spruce Meadows to victory over a 32-horse field in the WEZF Speed Derby yesterday at the $500,000 Vermont Equestrian Summer Showcase in Stowe. Grubb, who has a home in Pottersville, N.J., was fourth to try the 14-jump, 485-yard course at the Trapp Family Lodge. He guided his horse to a fault-free ride in 60.564 seconds to take an early lead that he never relinquished.  Tennis Sanchez Vicario to Play Navratilova: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario fought back from a first-set loss and a 1-5 deficit in the second set yesterday to beat Gabriela Sabatini for the first time in eight career matches and advance to the final of the Player's Challenge tournament in Toronto. In the other semifinal match, top-seeded Martina Navratilova overpowered the Australian Anne Minter, 6-0, 6-2. Sanchez Vicario, a 17-year-old Spaniard, defeated the second-seeded Sabatini, 3-6, 7-5, 6-3, winning six straight games in the second set. In only one of her previous matches with the Argentine had Sanchez Vicario managed to even win one set. Sabatini suffered a cramp in her right hand in the eighth game of the second set when she failed to capitalize on match point. On several changeovers, she iced her hand an


Prospects; Restructuring Kodak
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company announced a major restructuring aimed at paring costs following a weak second quarter.
The company will cut 4,500 jobs this year and will sell some of its business units.
There will also be a wage and salary freeze for 1990.
Kodak's poor showing comes after its $5.1 billion purchase of Sterling Drug Inc.


The Job Is to Solve the Crime
LEAD: IN a section of the State Police Forensics Laboratory, an investigator cautiously removes fingerprints from a series of bombs.
In another room, a photographer takes pictures of a telephone receiver that has been dusted for fingerprints.
In one of the other 14 divisions, three scientists examine tiny bits of glass and hair, while nearby in the arson room, fire debris is analyzed.


Connecticut Team Wins Little League Crown
LEAD: Taiwan's three consecutive Little League World Series victories did not intimidate Little Leaguers from Trumbull, Conn.


Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.
LEAD: South American cocaine cartels have transformed this desert town and other seemingly bucolic points along the cactus-dotted Mexican border into international drug passageways that now rival those of south Florida.


STAMPS
LEAD: With a certain inevitablity, Mickey Mouse has joined the galaxy at the United States Postal Service.
To promote World Stamp Expo '89, in Washington between Nov. 17 and Dec. 3, the post office ran a cartoon contest involving a space-suited Mickey and a cute green extraterrestial.


Lost Opportunity
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fire Department Seeks Tips From Fire Victims
LEAD: FIREFIGHTERS in Fairfield have a new piece of protective equipment that they bring to fires.
It is a roll of plastic to cover rugs when responding to minor fires, so they do not muddy the carpet on rainy days.
It is the first innovation to come out of a fire department program that offers fire victims a chance to evaluate firefighting techniques.

History at the Tip of Long Island
LEAD: MONTAUK, at the eastern tip of Long Island's South Fork, 125 miles by highway from Manhattan, has the mystique of places at the end of the road.
Here, past the endless coiled circuits of midisland suburbs, beyond the clipped expensive foliage of the Hamptons, the wind blows harder, the waves curl higher, the light reflects with a scouring whiteness off the restless back of the Atlantic.

Political Violence Sweeping Once-Quiet Honduras
LEAD: Salomon Vallecilo, a 34-year-old factory worker and labor leader, left his house in a working-class neighborhood here on July 4 to take a 6 A.M. bus to work.
He passed a nightclub on his left and, on his right, an assassin, who was reading a newspaper in the shade of a small almond tree.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew.
Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off.
We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.


FICTION
LEAD:  OPHELIA AND THE GREAT IDEA.
By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $16.95.) In the title story of this collection by the young British playwright Deborah Levy, one character glosses the eponymous ''great idea'': ''To invent a time and place of your own.'' To this end, Ms.
Levy has discarded the traditional props of plot and unified setting.

LEAD: Control of Hawaiian Airlines would be acquired by a group that includes Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner whose deal for Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, under an agreement set with HAL Inc., which owns the financially troubled airline.
The group is headed by J. Thomas Talbot, former chairman of Jet America, a California-based airline.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  JAPAN: In the Land of the Brokenhearted.
By Michael Shapiro. (Holt, $19.95.) Perhaps no country makes a foreigner feel more conscious of his foreignness than Japan.
For foreigners who seek fulfillment by submerging themselves in another culture, it represents the ultimate challenge.
As Michael Shapiro shows in his insightful book, ''Japan,'' it is a challenge they can never entirely meet.

Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


Abundant Salmon From Irish Rivers
LEAD: ON the day we arrived in Ireland, there were too many salmon.
We had driven from Shannon Airport through the counties of Kerry and Cork to a Georgian mansion called Longueville House on a hillside overlooking the Blackwater, a 70-mile-long river crowded with salmon rushing to their spawning grounds.

LONG ISLAND GUIDE

Behind the Wheel in the Soviet Union
LEAD: TRAVELERS driving through the Soviet Union can easily distinguish foreign tourists' cars from those of Soviet citizens.
The latter don't have windshield wipers.
The former do - but not for long.


500-Year-Old Pine Is Felled
LEAD: A tree nine feet in diameter, believed to be the world's tallest Ponderosa pine, has been cut down in a central Idaho forest, producing a 112-foot log.
The pine, which died three years ago, was more than 500 years old.
Sections of the trunk, with historical dates marked on its growth rings, will go to parks in Boise, Donnelly and Pocatello, Idaho, and a botanical garden in Dortmund, West Germany.


Making Nice to Your Stockbroker
LEAD: The current market rally may prompt more investors to call their stockbrokers for advice.
Unfortunately, most brokers pay serious attention to only a handful of clients, and chances are you are not one of them - even if you have $50,000 or more in securities.
Further, if you don't know how to work with a broker, even paying a steady flow of commissions won't necessarily win the broker's constant attention.


ABOUT NEW JERSEY
LEAD: NEVER at a loss for news, New Jersey reached another first this month when it was identified by the United States Bureau of the Census as the only state in the nation situated entirely within metropolitan areas.


Why Laughter Is Often a Dancer's Partner
LEAD: Dancers are often called frivolous.
Over the centuries, stern moralists have deplored them for being so.
Yet, the seeming lack of serious intent of dancers may be a sign of a virtue, rather than a vice.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew.
Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off.
We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.

LEAD: FLAT or nearly flat roofs are usually built up of several layers of roofing felt and either coal tar or asphalt.
A layer of gravel or marble chips is often spread over the surface to protect it and reflect heat.

Paying the Price
LEAD: In the Government's insider-trading investigation of Wall Street, the first person convicted by a jury was Lisa Ann Jones, a runaway at age 14 who become a $117,000-a-year trading assistant for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. at age 26.

CHESS
LEAD: There is no problem playing against a man who has just published a book on an opening.
If the work is at all honest, you know where you have him.
Paired with him, you obviously don't choose to confront the variations where you agree that his side stands better, but only those where you have uncovered a loophole, a sincere error that he does not know exists.

COMRADE ENGVER GOES TO MOSCOW
LEAD: BY 9:30 A.M., THE DEPUTIES HAVE ALREADY BEGUN drifting into the semicircular chamber of the Supreme Soviet, half an hour before the bell signals the beginning of the session.
The meeting place is contemporary and, by the grandiose norm of this country, intimate.
Banks of wooden desks, sleek marble walls adorned by the gilt Soviet insignia, but none of the heroic Lenin statuary that lends an air of secular idolatry to almost every other auditorium

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a ''What's Doing'' article in the Travel section on Aug. 6 about Edinburgh carried an erroneous restaurant listing.
The restaurant, Handsel's, closed last December.
The exchange rate was also misstated; it is $1.60 to the pound.
And the birthplace of James VI of Scotland, later James I, was misidentified; it was Holyrood House.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-19


FICTION
LEAD:  QUITE THE OTHER WAY.
By Kaylie Jones. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Although we've got used to second-generation actors equaling or surpassing the accomplishments of their parents, the same hasn't happened with second-generation novelists.
Nonetheless there are a few, like Martin Amis and Susan Cheever, who are making names for themselves - and added to their small number ought to be Kaylie Jones, the daughter of James Jones, whose second novel, ''Quite the Other Way,'' is a look at the particulars and peculiarities of glasnost.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew.
Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off.
We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.


FICTION
LEAD:  TROPHY FOR EAGLES.
By Walter J. Boyne. (Crown, $19.95.) Walter J. Boyne, the author of 10 books on aviation, has written an 11th book on aviation, thickly disguised as a novel.
It concerns airplanes and people, real and imaginary, of the period 1927-37, a glorious era for aviation but for Western humanity a slog through the sloughs of depression and totalitarianism, emerging in war.

What Happens When What's Under Manhattan Breaks
LEAD: IT is a jungle down there.
Beneath the 23 square miles of Manhattan are 11 million miles of telephone wire, 19,000 miles of electrical cable, 6,000 miles of water mains, 4,000 miles of gas lines, 100 miles of cable television wiring and 105 miles of steam pipes.
And that is not all that is stretched over, under and around subway tunnels, sewage lines and passages barely big enough to crawl through.

A minister sees a religious monument.
A mechanical engineer sees a balance of forces and materials.

With the decline of fascism and Communism, he argues, Western liberal democracy has triumphed and mankind has reached its highest wisdom.

Trucking
LEAD: To the Editor: I'm sure you know how dangerous it is on the highways when it rains.
Most of the hazard is created by trucks, which frequently go beyond the speed limit and throw a heavy spray onto passenger cars.
This is particularly troublesome when the trucks are large and their wheels high.
In a heavy storm, and at night, there can be long moments when visibility for drivers of smaller cars is almost nil.

Different Products Need Different Rules
LEAD: In 1982, when futures markets came up with the idea of stock index contracts, the securities industry said it was a silly idea that would not work.
Later, when it did work, the industry said it was the work of the devil and ought to be banned.
Later, when most academicians lauded these contracts as indispensable risk-management tools, the securities exchanges decided that maybe it was a good idea after all.


Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about day-care centers misstated a requirement of a proposed zoning ordinance in Greenburgh.
In office districts, a center's building plans would need approval from the Planning Board, not the Zoning Board.


WHEN ALL THE STARS ARE GONE
LEAD: The very term ''street people'' seems to have taken on a life of its own: they seem almost a separate species, so wholly other, so seemingly lacking in context and individual history - so abstract.
Yet, Fred Waitzkin's article fights this violence of abstraction.
We are forced to confront a portrait of human suffering, in this case of mental illness and homelessness, that is both our society's shadow and reflection.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew.
Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off.
We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.

Q and A
LEAD:  Terrace Cookout  Question: I have seen newspaper articles recently about people cooking outdoors on apartment terraces and on balconies and in back yards.
I thought terrace cooking was illegal.
Is it? . . .
B.
K., Manhattan  Answer: Yes.
According to a spokesman for the New York City Fire Department, fire rules prohibit the use of grills of any kind inside houses, apartments or garages or on any apartment balcony, terrace or roof.

Touring Native Ground
LEAD: ''WHEN are you coming home this summer?'' asked my mother. ''Home'' is Lansing, Mich., and it has not really been my home for nearly 25 (Is that possible?) years.
No matter.
Most adults approach these journeys home with a mixture of anticipation and boredom - anticipation (at least on my part) of seeing much-loved relatives, boredom at the prospect of being stuck in a place frozen in memory as an incubator of youthful dreams rather than a living community.

Dispute at Coachlight Leads to Non-Union Cast
LEAD: AFTER the Aug. 13 performance of ''They're Playing Our Song'' at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, the eight-member cast quit the show.
Three day later, a new company took over in the Marvin Hamlisch-Neil Simon musical, which is scheduled to run through Sept. 17.
What sets the two casts apart is that the first consisted of members of Actors' Equity, the union of professional actors and stage managers; the new cast does not.

I found it almost hidden from view among the drooping branches of a withered tomato plant.
It was huge, this beefsteak tomato, ripe, red and luscious.
The kind that drips down your chin when you take a bite.

LEAD: WHEN they ponder their good fortune to be living and working here and now, planetary scientists sometimes speak of this as the golden age in the exploration of the solar system.

For the first time, they have emerged as distinct and varied worlds.

THE ECSTASY OF GERARD MANLEY HOPKINS
LEAD: It is just 100 years since the death of Gerard Manley Hopkins, S.J., and about 60 years since I first read him.
Those were the days when to read ''Ulysses'' was to break the law.
Modernism was dangerous, and one of the marks of modernism was strangeness of language.
Hopkins, like James Joyce, had bizarre compound words like ''beadbonny'' and ''fallowboot-fellow''; he seemed to be dragging the Germanic roots of English out of freshly dug earth.

For a Quick Change of Personality, Curry Powder
LEAD: THE heat of curry seems to wake summer appetites.
Spicy seasonings are often characteristic in regions with hot climates, and curry - or the spices like pepper, cumin, turmeric, ginger and others that make up the blend - is no exception.


Correction
LEAD: An article about Los Angeles art on July 16 incorrectly characterized the change in location of the Richard Green Gallery.
It has moved from SoHo to 24 West 57th Street, not from Los Angeles to New York.


Colombia Welcomes Aid; Long Struggle Seen
LEAD: Colombian leaders today welcomed a $65 million anti-narcotics aid package from the United States but predicted that it would be the opening volley in a long, bloody battle.

LEAD: With a variety of issues on the agenda but none urgent, members of the International Olympic Committee opened their 95th congress today with six days of meetings to follow.


Dennis L. O'Connor, Lawyer, 76
LEAD: Dennis L. O'Connor, a lawyer, died of cancer Wednesday at the home of his sister in Larchmont, N.Y.
He was 76 years old and was a longtime resident of White Plains.


Polish Prime Minister Meets With Head of Soviet K.G.B.
LEAD: The head of the Soviet K.G.B. met with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki today and said the new Polish leader was ''a solid man'' who will succeed in solving the nation's problems.


A Housing Renaissance Sweeps Central Harlem
LEAD: WHEN construction of Towers on the Park, the twin-building condominium complex that hugs the northwest corner of Central Park, was begun in 1986, it was hailed as the start of a housing initiative that would put home ownership within reach of many more Harlem residents.


Lutherans Allow Dissent in Pronouncements
LEAD: The Evangelical Lutheran Church of America has decided to make sure dissenting voices are heard when the new denomination makes a pronouncement on a social issue.


New HQ For Jaguar
LEAD: Flush with a surge in demand for its luxury automobiles, Jaguar Cars Inc. is building a new North American headquarters in the 20-acre Ramapo Ridge corporate park in Mahwah, N.J.
The $25 million construction project, due to be completed next spring, will consolidate the British motor company's current corporate operations in Leonia and Teaneck, N.J., into one building of 200,000 square feet, more than double the current space.


The Bailout's Ripple Effect
LEAD: Washington's savings-and- loan bailout plan is intended to restore that industry to health.
But in the process, the market for securities that are backed by home mortgages may suffer some ill effects of its own.
The dramatic consolidation of savings institutions is causing a wave of selling of those securities.


Angola Truce Is as Deadly As Civil War
LEAD: It was shortly past midnight the other night when a mortar shell ripped through the roof of Felismina Castilho's adobe hut.
Shrapnel from the explosion tore a hole in her right thigh.
Her parents, sleeping in a room next door, were killed.

Still the Stones, but There's a Catch
LEAD: The Rolling Stones announce that they're back with the two triumphal chords that start ''Sad Sad Sad'' and open the album ''Steel Wheels'' (Columbia 45333; all three formats).
Those two syncopated chords, like a rock ''Amen,'' are the ones that kicked ''Jumping Jack Flash,'' ''Honky Tonk Women'' and ''Start Me Up'' into gear; they're a Stones trademark, and Keith Richards's guitar makes them sound brash, slick, edgy, poised, offhand, jubilant and nasty, all at once.

LEAD: Rough wear.
Animal prints.
Classics.
Quilted bags with chain-link handles.
No, it's not designer sportswear; it's the back-to-school department.

LEAD: The outcome of the Shoreham controversy is a foregone conclusion.
Despite the apparently never-ending controversy, there is really no question about the ultimate outcome.
The old adage that ''money talks'' holds true in this case.
And the people of Long Island have ''voted'' with their pocketbooks.


Steering Your Way to a Car Vacation in the Soviet Union
LEAD: Even with the new openness, the Soviet Union is not the sort of place where you can jump in a car and drive off into the sunset.
You need to plan a car trip well ahead of time, and to stick to the itinerary you have agreed to.
All this is worth a trip with no parking meters or toll booths, some beautiful countryside, intriguing places and a sense of unmapped adventure.

Q and A
LEAD:  Tipping the Guide  Question: How does one tip adventure travel guides? - J. M., Stowe, Vt.
Answer: Tipping on such trips is never mandatory but almost always appreciated if participants feel a guide has done a good job.
The best approach is before you leave to to ask the tour company for guidelines on tipping.

Why Training Is Worth the Cost
LEAD: Too few people gave much thought to training when personal computers arrived in offices. ''Here it is,'' a technician said, patting the contraption that replaced the typewriter. ''Call if you need help.

Getting to the Top In the Caucasus
LEAD: THE man in the street, the man in the woods, even the top-notch travel agent have probably never heard of Europe's highest peak.
But the obscurity of this Russian volcano is undeserved; any strong hiker with an ice ax and a pair of crampons can reach the summit at 18,481 feet, and look down on 30,000 square miles of mountains, high plains and inland seas.


Closing at the Open
LEAD: It was at the United States Open in 1971 that Chris Evert burst onto the tennis scene, reaching the semifinals as a 16-year-old, and it will be after this year's Open that she will close out serious competition as a 34-year-old. ''No more 'maybes,' '' Ms.
Evert wrote in Sports Illustrated.
She has won more matches and more tournaments than any other player, male or female, including the United States Open six times, Wimbledon three times, the Australian Open twice and the French Open a record seven times.

Body and Mind; Challenge of Gravity
LEAD: FIFTY FEET ABOVE dirt and talus, I plaster myself to a vertical wall of rock.
I lift my way against the unfamiliar demands of gravity, calling on joints and muscles that suddenly seem inflexible and weak.
My novice's eye can hardly make out the slender juts of stone above me that must serve as holds for hand and foot - and it requires a great leap of faith to believe in them.

Question Box
LEAD:  Yankees and Mets  Q. When Walt Terrell joined the Yankees from San Diego last month, he also joined a list of major leaguers who have been with both New York teams, the Yankees and the Mets.
How many pitchers are in that group?
A.
Terrell is the 18th pitcher among the 39 players to have donned both New York uniforms in a regular season, meaning that more than 45 percent of those with Met-Yankee backgrounds have been pitchers.

AZT's Inhuman Cost
LEAD: AZT is the only drug approved for use against AIDS.
It's now known that AZT also postpones the onset of AIDS in people infected with the virus.
Yet there's a massive obstacle to wider use of this life-saving drug - its extraordinary cost.
At $8,000 a year for users, AZT is said to be the most expensive prescription drug in history.

Filbert Estimate Down
LEAD: The filbert harvest in Oregon and Washington is estimated at 13,500 tons, down 18 percent from 1988 and the smallest output since 1984.
An Agriculture Department report said severe cold in early February interfered with pollination.
The Oregon crop of filberts, or hazelnuts, was forecast at 13,300 tons, compared with 16,300 tons in 1988.

LEAD: With its long nose and bulbous cockpit, the Turbo-Thrush looks like an airplane designed by a committee.
But the plane's ungainly features make it a high-performance crop duster, with promising potential in the drug fields of Colombia.

On this day, each finger was a different color, blue, red and purple.

LEAD: USING computer-based accounting to handle household finances is like using a combine to mow the yard.
But there are simpler programs available that manage household, home office or small business finances with relative ease.
Three of the best are Quicken, Checkwrite Plus and Managing Your Money.
Which one to use depends on which type of user you are.

Holocaust Memorial Unveiled
LEAD: Fairfield County's first Holocaust memorial was unveiled and dedicated Sunday before about 100 people in Norwalk.
The memorial is in the wall of the Norwalk Jewish Community Center and includes hundreds of tiles made by children who attended the center's summer camp.
The memorial was inspired by the life of Charles Mittel, who escaped from Auschwitz.
