Needs of Civil Society
LEAD: There was a meeting in early August at Pope John Paul II's summer palace in Castel Gandolfo on civil society and what it means.
It isn't a new concept, but it has a new immediacy and importance as people in various parts of the world come to grips with the wrenching problems of transformation and advancing humane values.

Triton May Be Coldest Spot in Solar System
LEAD: Surprising Triton, the largest moon of Neptune, appears to be the coldest place in the solar system, Voyager 2 scientists reported today.
It also displays a glowing aurora caused by bombarding radiation trapped by Neptunian magnetic fields.


Patterns
LEAD: Wanted: Senior fashion director.
Must be willing to make six-figure income, travel to London, Paris and Milan, Italy, at least twice a year, stay at chic hotels, eat in the finest restaurants.
Should love clothes and have great style while being a good corporate soldier.
Prefer candidate not wear Chanel in public.

LEAD: The new president and chief executive of Prime Computer Inc., James F. McDonald, said the company would reduce its costs and focus on its three main businesses.
But Prime's new owner, J. H. Whitney &amp; Company, had no immediate plans to sell any significant assets, he said.
Mr.
McDonald said Prime would concentrate on computer-aided design, minicomputers and service.

Terms of the contracts were not disclosed.
Quick previously had a three-year pact for $700,000 a year.

LEAD: Critics of a policy of Domino's Pizza Inc. that guarantees delivery within 30 minutes plan to try to hit the company where it hurts this autumn.

LEAD: An experimental drug can help women conquer an overwhelming urge to tear out their hair, a surprisingly common disorder that affects millions of Americans, leaving some bald, researchers say.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers traded Maurice Cheeks, David Wingate and Chris Welp to the San Antonio Spurs yesterday for Johnny Dawkins, a guard, and Jay Vincent, a forward.

LEAD: An investment group led by the FAI Traders Insurance Company, an insurance concern based in Sydney, Australia, has acquired 5.1 percent of the Foremost Corporation of America.
Foremost, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., insures mobile homes and recreational vehicles.

LEAD: Ecolab Inc.'s stock today rose to a new high for the year on renewed rumors that the company was a takeover target, analysts said.
Stock in the St.
Paul-based cleaning and maintenance company rose $2 a share, to $32.50, eclipsing its previous high of $30.50.
More than 193,000 shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that its consolidated profit in the first quarter rose 1.5 percent from the period a year earlier, as domestic sales weakened.

LEAD: Bernard Goetz, who was originally scheduled to be released from Rikers Island Sept. 6 after serving at least eight months of his one-year sentence for possessing an unlicensed handgun, has had his release date pushed back to Sept. 20 because of a prison infraction, correction officials said yesterday.

LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that a shareholder lawsuit against the Sundstrand Corporation can be brought to trial, reversing his March ruling that the claims should first be submitted to the company's board, Sundstrand announced today.

LEAD: Another Pro Bowl receiver, Anthony Carter of the Minnesota Vikings, ended a 28-day holdout, but he is without a new contract.

Ally Sought By Plessey
LEAD: The Plessey Company P.L.C., the British electronics group fighting a hostile takeover offer, has disclosed it is seeking an alliance with a leading Japanese semiconductor company.


Postage Stamps' Cost Likely to Rise in 1991
LEAD: The cost of a first-class postage stamp will probably rise, to between 28 and 32 cents, early in 1991, Postmaster General Anthony Frank said today.
That means two more Christmases at the current 25-cent rate for first-class letters, Mr.
Frank said on NBC-TV's ''Today'' show.
Mr.
Frank had previously said the Postal Service would apply for a rate increase next year, to take effect in 1991, but had not specified the amount.

A New Prime Number
LEAD: After more than a year of computation, six researchers at a California computer company have found the largest known prime number, which is 65,087 digits long and would fill more than 32 double-spaced typed pages.


Easing the Grocer's Burden
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has amended its rules that required retail food stores to provide adequate stocks of items that are advertised for sale.
The agency says the costs of complying exceed the regulation's benefits.

LEAD: An independent Government agency that investigates trade issues ruled today that subsidized exports of Canadian pork financially injure American hog producers.

LEAD: South Korea approved a plan today to revitalize its ailing shipbuilding industry through loans and tax incentives to three companies, including the huge Daewoo Group's debt-ridden shipyard, trade ministry officials said today.

LEAD: While neighboring Poland celebrated the ascent of non-Communists to national leadership, East Germany's aging leaders have stubbornly clung to their Marxist faith, evidently convinced that for them any surrender to the new winds would mean extinction.


OMI Stock Bought
LEAD: Storebrand A.S., a Norwegian insurance company, has acquired 6.9 percent of the OMI Corporation, a cargo-fleet operator based in New York.
OMI's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $9.50, on the American Stock Exchange.
At current stock prices, the company's is valued at $303 million.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Storebrand said it had made net purchases of 1.8 million OMI shares since December for $6.525 to $10.30 each.

Billy Samuels.

Attendance and handle reached new highs.
Everybody ate and drank too much and stayed out too late.

LEAD: Two decades ago, a British scientist named James Lovelock put forth an imaginative and poetic view of how the Earth functions.
The planet's living organisms, he said, act together to regulate the global environment: Life interacts chemically and physically with the air, the waters and the rocks to maintain optimum conditions for itself.

By Design; Not for Riding
LEAD: The woman was wearing crisply tailored, beautifully pressed jodhpurs.
She was slim and had narrow hips - the right body for pants of any cut.
But with the jodhpurs she was wearing a dressy jacket, a fussy hat and high-heeled shoes - all the wrong accessories.
She was an object lesson: it isn't enough to latch on to the latest style.

LEAD: The Security Council adopted a resolution today demanding strict compliance, ''especially by South Africa,'' with the United Nations independence plan for Namibia and the disbanding of all paramilitary forces in the territory, particularly a unit whose members are accused of pre-election harassment.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES  U.S.
Defeats Soviets: The United States won its first major men's international basketball competition in three years yesterday with an 88-80 victory over the Soviet Union in the gold medal game of the World University Games at Duisburg, West Germany.


Indonesia Nutmeg Shift
LEAD: Indonesia which produces 80 percent of the world's nutmeg, has abandoned five foreign companies and appointed a locally controlled company to handle overseas sales. ''Prices have fallen remarkably, and foreign trading houses that used to handle our nutmeg marketing failed to stabilize them,'' said Yantje Worotitjan, chairman of the national nutmeg association.


From Sympathy to Condemnation: People in Frank's District React
LEAD: People in his district are expressing a mixture of sympathy, embarrassment and distaste over the disclosure last week of Representative Barney Frank's relationship with a male prostitute from 1985 to 1987.

LEAD: Barely three weeks after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is to leave for the United States this week to offer assurances that Japan's recent political turmoil has not undermined its dependability or willingness to negotiate thorny trade and security disputes.


Plant Cited in Canyon Haze
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency concluded today that a nearby coal-fired power plant causes up to 70 percent of the air pollution over the Grand Canyon.
The agency said it expected a final decision by February on how to curb emissions from the plant, the Navajo Generating Station in Page, Ariz.


Court Curbs Dallas News
LEAD: The Dallas Times Herald was granted a temporary restraining order on Monday that forbids its rival, The Dallas Morning News, from publishing syndicated cartoons and columns, including the Far Side and Dear Abby, that now appear in The Times Herald.

LEAD: Scores of youths roamed the main business district here for about four hours Monday night and early today, hurling rocks and bottles at cars and storefronts in the tense aftermath of the fatal shooting of a black man by a white police officer on Sunday.

LEAD: The International Monetary Fund has cut its estimates for United States and world economic growth this year, monetary sources said today.

LEAD: Schlumberger Ltd., a large industrial concern, and the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan announced they were forming a company to develop advanced testing for integrated circuits.

LEAD: A ''SOFT LANDING'' appears to be at hand.
Although the statistics bounce around a bit, the American economy is clearly growing more sluggishly than it was last year, much to the relief of the Federal Reserve and many economists.
Now, the question is whether a slowly growing economy is really a blessing.

Bruce Gould, 91; Edited Women's Magazine
LEAD: Bruce Gould, co-editor with his wife, Beatrice Blackmar Gould, of the Ladies' Home Journal from 1935 until 1962, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Hopewell, N.J.
He was 91 years old.
Mr.
Gould was on the editorial staff of the Saturday Evening Post in 1935 when he and his wife were made co-editors of the Journal.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: Alabama is tentatively offering $351.4 million in zero-coupon general obligation refunding bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The capital appreciation bonds, which pay no interest to the bondholder, are priced to yield from 7 percent for an issue due in 2000 to 7.35 percent in 2002 and 7.40 percent in 2003 through 2008.

LEAD: ''Anything Goes,'' a revival of the 1934 musical with music and lyrics by Cole Porter, will end its run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, following the Sunday matinee performance.
Directed by Jerry Zaks, the show will have run for 44 previews and 804 regular performances.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, far higher than the 1.7 percent rate estimated last month, the Commerce Department reported.
The widely expected change reinforced the view that the economy is no longer slowing and might, in fact, be gaining fresh momentum.

LEAD: A monthlong international conference aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia appears to have collapsed, with officials predicting today that there will be large-scale fighting between the warring Cambodian factions before serious negotations can resume.

Editors' Note
LEAD: An article and its headline on Sunday about the previous day's Washington march protesting Supreme Court limits on affirmative action reported that 5,000 people had taken part.
That proved to be a premature estimate.
The National Park Service later estimated the crowd at 35,000, and some organizers said the number was 75,000 to 100,000.

Review/Film; Shirley Valentine Talks With Others
LEAD: A heroine whose dialogue can be packaged in a tiny publicity pamphlet called ''The Wit and Wisdom of Shirley Valentine'' is probably spouting shallow aphorisms rather than anything witty or wise.
Banality is precisely the problem with ''Shirley Valentine,'' the one-woman stage play that has been turned into a misguided, fully cast film.

LEAD: A virtual one-man crusade by a New Orleans oil company owner to extend free public education beyond high school for the academically prepared will benefit more than 1,000 Louisiana freshman this fall.


Disney Files Suit
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company filed suit yesterday against 149 New York area merchants charging they violated copyright laws by selling and distributing unsanctioned merchandise that bears representations of Disney characters.

Eating Well
LEAD: ''LOSE weight safely and quickly without cutting calories - or even counting them.'' That is the promise of ''The T-Factor Diet'' by Martin Katahn (W. W. Norton, $18.95), a best-selling diet book.
Dr.
Katahn, a psychologist, maintains that as long as you reduce the fat in your diet to about 20 percent of total calories, you can eat as much food as you want and still lose weight.

Molding a Higher Cut of Bureaucrat WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 - How do you make a better bureaucrat?   It is a question that the Federal Government asks itself the way Detroit ponders how to make better cars. It is also the chief concern of the Federal Executive Institute, the Government's version of a General Motors-style executive training program.   For the last 21 years, the institute has taught trainees how to lift themselves above the faceless masses of the Federal bureaucracy.   At first glance, its program looks like any in the private sector. Some course titles even sound like they have been pulled out of a G.M. training guide: Leadership and Work Group Effectiveness, or Negotiation and Conflict.   Others in the institute's curriculum, like Foundations of American Constitutional Government and Great Presidents of the 20th Century, leave little doubt that the corporation under discussion is the Federal Government.   The most promising career bureaucrats, part of the Senior Executive Service, attend the four-week sessions at a converted hotel in Charlottesville, Va., two hours south of here. The $4,700 cost of a session is paid by the executive's respective agency.   Teachers drawn from universities and the public sector guide the students through 15 courses, designed primarily to teach them about their own potential for leadership and about the operation of the Federal Government. Stress on Critical Thinking    ''Our emphasis is less on moving papers than on critical thinking, problem-solving, strategic thinking for the Government with a large view,'' said Pamela Gwin, the institute's assistant director for academic programs. ''I see it as a broadening experience in the sense of making people aware of a broader environment, that their particular piece of their agency is no longer their whole world.''   Taught in a seminar setting, the classes employ a mixture of techniques: lectures, readings, group discussions, role-playing and examinations of case studies. Guest lecturers have included Frank C. Carlucci, the former Secretary of Defense, and the late William Bolger, the former Postmaster General.   Though some of the sessions may resemble aspects of programs in the private sector, the institute bears the unmistakable stamp of the Government. Not only is its thick guidebook devoid of glossy photographs, but also half of the book's pages are crammed with Federal rules and regulations.   Some of its lessons, too, would be of little value in the private sector, like that on page 27: Never Surprise Members at Home.   The guidebook instructs the trainees in the fine points of dealing with Congress, cautioning: ''Members of Congress anger very quickly when they are not notified in advance by the relevant agency of a grant awarded or denied to parties in their district, a government facility closed, or a contract signed with a district business.''   During free time, which is scarce, there are voluntary courses offered on quitting smoking, C.P.R. and wellness. There are also opportunities for volleyball and other exercise. ''The focus here is on the total executive,'' said Michael Hansen, the director of the institute, which is host to 68 executives at each of nine sessions during the year. ''Basically, the goal here is to get them to look at things they never had time to do.'' Administrator Looks Back    Adele Derby had just joined the Federal Government when she attended the institute in 1981. Now an associate administrator at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ms. Derby said she learned much about her personality through tests she took and classes she attended there.   ''I get too intense,'' she said. ''If you get really intense about something trivial, it can turn people off.''   Ms. Derby, who is serving in her second one-year term as president of the institute's 2,400-member alumni association, said the institute helped her eliminate the negative influence she felt she was having on her department and her employees. ''When I came back, I felt I was a better manager for having gone there,'' she said.   James Colvard, then a director of a United States Naval laboratory, said a course on black history that he took at the institute in 1971 gave him a new understanding of his black employees. ''It gave you a perspective of being black,'' he said.   Mr. Colvard, now with Johns Hopkins University, said the course might have been in the back of his mind when he appointed the first black technical director of a Naval laboratory. ''He was qualified and a talented person,'' Mr. Colvard said of his choice, adding, ''I was probably more sensitive to needing to have role models at that level, so they could serve as role models to other black scientists in the Navy community.'' Overhaul and Renovation    The institute is now overhauling its curriculum, borrowing bits and pieces from the most current management techniques in the private sector, the university environment and other areas of the Government. The change, by all accounts, is long overdue. Though it opened in 1968 on the cutting edge of executive training programs, the institute, by the early 1980's, was mired in what many describe as an outdated, ''touchy-feely'' approach to management.   Its physical plant is also undergoing a much-needed renovation, at an expected cost of $4 million. The run-down, unkempt hotel that houses the institute has changed little since it was built in 1953. Though the renovation will tackle maintenance problems and make the dormitory-style bedrooms more livable, Mr. Hansen cautions that the work is being done with the taxpayer in mind.   ''It will not be a posh hotel,'' he said, ''but it will be very comfortable.''   With the growing perception that the Civil Service is having difficulty attracting, motivating and retaining highly skilled workers, the institute has the potential to restore some luster to the upper echelons of Government management, Ms. Gwin said.   ''That's part of our mission in a sense, because we talk about people doing good work and part of it is to have executives in the Government feel like executives,'' Ms. Gwin said. ''It gives them a sense of pride. It helps them feel sort of revitalized.''

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Aug. 8 about the effect of Medicaid cutbacks on Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford misstated the percentage of its patients enrolled in Medicaid, the Federal health insurance for the poor.
Medicaid insures 20 percent of Mount Sinai's patients; an additional 8 percent have no insurance.

Turning Dirt Into Gold: Somebody Has to Do It
LEAD: AT the age of 21, Don Aslett was scrubbing toilets to pay his way through college.
At 54, this self-proclaimed ''Porcelain Preacher'' and ''Don Juan of the John'' is so busy writing books like ''Pet Clean-Up Made Easy'' and ''Clutter's Last Stand'' and zigzagging around the world giving seminars on housecleaning, he is forced to tidy up his hotel rooms until he can get home to give his toilet-bowl brush a good swish.


Anti-Government General Strike Leaves at Least 11 Dead in India
LEAD: Daily life was disrupted all over India today as a general strike called by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's political opponents closed shops, stopped trains and emptied streets and schools.

LEAD: Already acknowledged as the front-runner by her opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for New York City comptroller, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn last night began a $500,000 radio and television advertising campaign.

Ex-Official Says Reagan's Aides Often Used Influence at H.U.D.
LEAD: A former Government housing official who is at the center of Congressional inquiries has told a Federal grand jury that Reagan White House aides repeatedly sought to intervene in an urban renewal program once lauded as free of political influence.

LEAD: ''Largely New York,'' a comedy written and directed by Bill Irwin, is to close after Saturday evening's performance at the St.
James Theater, 246 West 44th Street.
The play will have run for 11 previews and 152 regular performances.

LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Jury Finds Helmsley Guilty Of Tax Evasion but Not Extortion
LEAD: Leona Helmsley, who runs a hotel empire with an iron will, a tart tongue and a self-bestowed title of Queen, was convicted yesterday of evading $1.2 million in Federal income taxes.


4 Killed in Plane Collision
LEAD: Two small planes collided and crashed Tuesday night, and all four people on board were killed, the authorities said.
The crash occurred in clear weather about a mile west of Harvey Field near here.
The planes were not under the direction of air traffic controllers, and the pilots were responsible for watching for other craft, said Errol van Eaton, a Federal Aviation Administration investigator.


2 Indicted for Murder in Racial Attack
LEAD: Two suspects in the racial attack on 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins were indicted yesterday on second-degree murder charges.


Belgian Is Named Director Of the Salzburg Festival
LEAD: Gerard Mortier, the director of La Monnaie, Belgium's national opera, has been named artistic director of the Salzburg Festival with a mandate to revamp a cultural showcase some critics say is elitist and conservative.

Wide Variety Is Found In Pharmacy Drug Cost
LEAD: Prescription drug prices vary widely around the country and even between drug stores in the same town, according to a private survey that found one pharmacy charging nearly $32 more for a heart medication than did a nearby competitor.


Cubs Trade Schiraldi
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs traded the pitcher Calvin Schiraldi, the outfielder Darrin Jackson and a minor league player to be determined to the San Diego Padres last night for the outfielder Marvell Wynne and the infielder Luis Salazar.


Accord Ends Phone Strike in Five Midwest States
LEAD: Michigan Bell agreed on a tentative contract for 12,800 telephone workers today, paving the way for 37,000 Ameritech workers in five Middle Western States to go back to work, company and union officials said.

LEAD: America has many problems, but one is entrenched in our culture, our history.
It has defied what we thought were solutions.
It is growing worse, eating away at the social fabric.
It cries out for leadership.
But there is no leadership.

Creatures That Glow In the Dark
LEAD: WHEN she was growing up in Arizona, Sue Scott's nickname was ''lizard.'' ''And I used to go trout fishing,'' said the Oakland, Calif., entrepreneur.
So the seminal products of her two-year-old company, Primal Lite, were strings of lights called ''Bunch-A-Lizards'' and ''Mess-O-Trout.''

LEAD: Robert Helmick's election today to the International Olympic Committee's executive board ended a calculated campaign to return the United States into the highest sphere of influence within the Olympic movement.

LEAD: Criticized as too classical and not garish and lively enough, the designs for four office towers in the Times Square redevelopment project have been overhauled.


Israel to Sell Big Stake In El Al
LEAD: El Al, Israel's national airline, announced yesterday that the Israeli Government plans to sell a large stake in the company to domestic and foreign investors.

New Designs for Times Square Try to Reflect Neon Atmosphere
LEAD: Bowing to intense public criticism, the planners of the Times Square redevelopment project yesterday presented entirely new designs for four office towers, including one with a 27-story built-in sign.


Wave of Vietnamese Refugees Straining Japan
LEAD: Braving distances of up to 1,500 miles at sea, thousands of boat people from Southeast Asia and China have begun arriving at Japanese shores in recent months, straining Japan's refugee centers and posing difficult new challenges for the Government.


Jet Lands in Emergency
LEAD: An American Airlines MD-80 jet made an emergency landing at an airport today after one of its three hydraulic systems failed, an airline spokesman said.
Flight 891, carrying 66 passengers and a crew of six from Oklahoma City to Dallas, returned to Will Rogers World Airport 11 minutes after taking off, said the spokesman.


Ulster Group Reports Use of Secret Data in Killing
LEAD: An outlawed Protestant group in Northern Ireland has asserted that it penetrated British security and used top-secret intelligence information to locate and kill a Roman Catholic man last week.

Tambo Had a Brain Spasm, African Rebel Group Says
LEAD: Oliver Tambo, the African National Congress president, has had a brain spasm, a spokesman for the black nationalist group said today.


Election by Publishers
LEAD: Russell T. Lewis, senior vice president for production for The New York Times, has been elected president of the New York Newspaper Publishers Association.
He succeeds Richard A. Myers, operating vice president of Ottaway Newspapers.
The election, for the 1989-90 term, took place this week at the association's 68th annual convention.

LEAD: The chief witness in baseball's investigation of Pete Rose testified in Federal court here today that Rose attempted to avoid paying taxes on race-track winnings.


Court Upholds Drug Testing For Civilian Workers in Army
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the Army may subject more than 6,500 of its civilian workers, including law enforcement and aviation personnel, to random drug tests.


Ponderosa To Buy Rival
LEAD: The owner of the Ponderosa steakhouses, the Metromedia Company, has agreed to buy the rival Bonanza steakhouse chain from USA Cafes L.P. for $10.25 in cash for each outstanding partnership unit, or about $70 million.


Yanks Dismiss Thrift's Top Aide
LEAD: Jim Bowden, Syd Thrift's top assistant with the Yankees, was told to leave the organization yesterday, one day after Thrift's departure.


New Currency In Yugoslavia
LEAD: Yugoslavia will introduce a new currency to help fight inflation, which is currently at an annual rate of 800 percent, a Government official said today.

Dorothy Schiff, 86, Ex-Post Owner, Dies
LEAD: Dorothy Schiff, owner of The New York Post for 37 years, died early yesterday in her apartment on the East Side of Manhattan.
She was 86 years old.


Talks on Cambodia Break Off in Anger
LEAD: As a monthlong international conference aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia ended in failure, the warring Cambodian factions angrily blamed each other today for the breakdown of the talks.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Painting Stained Pillars  Q.We live in an 83-year-old house that has a front porch with pillars made of hollow concrete sewer tiles stacked on top of each other and joined with cement.
They were apparently stained, but now are a splotchy red.
We want to paint them when we paint the rest of the house (gray with white trim).


Israel Criticized by U.N. for Deporting Arabs
LEAD: The Security Council today criticized Israel's deportation of Palestinians from the occupied territories and called for an end to the expulsions.


A Vote for Bicycles
LEAD: To The Home Section:


French Economy Slows
LEAD: The French economy grew by seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of 1989, about half the pace of the first three months of the year, the national statistics institute said today.
The report came a day after France reported its worst month external trade performance in a year - a July deficit of almost 7.5 billion francs ($1.14 billion).


Dow Edges Up 1.52 Points In Seesaw Trading Session
LEAD: Stock prices ended narrowly higher yesterday, buoyed by the strength in airline and pharmaceutical issues at one juncture, only to be weighted down by program selling and falling bond prices at the next.


Choosing the Home-Gym Advantage
LEAD: JOHN GREELEY started John Greeley's Fitness Plus in 1985, and since then his business, in Syosset, L.I., has increased twentyfold.
Mr.
Greeley or one of his staff will go to your home, take measurements and develop a floor plan for the room you wish to convert to a home gym.

LEAD: The Corcoran Gallery of Art here has beome the target of an artists' boycott because of its cancellation in June of a retrospective of the work of the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe.

LEAD: A man convicted of raping and murdering a 61-year-old woman in 1977 was executed tonight in Virginia's electric chair.

LEAD: THE idea is as simple as it is ingenious.
Why can't a side chair be available with a number of different arm designs?
The answer is it can.


Life Term in Drug-Rape Case
LEAD: A woman was sentenced Tuesday to life in prison for giving her 13-year-old daughter to a rapist in exchange for drugs.
The 29-year-old woman, Susan Barbier, who was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct in the May 1988 incident, was told by Judge James J. Rashid of Wayne County Circuit Court that he was exceeding the sentencing guidelines because she had ''very little, if any at all, potential for reformation.

LEAD: Christian and Muslim areas came under artillery bombardment again today after a French effort to negotiate a cease-fire between the warring parties apparently failed.

LEAD: Joe Collins, a first baseman for 10 years with the New York Yankees, died today at his home here.

Hospital Corp. Cuts Price of Deal
LEAD: The Hospital Corporation of America reduced by $100 million, to $1.125 billion, the sale price of its psychiatric division, which it is selling to the division's executives and an employee stock ownership plan.
The company said it would also retain ownership of $150 million in the new company's common stock and preferred stock along with warrants to buy additional shares of common stock.

Prisoner With AIDS Virus Wins Reversal of Conviction for Biting

An Ending Revealed
LEAD: To The Home Section:


The Good War
LEAD: Fifty years ago this week, Adolf Hitler fabricated a grotesque incident to justify a German attack on Poland.
He told his generals: ''It doesn't matter whether it is plausible or not.
The victor will not be asked by the vanquished whether he told the truth.
In starting or making war, it is not right which matters but victory.

LEAD: Acting in response to pressure to put an environmentalist on its board, the Exxon Corporation yesterday named John H. Steele, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts.

AMR Stock Up $1.50
LEAD: Shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, continued to move up amid speculation that there may be a bid for the company.
AMR climbed $1.50 a share yesterday, to $93, on the New York Stock Exchange.
On Tuesday, the stock jumped $10.25.
But analysts said that there was no evidence that a bid was forthcoming.

Youth's Funeral Focuses on Racial Divisions
LEAD: Yusuf K. Hawkins was buried yesterday in Brooklyn, and just as the 16-year-old black youth's death has been taken as a painful symbol of racial division, so, too, was his funeral used as an occasion to reflect not only on the dead young man but also on the state of race relations in New York City.

LTV Steel Closer To Sale of Unit
LEAD: The LTV Steel Company, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, reached a tentative agreement with the United Steelworkers of America that clears the sale of its bar division to an employee stock ownership plan.
LTV did not disclose terms of the sale, pending a vote of the union's membership in September, but industry experts have estimated the price would be between $200 million and $300 million.

Prices on Notes and Bonds Climb
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in generally dull trading yesterday, aided by a firmer dollar and a hint that the Federal Reserve Board may be on the verge of easing the cost of credit further.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart on Tuesday outlining the views of New York City mayoral candidates on health issues included an erroneous statistic from Mayor Edward I. Koch in some copies for medical surgical beds in hospitals in New York City.
Municipal hospitals have 16 percent of the medical surgical beds in the city, not 34 percent.

Review/Rock; Reunited Jefferson Airplane: Still Loose, Still Utopian
LEAD: Loose ends were a big part of psychedelic rock; they went with its improvisational spirit.
The reunited Jefferson Airplane, which opened a two-night stand Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, kept some of those loose ends in a generous, two-part concert that veered between the 1960's and the 1980's.
Although it had such modern trimmings as lighting effects, smoke machines and synthesizers, it was also refreshingly informal.

Uganda Stock Exchange
LEAD: Uganda plans to open a stock exchange early next year to help rehabilitate the country's economy, the market's organizers said today.
Leo Kibirango, former governor of the Bank of Uganda, said the stock exchange should help the economy by encouraging private industry and directing new investment to capital-starved businesses.

LEAD:  Debt


Farm Banks Given Triple-A Rating
LEAD: Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday that for the first time it had assigned a triple-A rating to about $29 billion in long-term debt of the Federal Farm Credit Banks, the Federal Land Banks and the Farm Credit System Financial Assistance Corporation.

Review/Theater; A Tosca Who Doesn't Sing And Ends in Scarpio's Arms
LEAD: Should there ever be a revival of interest in the plays of Terence Rattigan, ''Before Dawn'' will certainly not be in the vanguard of rediscoveries.
In fact, by offering the New York premiere of this flaccid sendup of ''Tosca,'' the Quaigh Theater is doing the late English playwright a disservice.


Panel to Examine Police Policies In New Jersey Town After Unrest
LEAD: In hopes of improving relations between this tense city's police force and its black and Puerto Rican residents, Mayor Harry Curley appointed a task force today to study four police policies, including minority recruitment.


Mutual Fund Yields Mixed
LEAD: Yields of the money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with those of tax-exempt funds rising and those of taxable funds declining.


Calendar: Children's Harvest Fair
LEAD:  Little Green Thumbs, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433.


AIRLINES ORDERED TO INSTALL DEVICE TO DETECT BOMBS
LEAD: In its strongest effort to counter attacks on airlines, the Government yesterday ordered American carriers to install a new type of bomb detector to check luggage at major airports in this country and overseas.


Seymour Krim, 67, Author and Essayist
LEAD: Seymour Krim, an author and critic, was found dead, apparently of a drug overdose, in his Manhattan apartment last night, the police said.


Corrections
LEAD: Articles between Aug. 25 and Aug. 30 about the racial killing of a black teen-ager in Brooklyn included an erroneous rendering of his name provided by the police.
His family says the correct name is Yusuf K. Hawkins.

Mayoral Rivals Offer Few New Ideas About Housing
LEAD: The six New York City mayoral candidates offer few new ideas for addressing the lack of affordable housing and the plight of the thousands of homeless New Yorkers.


Cities Cite Need for Child-Care Funds
LEAD: A lack of money is hampering local governments in dealing with child care and other problems involving children and teen-agers, the National League of Cities said Monday in appealing for long-term Federal assistance.

Helmsley's Personality Not an Issue, Jurors Say
LEAD: Months of testimony portraying Leona Helmsley as an arrogant and vindictive woman had little effect on the deliberations that led to a tax-evasion verdict against her, jurors said yesterday.

Market Place; Mutual Funds Come Back to Life
LEAD: Americans are putting more cash into mutual funds than at any time since the 1987 stock market crash, new figures released yesterday showed.
As a result of that and the market's 1989 rally, the total assets of stock and bond mutual funds now almost equal the record set just before the crash.


Government Is Issuing New Pilot's License Requiring Fewer Hours
LEAD: In an effort to lure more people into aviation and replenish the dwindling supply of airline pilots, the Government put rules into effect today to make it easier and less expensive to learn to fly.


A Prominent Trader Admits He Schemed To Rig a Stock Price
LEAD: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a leading Wall Street trader who was once a special adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges that he helped manipulate a stock price in the spring of 1986, in an action that benefited the American Express Company.


Flirting With Health Claim, Kellogg Announces a Cereal
LEAD: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that it will soon market a cereal that includes the grain psyllium, aimed at consumers anxious to reduce their blood cholesterol levels.
The product, known as Heartwise, follows the lead of General Mills' psyllium-based cereal Benefit, which was introduced last spring, and it is expected to touch off new conflicts about the health claims made for such cereals.


Dissenter Resumes Fight for Amdura
LEAD: A dissident shareholder in the Amdura Corporation, Frank Cilluffo, said that he would proceed with his plan to unseat Amdura's board and that materials had been mailed to the company's shareholders.
Mr.
Cilluffo and his investor group need the consent of 50 percent of Amdura's shareholders to unseat its board and to replace it with its own slate.


U.S. Officials' Families to Quit Bogota
LEAD: With tension running high in the second week of an intensified drug war in Colombia, the United States today ordered the evacuation of all dependents of American diplomats, and an overnight curfew was imposed in the bomb-shaken city of Medellin.


Alabama Bans Many Toxic Waste Shipments
LEAD: Alabama is banning hazardous waste shipments from 22 states and the District of Columbia to keep the state ''from becoming the waste dump of the nation,'' Gov.
Guy Hunt announced Tuesday.


Talking Deals; Holiday's Plan To Cut Incentives
LEAD: WHEN managers are given stock in a company, the goal is often to provide an incentive to make the company prosper.
But what happens when the managers get a lot of stock, and a lot of cash besides?
With the initial incentives gone, will the performance continue?


Herbert Loper, 92, Retired Army General
LEAD: Herbert B. Loper, a retired Army major general and former chairman of the Military Liaison Committee of the Atomic Energy Commission, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at the Palm Bay Care Center in Florida.
He was 92 years old and had lived in Bozman, Md., before entering the nursing home last year.


Savings-Unit Agency Plans 5 More Sales
LEAD: The agency created to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan institutions announced today that it was putting up for sale five institutions with $10.8 billion in total assets.
But officials said it may be as long as two months before any final deals will be struck.


4-for-1 Stock Split By Philip Morris
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday announced a stock split and a 22 percent dividend increase.
Philip Morris, maker of Marlboro cigarettes, Miller beer and other products, said it would split its stock four-for-one and raise its annual cash dividend to $5.50 a pre-split share from $4.50.
The company's shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $163.50, in active trading on the New York Stock


New Rules for Credit Cards
LEAD: Federal disclosure rules for credit cards take effect on Thursday, and they may foster competition that could lower interest rates for the nation's 107 million cardholders.


Sales Up Slightly for New York Retailers
LEAD: Most of New York's large retailers did not have a rewarding first half even though the women's apparel business revived, industry executives said yesterday in an informal survey.


Savings Unit's Ties to Boesky
LEAD: The Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, whose failure may cost the Government $2.5 billion, invested $100 million with Ivan F. Boesky, newspaper reports said today.
The Los Angeles Times and
